PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received through the Administrator of the Commonwealth of Australia from the Lieutenant-Governor of the State of Tasmania a certificate of the choice by the houses of parliament of Tasmania of Senator Kay Denman to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Senator Michael Carter Tate. I table a copy of the certificate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kay Denman made and subscribed the affirmation of allegiance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Senator Faulkner, departed for overseas on 27 August and will return on 6 September. He is leading a mission to attend the Western Front commemorative ceremonies in France and Belgium. During his absence, the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, Mr Howe, will act as Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, will cover the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Senator McMullan will act as Manager of Government Business. Up to and including Monday, 6 September, questions relating to the portfolio of defence science and personnel should be directed to Senator Ray and questions on veterans' affairs should be directed to Senator Richardson.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and is about honesty and credibility or lack of it. What did Mr Dawkins mean when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: As far as I am concerned, and the Government's concerned, this—

And what did Mr Willis mean when he said that any changes would only be `to minuscule parts of what has been proposed, at the very edges'? Are these statements accurate or are they simply more government lies?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody wants a situation in this country where every budget is a negotiating document and has to be negotiated each year between the executive and the parliamentary branches. That, as we have seen over many years, is the way in which budgets have been constructed in the United States with desperately unhappy implications so far as fiscal responsibility in that particular country is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the situation that governments of the day have to put down their budgets, assume the responsibility for them and assume the electoral responsibility for them at the regular intervals that are provided under our constitution for executive governments to be tested. Of course it is the case that budgets must be constructed in that way and that it is utterly inappropriate, as Mr Dawkins and others have been saying, for those budgets to be regarded as an open-ended negotiating document, even if the circumstances may be such, with the construction of the parliament, that obviously some opportunities for such a course are open to the other side.

I simply make the point—and it is one I hope the opposition bears very firmly in mind if it ever has any pretensions to once again lead this country, to be the government of this country—that that is no way to go and that the opposition, contributing as it has to the process of assaulting this particular budget, is buying up a store of trouble for itself in the unhappy event that this country should ever give it the vote of confidence that it claims.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of credibility, what is the credibility of the opposition when it comes to macro-economic management when one considers the statement made by Dr Hewson—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This was not a question about the opposition's credibility. It has no relevance whatsoever. I ask you to draw the minister's attention to the standing orders.
—Order! He was asked about the budget negotiations and credibility, but I remind Senator Gareth Evans of the question.
—I am very happy to respond to the question, Mr President, and I am doing just that.
—Are the statements accurate?

—I am making the point that if the opposition or any member of its front bench calls in aid the question of credibility, as we have heard from Senator Short, as a basis for assaulting what this government has been about with this particular budget or its response in recent days to the obvious pressures that do exist and to which we have indicated that we are going to make a response, it has to look at the mote in its own eye. I remind honourable senators of just how large that particular mote is when we look at what Dr Hewson had to say in his response to the budget—
—Mr President, on point of order, again.
—You are very embarrassed about that. It was a very embarrassing speech.

—No. If those opposite want a debate on Dr Hewson, they will get the debate, but not in question time. The Minister was asked a question which he is not now answering. He wants to debate the opposition and he should stay within the standing orders in the same way that everyone else has to.
—Order! Senator Evans should not talk about opposition policies, but again I remind people on my left that a lot of the remarks have been made in response to interjections.

—There is no trouble not talking about opposition policies because we have seen after last weekend that there is no such animal. All I ask is that if the government's credibility is going to be assessed and judged on this particular budget and the current course of events, that must be weighed and balanced against the credibility of someone who proposes to increase the deficit in 1993-94 by almost $1,400 million and by more than $3,000 million in 1996-97. Dr Hewson and Mr Downer would increase the deficit in each of the next four years which would leave that deficit in 1996-97 over 50 per cent more than what it is now.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is an outrageous misuse of question time. The question was: why did Mr Dawkins say specifically that this was not a negotiating document? The minister has not even attempted to answer that question. If he is going to rabbit on about other matters, you ought to sit him down.
—Order! I believe the minister has finished.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask Senator Evans whether those statements were accurate. I was trying to get some indication of whether Mr Dawkins and Mr Willis, when they say things, are being truthful. I ask the minister: how can the people of Australia ever have any faith or trust in anything said by any member of this government in the future? Does the minister agree that Paul Keating will `wear the tag of liar for the rest of his political career'?
—That is out of order. I ask the senator to withdraw.
—Order! It is clearly out of order. It has been ruled by many presidents before me that a direct reference to another member of parliament lying is out of order.
—Mr President, I will accept your ruling while pointing out that I am quoting from a newspaper report.
—Order! Quoting from a newspaper has also been ruled out of order.

—Could I rephrase it, Mr President, by asking Senator Evans—not personally, but as a member of the government and talking about the government—whether he agrees with the following: when talking about the budget, `Were you lying then, or are you lying now, or are you not a chronic and habitual liar'?
—Is it within standing orders to ask the question, Mr President, with the imputation it conveys? If it is, I am happy to answer it. I am seeking a ruling.
—I will ask Senator Evans to answer the question.

—The short answer is of course not, and nor can that allegation be made against anyone in this government. The only claim that has ever been made in this chamber about the breaking of promises was in the context of Mr Keating's statement before the last election to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment—`in other words, I am promising not to put up tax'. That particular commitment was made squarely, as I have said a dozen times, in the context of maintaining tax to GDP ratios. Those ratios—of that order of magnitude—will be maintained, as we have constantly said.

PARA.TAB: We have said that we would not introduce a broad based consumption tax. We did not introduce a broad based consumption tax, a GST or anything like it. That is the context in which we put this budget down. The economic credibility of that budget has been demonstrated and acknowledged and responded to. There may be particular problems with it at the margin that we are going to address, as has been indicated, but there is no fundamental change to the budget strategy as has been laid down, nor should there be, nor will there be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science. In May this year the Minister announced the establishment of an advisory committee to examine strategies designed to encourage greater participation of women in science and engineering courses and careers. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the progress of this committee and how he will help to overcome the problem of low participation of girls and women in science.
—Where are the women on your front bench? You have only one.

—I notice that Senator Kemp always treats these matters with hilarity. It is typical of his commitment; typical of the Liberal Party. In May of this year I announced the establishment of an advisory committee to look at the problem of the lack of women's participation in certain science and engineering professions in Australia. This came about as a result of discussions with a number of people and also just my own anecdotal observation, having gone to a number of science forums and noting, in the middle and upper levels of science administration and engineering administration in Australia, the complete absence of women.

PARA.TAB: The working party has terms of reference that will examine the low participation of women and the retention rates of women in these professions, the career progression and reasons for why women would be dropping out of these professions after they have received their training.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this your initiative or is it from the Public Service?

—I can tell Senator Macdonald that this is in the private sector as well as in the public sector. Today I am pleased to announce that Professor Ann Henderson-Sellers has agreed to chair this advisory committee. In the next few days I anticipate announcing the membership of the rest of the advisory committee which will, of course, include men as well as women. Professor Ann Henderson-Sellers presently is a research director and teacher at the Climatic Impact Centre, a member of the ASTEC, a member of the research reactor review, and a member of a number of international organisations. She has risen to the top of her profession and has a well-recognised standing in her profession within the science community in Australia. I am very pleased she was able to accept my invitation to chair this committee.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the community understand that as a community we lose because many women do not continue with their careers. Overwhelmingly it is a cost to the community to train people to be scientists and engineers. When many of them complete only a few years in their careers before they leave to have families and so on, and never return, the community has lost its investment in their training. It is not just at the university level that there is a problem with the number of women enrolling; there is also very much a problem of ensuring that the structure of their profession enables them to have families and meet their family commitments without in any way suffering in their career progression.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you knew so much about it, Sue Ryan would still be in parliament.
—Order! It is not a debate.
—If you lot behaved properly, Susan Ryan would still be here. You know that.

—I am very surprised at Senator Vanstone. She comes in here, shouting and screaming about the role of women, and as soon as one of us announces something all she does is get up and whinge and whine and show great cynicism towards it.
—Order! It is a very interesting debate but it has nothing to do with the question.
—Too right it has, Mr President.
—Thank you, Mr President.
—You will never be forgiven for what you did.
—Senator Vanstone, you will cease interjecting.

—I am very pleased that this advisory group, to be chaired by Professor Ann Henderson-Sellers, will be able to report to the government and look at ways of encouraging women not only to enrol—in engineering, for example, only about 10 per cent of the enrollees are women—but also to be able to continue their careers, in view of their training, throughout the rest of their lives without having to suffer the impediments that having a family and family responsibilities can sometimes bring to a career. I think this is an important initiative for ensuring that women get a fair go in science and engineering in Australia.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why should the Australian people not see the government's watering down of this year's budget as confirmation that the budget was indeed an act of bastardry? If the Prime Minister is serious about addressing the community outrage over the aggressive taxes in the budget, why does he not simply stand by his commitment to the Australian people not to increase taxation?

—This is a caring and responsible government, and we are always prepared to respond in a caring and responsible way when particular groups in the community make a strong case as to the effect of particular measures. We are prepared to reconsider some of those measures, provided that can be done in a fiscally responsible way. It is absolutely crucial for the effective management of this country and the interests of everybody in it that we continue to govern in a fiscally responsible way.

PARA.TAB: It is crucially important that we not go to the people promising to do things like increase the deficit in 1993-94 by $1.4 million, or saying that we are prepared to increase that deficit by $3 billion in 1996-97, which is something like 50 per cent on top of what we have undertaken to do. There is a very dramatic difference between the degree of responsibility that we have brought to these budget decisions and these budget discussions and that totally irresponsible, opportunistic approach which has been brought to that debate and so obviously and crassly stated in the parliament by the opposition leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister might think it is legitimate to laugh at those who are particularly hurt by his regressive taxation, but what does he say, therefore, to those who made investment decisions last week on the basis of the government's assurances that the budget was not a negotiating document? Having lied to the Australian people before the election and further betrayed them by the budget, is it not about time that this government started telling the truth?

—I have already made it clear that the document is not a negotiating document in the terms in which Senator Hill has tried to portray it. There is a situation, which I have indicated, where some particular measures might appropriately require some re-evaluation as a result of discussions that have occurred and that are ongoing. But that is a very distant thing from saying that this budget that we have put down as a responsible act of government economic decision making is a negotiating document.

PARA.TAB: It is a tough budget certainly, because times are tough and the need is obviously there for the fiscal discipline and the monetary discipline that is associated with that, and we accept that particular responsibility. But to make the judgment that we have that there are some changes that need to be made as a result of the particular impact of measures that have been the subject of public debate is not for a moment to concede that henceforth in this country budgets should be regarded as simply open for negotiation, an opening salvo in an exchange, rather than something which represents a considered statement of responsible government policy. That is the position we will adhere to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to efforts by Australian law enforcement agencies to prevent this country being subject to penetration by organised crime. Is the minister able to inform the Senate of action taken to prevent entry into Australia of the alleged Yakuza baron, Masaru Takumi?

—Senator Loosely raises a matter which first came to light a couple of months ago. At that time it generated considerable public interest, particularly I think in Queensland, and Senator Jones raised the matter in the Senate as well.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the inquiries at the time, I asked my department urgently to investigate Mr Takumi's case in particular and also the general question of visa issue to other persons with similar associations. The government takes the position that these matters are of public importance and we are not prepared to tolerate any potential threat to the Australian community as a whole emanating from such situations. As a consequence, on 21 July I cancelled the visa of Mr Masaru Takumi. I took this action under section 180A of the Migration Act on the basis of Mr Takumi's admitted membership of the Yamaguchi-Gumi, the Yakuza group which the relevant Australian law agencies advise is an organisation which does have associations with organised crime in Japan.
I took that action then and I also signal now that others in similar situations who wish to come to Australia will find a similar response from this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the analysis of the 1993-94 budget by Dr Neil Warren of the University of New South Wales. The analysis finds that this budget dramatically widens the gap between the rich and the poor in this country. Does the government agree with Dr Warren's analysis? I expect he will say he does not, so has the Treasurer instructed Treasury to model the distributional effects of the budget changes in order to challenge Dr Warren's findings or is this just too hard?

—We do disagree with the conclusion that has been drawn in that particular piece of analysis. I am advised that we have instructed the Treasury to do some modelling on the impact of the budget as it was brought down and also the impact, perhaps, of alternative measures that might be contemplated. The results of that will, as I understand it, be made public quite soon, perhaps as early as within a day or so, although that is, of course, a matter for the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: It is not a matter simply of the government making counter-assertions in this matter. We believe the point can be made very substantially and very accurately. It follows of course from the fact that over the course of this government's lifetime we have introduced a great many measures which have significantly increased the position of low income earners relative to those with higher incomes, and that tradition has been continued in a number of the aspects of this particular budget which have received, unhappily, much less attention than some of those impacts of the budget which work the other way.When one does that balancing out, the results are by no means those that have been predicted by a number of commentators and analysts. My understanding is that that will become clear when this analysis is published.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. What is the composition of the GATT disputes panel for the second Tuna-Dolphin case? What are the criteria for the selection of panel members to these dispute panels? Who is responsible for appointing members to these panels? Has former Australian trade commissioner to GATT, Alan Oxley, been chosen as a member of the disputes panel for the Tuna-Dolphin case? If so, on what basis? Given his opposition to environmental concerns, as outlined in his paper The looming issue of trade and environment, does this pre-suppose his recommendation on the outcome of that case? If not, why not?
—There are five questions here and I have two minutes to answer them; I will do my best to get across them all.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Four, four!

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, maybe I will be able to get across all of them. I understand that Mr Alan Oxley, in a paper given to a recent Fenner conference on trade and the environment, indicated to the audience that he could not comment on the Tuna-Dolphin case that is before the GATT for the reason that he had been selected to sit on the panel. I should record, therefore, that I think that is an entirely appropriate action for anyone adjudicating on such a case.

PARA.TAB: The panel consists of a former Brazilian ambassador to the GATT, Mr George Maciel, Mr Winfried Lang, a former Austrian ambassador to the GATT, and Mr Alan Oxley, the former Australian ambassador to the GATT. There are several criteria for selecting panel members. The panels are composed of people who are well qualified, either from government or non-government organisations. They cannot be from contending countries in the procedure before the GATT; they have to be from third countries. Panel members are to serve in their individual capacities and not as government representatives, nor can they represent any organisation. The governments cannot give them instructions or seek to influence them as individuals on matters that are before the panel and, importantly, panel members should be selected with a view to ensuring that they are independent and of a sufficiently diverse background and have a wide spectrum of experience.

Responsibility for appointing panel members lies with the Director-General of the GATT, in consultation with the parties involved in the dispute. Often they all agree on who should be on the panel. In default of agreement, in consultation the director-general can appoint members to the panel. In doing so, he calls on people who he thinks have the appropriate skills for the case that is to be considered. I believe that Mr Oxley was included in this particular case by the director-general. He was not on any list that we put forward, nor did he go forward on the sponsorship of this government; he was selected by the director-general himself and for this particular case. Mr Oxley is a former Australian ambassador to the GATT. He is now a managing director of a private company—International Trade Strategies Pty Ltd. The Australian government has had no role in his selection.

To the question about the environmental concerns in his paper, whether Mr Oxley is an impartial judge of environmental and trade issues is a subjective judgment for all of us to make. I do not purport to make a judgment about the degree of impartiality or otherwise, but I do say that, from my experience, Mr Oxley is held in high esteem in a wide section of the community in Australia and is regarded as being able to conduct himself properly and fairly in all the circumstances. But it is not for me to comment on his selection or otherwise and I do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Considering Mr Oxley's widely publicised views on removing environmental concern as a basis of trade, does this choice of Mr Oxley mean that the government would prefer to allow GATT to prohibit trading choices based on their environmental implications as unfair trading practices under the rules of the Uruguay Round of GATT?
—With the greatest of respect to the honourable senator, I must say that this question springs from a defective knowledge of what the GATT does.
—You will get used to this sort of gratuitous comment from him.

—It is not a gratuitous comment. When a question is asked of the government which is founded on a wrong notion, it is appropriate for that wrong notion to be pointed out, and I do so with the greatest of respect to Senator Margetts.

PARA.TAB: The Director-General of the GATT has chosen Mr Oxley. We as a government have had no role in that. Therefore, it is not appropriate for the government to be held to answer for the choice. That is the GATT's decision and we acknowledge and respect it.

As far as the Australian government is concerned, we have stood up publicly on environmental issues in all the appropriate forums around the world. This government's record on that is without parallel in the history of this federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the Winemakers Federation's initial estimate that the 55 per cent increase in tax on wine will cost at least 650 jobs in the wine industry immediately and many more over time. Given the budget speech statement that `the primary objective of this budget is jobs', I ask the minister whether the government has sought and been supplied with Public Service advice on the number of jobs that could be lost as a result of the massive increase in wine tax. If so, what is the advice?

—Every time tax is increased on any industry it immediately indicates that this is the end of Western civilisation. I can remember it was stated with great strength by the wine industry when it was first taxed that the industry would certainly go into decline as a consequence. It has subsequently gone from strength to strength. The likelihood that there will be an impact on the propensity to consume wine—
—Do you think it will increase their sales, Bob?
—Will it have any effect on jobs?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—This is an attempt to cast pearls before swine, Mr President. There is no evidence to sustain the view that the propensity to consume wine is so volatile that it will be affected in anything like the manner suggested by the industry in respect of the increase from 20 to 31 per cent. Reasonably obviously, if that is the point, we do not accept that the employment consequences will be anything like those which the industry outlines.

PARA.TAB: Having spent the last three years dealing with matters of tax for the government, I can say that it is always true that every industry can tell you that if only it was not taxed it could employ a lot more and it would have an advantage over all those industries with which it competes. It is not our intention to give this industry or any other an advantage over the industries with which it competes through the tax system. We have every confidence that, notwithstanding the pessimistic statements of the industry, it will continue to succeed as it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask again: is the minister saying that the government did not seek or receive advice on the job losses that will result from the decision to increase the wine tax?
—I have no intention of outlining here the nature of any advice from any department to any minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I refer to the recent approval by the Queensland Environment Court of construction of a woodchip mill at Owanyilla Siding south of Maryborough, which will provide more than 100 jobs in that area. The woodchip, from pine trimmings, will be used in Japan for the paper industry. I ask: does the minister see this project as yet another sign of industry having confidence in the government's economic policies?

—I guess this is yet another example of Senator Jones's dedication to the interests of his constituents in Queensland that he should ask a question about developments in his state. As referred to in Senator Jones's question, I understand that this important investment has now completed all of the requirements of local, state and Commonwealth government approvals. That includes an environmental impact study which was, I understand, completed last year and which addressed all the Commonwealth, state and local government concerns. So much so that on 27 November last year the then Minister for Resources, Alan Griffiths, announced in-principle export approval for this particular project. I understand that shortly the joint venture will formally request a woodchip export licence.

PARA.TAB: The project involves significant long term investment by both Australian and foreign investors. It clearly illustrates confidence in the government's economic policies and is an example of the cooperative approach between Commonwealth, state and local governments in facilitating investment in resource processing industries.

The project also demonstrates that Australia and foreign investors have confidence in the future of the plantation based forest industry in this country. The project will generate substantial jobs in the Maryborough region; creating through direct and indirect employment more than 100 jobs in the construction phase and about 270 jobs once it is operational. It will generate an annual export income of about $20 million a year.

The project involves the processing into woodchips of 1.7 million cubic metres of thinnings to be harvested from state owned pine plantations in the Gympie, Maryborough and Bundaberg region over a 10-year period. The woodchips will be substantially exported through the port of Gladstone to Japan to be used in the manufacture of pulp and paper. The thinnings program will enable the remaining trees to grow to a mature size and to be harvested later as sawlogs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to her special portfolio responsibilities in the area of families. Was the decision to impose a massive tax increase on leaded fuel taken out of concern for the health of children and families, or was it basically just a revenue measure?

—I suppose it is a long trawl that this question is actually addressed to me, but I am very happy to answer it, particularly in terms of the impact of lead on the health of children and women in this society. There is a very valid reason for wanting to reduce the lead levels in the air breathed by citizens of this country. Those opposite who know the difficulties for people in Port Pirie and around smelting works would know the evidence about the damaging effects of lead and would know entirely the proper process and outcome that one would expect from reducing lead levels in petrol.

PARA.TAB: There is absolutely no doubt about it that the arguments for reducing lead, in terms of the health outcomes of Australian citizens, are very valid. It is quite surprising to hear the opposition argue, as I suspect it is, that we should not reduce leaded petrol because it will not have those health impacts. There is no doubt at all that reducing the use of leaded petrol will reduce the amount of lead that is available for Australian children and adults to breathe. It is now clear that the lead levels that can have a deleterious impact on children are actually judged to be lower than was previously thought. So it is of concern that we seriously consider making sure those lead levels come down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of that answer, can the minister inform us of some of the evidence on which the government has based its decision that increasing the price of fuel will improve the health of children and families, or is it really just a case of the government being caught out lying again?
—As my colleague Senator McMullan just said, there is no way you would want to reveal the advice given to government in making its budget decisions.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me finish. There may well be information I can obtain from my colleague Minister Kelly, or from the health minister Senator Richardson, or from the science minister Senator Schacht, all of whom have carriage of this matter. If there is such data, I will certainly find it and make it available to Senator Ferguson.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In answer to a question from Senator Spindler in the last sitting week Senator Cook described the proposed US energy tax which sought to tax the energy content of goods and services, including imports, as `a non-tariff barrier to trade' and, by extension, not a legitimate environmental measure within the terms of GATT. Could the minister list the criteria which have been developed within the Uruguay Round by which these judgments can be made, that is, judgments which differentiate between non-tariff barriers to trade and environmental measures? What has Australia contributed to the development of these criteria? Have experts in environmental management been involved in the development of these criteria and, if so, who are they?

—I think the question I answered was asked on 19 August. The answer I gave was that Australia did not oppose anything the Clinton administration was doing on energy taxes in the United States—the BTU tax, as it was called then. What we did make representations about was a proposal attached to it which came from the House of Representatives that there be the imposition of an imports tax on energy—on the energy content of imports. In any case, that was knocked out in the Senate and the BTU tax—the British thermal unit tax—was then dropped by the Clinton administration. It is essential to get that point clear. One would have to say that the proposed tax that the House of Representatives was considering was not, in the classic sense, a non-tariff barrier but it was particularly discriminatory against imports and for that reason we were concerned.

PARA.TAB: The proposed tax on imports raises the issue of consistency with provisions in the GATT. Therefore, it was the GATT we were concerned about, not the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations which are being held under the auspices of the GATT. The provisions in the GATT have been there for the 40 years of the GATT's existence, though there have been subsequent related discussions in the form of a working party and panel reports on the general issue of border tax adjustments for imports. In other words, these have been the standard rules for the GATT almost since the GATT's inception. Lately there have been some discussions about border tax arrangements. It is not part of the Uruguay Round outcome; it is part of the general rules of the GATT. Thus the appropriate answer to Senator Coulter's first question is—none; to the second question—not applicable; and to the third question—not applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Substituting the word `GATT' for `Uruguay Round', am I to assume—because I have read the original GATT agreement—that there are no criteria by which one can differentiate between non-tariff barriers to trade and environmental measures within those arrangements which, as the minister says, go back 40 years?

—Since Senator Coulter has read the articles of GATT, he would know that they have set up an organisation to oversee fair and open trade—not one which deals with the setting of standards. For example, labour standards are set by the International Labour Organisation; environmental standards were set in part by the Rio summit as well as a number of other international things. The GATT comprehends those, but its concern is to see that trade is not distorted by the manipulation of standards of whatever sort; to provide non-tariff barriers to trade and thus distort free trade patterns. It flows from my answer to Senator Coulter's question that GATT does not turn its mind to whether or not something is environmentally sound; it turns its mind to whether environmental issues are being manipulated to prevent free and fair trade.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Ms Pamela Bornhorst

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the government's involvement in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation—that is, it appoints the ABC board—has the minister or the ABC management received any complaints about the presenter of the ABC's 7.30 Report, Pamela Bornhorst? Why was it so urgent that Ms Pamela Bornhorst be sacked when her contract was due for renewal in only a couple of months time? Why was it so important that the issue could not have been left to the local management, instead of the national director, Philip Chubb, and the general manager, David Hill, having to fly to Brisbane to do the task? Did the fact that the Queensland Premier and a number of state ministers were refusing to appear on the program have any bearing on her sacking?

—As I have said in response to a number of similar questions over the years, staffing arrangements of the ABC are a matter for the management of the ABC, and that is the way it will remain. I am certainly happy to inquire about this specific issue for Senator Boswell and provide him with whatever advice I can. But it is certainly a matter for ABC management to determine the disposition of its staff.

PARA.TAB: As far as the last part of the question about the refusal of various ministers to appear on the program is concerned, I have no knowledge of that, although I would have to say from my own experience in the Northern Territory that the refusal of ministers to appear on the 7.30 Report and on ABC radio, which has happened at regular intervals from time to time, has never ever deterred ABC broadcasters from continuing to broadcast programs or provide any disposition of staff. From my own observations, even attempts by government ministers to strangle ABC journalists have not deterred those same journalists from turning up again to attempt to interview people. So I do not think that issue would have been at all relevant to the question of what happened to this particular staffer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think Gossie might have put some political pressure on?

—There is no political pressure, at least successfully, applied to the ABC in terms of the disposition of individual members of staff, and I have said that repeatedly for all of the time I have represented that portfolio here in the Senate. I will happily take up this matter that Senator Boswell has raised with the ABC and get him an answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for advising that he will refer the matter back to the Senate. Was the minister informed that Ms Bornhorst's contract would have been cancelled?
—I was not personally informed of that but I will inquire as to whether the Minister for Communications, Mr Beddall, was informed of that matter, and respond to Senator Boswell as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the minister aware that community based women's health groups have expressed concern that during the last election the government undertook to extend the national women's health program for only one year? Can the minister outline the support given to women's health in the recent budget?

—I am very pleased to answer this question because, as the community based women's health groups said, the election promise was to extend the national women's health program for one year. In fact, what we have done in the budget is to increase it by four years.
—One of many?

—Senator Kemp, it is indeed one of many promises that have been honoured in my portfolio area. We did not just honour this promise for one year; as I said, we have extended the national women's health program to four years. That is a matched program of Commonwealth and state dollars.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators opposite would be very pleased to know the pleasure with which the national women's health program is accepted by the community. It is a program that has a long way to run because there are still many needs in women's health that this program is meeting which were not previously being met by the mainstream health services. It is also true that many women still say that mainstream health services are less than fully sympathetic to their needs. It is very useful to have this national women's health program which will continue to provide special regard and sympathy to women and women's health.

The funds provided for the national women's health program total $30 million over the next four years to be matched by the states. I can assure the Senate that that program is being well met by the states. I have heard of no objection from the states and I would be very surprised if any were forthcoming. Over the next four years I look forward to that program continuing the good work that has already been established.

We have also increased the money for the alternative birthing program which is very much part of the national women's health program. It is another program that has been very well accepted by the community. Increasingly women as well as men are arguing as to why we need to have so much interference at the time of birth. The evidence is a matter of concern. I have certainly asked questions about this in the past. I am now very interested to note in this new role the concern out in the community about the number of times that childbirth is initiated or manipulated by the profession or that there is interference such as a caesarean section or an instruments delivery. More and more people are saying that they should be given the option of a natural as possible childbirth. This program allows women to have the support of a midwife at home if they so choose or to have the baby born in an alternative birthing room in hospitals. Funding for those alternative birthing services in large hospitals has been one very successful part of this program.

In the election we also promised, for the first time ever, a longitudinal study for women's health. This is a very exciting initiative by government because for too long we have had women's health judged on the basis of data about men. That is an insufficient way of providing facts or building policy on women's health. Not too long ago, as I have said before, data on 350,000 men was measured and provided to women along the lines of `If women want to know if they are fit and healthy, this data has been adapted for them'. That is not sufficient. This government is addressing that by initiating this longitudinal study which for the first time will give us a much larger database of statistics and data on which we can then build policies for women into the future.

I might say that the other day our breast cancer screening program was very much supported by Minister Phillips in New South Wales at the launch of yet other program in that state. I take heart from the state governments' support for what this government is doing in the national women's health area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Are the government's proposed new taxes on accumulated holiday and long service leave being collected? If so, is this legal considering that there has been no change to the act and therefore no change to the rates? Has the Australian Taxation Office taken steps to inform employers not to collect this increased tax until the act is changed? What happens to tax already collected illegally?
—I am not sure that I heard the question correctly. Does the question relate to the long service and annual leave tax?
—Yes.

—I am not aware of any steps being taken to collect this tax prior to the legislation. If there are, I will inquire into it. I am not aware of it. I have not been informed of any such measure. It is different from the circumstances with regard to other legislation in the sales tax area where the history has sometimes been different because of the nature of the operation of sales taxes. I will inquire into it for Senator Parer. I am not aware of that situation occurring. So far as I know it is not occurring, but I cannot say definitely because I do not know. I will inquire and I will advise the honourable senator.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in response to that answer from Senator McMullan in respect of taxes being collected prior to legislation being introduced. What is the case in respect of the proposed tax increases on leaded fuel if, as it appears, the government is going to amend that tax on leaded fuel? What happens now to the taxes already collected?
—While I think it is highly unlikely that the question is actually a supplementary to the first, I will say that the assumption upon which Senator Parer has based his question is not well founded.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Tony Mulvihill. On behalf of all senators, I welcome him on this visit to Canberra.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What taxation treatment was applied by the Fisher Labor government in 1915 to the income of trade unions, friendly societies and credit unions? What Labor principles motivated that decision? Did not those same Labor principles motivate Labor Treasurer Frank Crean to restore the exemption of interest income derived from members by credit unions after the courts had ruled that the mutuality principle did not apply as previously thought? What motivates this government in its 1993 budget, which increased taxation of workers' friendly societies and credit unions, and will that not put them at a competitive disadvantage compared with life offices and banks which have much larger client bases over which to spread the fixed cost of regulations, for example, by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission?
—This will test your history, Bob.
—Yes, I have to say that I will capitulate—
—You'll have to take this one on notice, too.

—No, I will capitulate to others on the history lesson from Senator Harradine, but his question really went to the substance of why measures have been taken in this budget. That is the matter on which he really wants me to provide an answer, I am sure, and that is the matter to which I will address myself. I assume, for the purpose of the answer, that he is correct with regard to Andrew Fisher.

PARA.TAB: The problem with which the government found itself faced was that the exemption, as it previously existed, provided credit unions with an unfair competitive advantage when compared with the tax treatment of other financial institutions. These days, credit unions provide a range of services similar to those of other financial institutions and there is no justification for the tax exemption on the basis of the sorts of services provided. Building societies and other financial institutions are taxed and have to compete with credit unions. Effectively, the tax exemption provided credit unions with a cheap source of funds subsidised by the taxpayers.

Group asset growth for credit unions has been higher than for building societies and substantially higher than for banks. The credit union industry has high levels of compliance with the new prudential standards, including risk weighted capital requirements. There is no evidence to suggest that taxation would materially weaken the overall capacity of the industry to comply with its minimum capital requirements because, without going into all the details about how it might apply, by definition, only profitable credit unions will pay the tax.

The measure includes a significant adjustment period, especially for smaller credit unions, which goes to some of the concerns that Senator Harradine raised. While the credit union movement has played a very substantial and positive role in Australian history—and I would not, in any way, wish to question that, having been peripherally involved in it myself—I do not think it can any longer expect to build its financial strength on a tax exemption and a competitive advantage.

I think the inherent merits and virtues of many credit unions will indicate that they will go on from strength to strength, notwithstanding the tax change. The credit union movement will survive and thrive on its competitive merits, on the quality of its services and the special connections it can develop with its members—which credit unions have a capacity to do over and above many other financial institutions—rather than being a tax driven advantage which does not seem to be appropriate any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that the Artful Dodger in Charles Dickens's novel Oliver Twist was a pickpocket who lived in constant fear of being caught and that his real name was John Dawkins? Can the minister appreciate the resemblance between the current Australian Treasurer and the Artful Dodger, especially as both are called John Dawkins, both pick people's pockets surreptitiously, and both live in fear of being caught? Would he agree that Treasurer Dawkins has been caught by his mates in the union movement for picking too many pockets too frequently and told to rewrite his budget?

—All I can say, contemplating that question and contemplating what Dr Hewson had to say about the opposition's approach to this tax policy last week, is that I would describe him, whatever he looks like, as Bill Sykes the burglar and Alexander Downer as Bill Sykes's dog.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Following the successful launch of the navy's first Collins class submarine in Adelaide last weekend, can the minister advise the Senate of what this signifies for the future of Australia's defence industry? Further, will the minister give the Senate details of the letter of intent he and the Swedish Minister for Defence signed in Canberra last Friday?

—I am sure that everyone, including the many senators who attended on Saturday, enjoyed the launch ceremony for the submarine. It had much more than merely symbolic significance in my view, because what we were seeing on that day was the most elaborately transformed manufacturing project in this country's history. I think it is important more than from just a defence point of view; it shows that this country, when it puts its mind to it, can get itself involved in the most sophisticated manufacturing projects around. It should not just be in the defence field but right across secondary industry where we can do these things.

PARA.TAB: The project was on time and on cost, with enhanced capability. Furthermore, it also showed that, cooperating with other countries, there was a smooth technology transfer and a highly skilled work force—so skilled indeed that, in the welding area at least, some of our tradesmen have been going to Sweden to assist Sweden in its own submarine building.

I did sign on Friday of last week a letter of intent with the Swedish minister, which mostly went to the question of future joint cooperation, not just in submarines but in any other defence equipment, and in some of the potential markets in our own region. That will be translated some time around about Christmas into a renewed and enlarged memorandum of understanding. I think the prospects are quite good for further cooperation between the government of Sweden and the Australian defence industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the government's proposal to increase tax revenue by tighter provisions relating to travel expenses in excess of reasonable limits. The government's sources suggest that the prescribed public service rates which are used for substantiation purposes will be the relevant benchmarks. Given that the new provisions involve raising revenue through the fringe benefits tax regime and are not expense substantiation issues, does not the government's legislative methodology contravene the constitution in the manner in which it proposes to deal this bill?

—I would have thought that was a question that only my esteemed colleague the Minister representing the Attorney-General could answer, but instead of dumping it on him, let me say this: I think the general view of most Australians is that the intent of these measures is something that they strongly support because it involves very fundamental questions of equity about the rights of people to claim expenses, to which most Australians do not even aspire, and have them subsidised by the taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: I think the principle underpinning the legislation is sound. It is driven by a principle that not only is sound but also would have very widespread support and is equitable. As far as I am aware, nobody has raised the question of the constitutionality of the provision. I will seek advice on that. It seems to me, on the face of it, an unlikely proposition; nevertheless, I realise that Senator Watson raises these issues genuinely and usually on good advice, so I will seek a response to him on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and it relates to the international problem of substandard shipping which was highlighted by the recent report Ships of shame. I note that the United Nations International Maritime Organisation encourages members to conclude regional agreements on cooperation in the application of ship inspection programs. I ask the minister: what action is being taken by Australia to encourage regional cooperation on this matter?

—The short answer to the question is: a great deal. Australia has been instrumental in assisting cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region with the aim of coordinating measures to identify and reduce the number of substandard ships that are trading in this part of the world. The International Maritime Organisation has for some time encouraged its member nations to conclude regional agreements for cooperative application of port state control measures. These allow sharing of data collected from the inspection of foreign vessels in each country's ports and promote compatibility of information systems between regions.
—He is just behind you, Bob; just hand it over to him.

—I would have thought that Senator Ian Macdonald, representing the biggest port in northern Australia, would have treated this question a little more seriously than he is clearly doing. Such agreements already exist between European coastal states and, more recently, between 10 Latin American countries, with discussions also under way between Africa and Middle East regions.

PARA.TAB: In the Asia-Pacific region an initial preparatory meeting was convened in Japan in February last year which agreed to a number of principles aimed at harmonising a regional ship inspection program. In November last year the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, with the support of AIDAB, convened a second preparatory meeting in Sydney. Representatives attended from Canada, China, Fiji, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vanuatu and Vietnam.

A third meeting was convened in Vancouver in June of this year. It was agreed at that meeting that early 1994 was an appropriate target for the conclusion of a cooperative regional agreement for this area. The meeting also discussed the establishment of a permanent secretariat. In February this year AMSA established an interim secretariat in Melbourne to facilitate cooperative arrangements following agreement at the second regional meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hey, Shayne, he is answering your question; listen to him.

—I point out to Senator Ian Macdonald that this also has an impact on the Great Barrier Reef. The secretariat provides a focus for regional cooperation, including the promotion of information exchange and examination of training options for regional surveyors and inspectors of ships.

PARA.TAB: AMSA has also taken an active role in drafting the regional agreement and canvassing options for information exchange. It is currently developing a computer link with Canada, which will be the regional coordinating country, for electronic transfer of ship inspection data. It is expected that the system will be available for networking by the end of this year. The signing of the regional agreement will be the catalyst for a comprehensive and harmonised ship inspection regime which will substantially improve the control of substandard and unseaworthy ships within the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Falkinder, Charles William Jackson DSO, DFC

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 11 July 1993, of Charles William Jackson Falkinder, DSO, DFC, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Franklin from 1946 to 1966.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Minchin on this day, relating to the 1993-94 Budget measures concerning taxation on the wine industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to express my great concern about the effect on jobs in the wine industry as a result of the government's decision to lift wine taxes by 55 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Last week I took the opportunity to accompany Senator Troeth on a visit to central Victoria and to speak to some 12 winegrowers in that area. The message which came through to me—I am sure it has come through to the government and hopefully to government backbenchers who hold seats in winegrowing areas—was that this tax will have a very serious effect on jobs in rural Victoria and indeed in winegrowing areas throughout Australia. It will have a very serious effect on investment in the wine industry and no doubt will affect the investment potential in that industry.

The point I would like to make is that the government went to the election with a promise not to raise taxes. Throughout every electorate, particularly throughout every marginal electorate, Labor members of parliament ceaselessly repeated that promise. Nowhere was that clearer than in the seat of McEwen in Victoria, which has extensive winegrowing areas. That was a seat narrowly won by Mr Cleeland by some 300 votes. It was very clear from speaking to the winegrowers in that electorate that they were certainly under the impression, as indeed I am sure all members of the electorate were, that the Labor Party was not going to increase taxes, particularly taxes which savagely affect rural Victoria. The two key taxes that have been raised are the fuel tax and the wine tax.

I bring to the Senate's attention a comment that was made by Senator McMullan some years ago, before he entered this chamber. I think it raises an issue which I urge Labor backbenchers in winegrowing areas to remember. They had a mandate not to lift taxes. Senator McMullan, in speaking to a Fabian conference some years ago—I am glad he is in the chamber—said:

SPEECH.PARA: If I can use an innocent example, because it occurs in a safe Conservative electorate,—
this was some years ago—

if the Labor Party had won the electorate based on the Barossa Valley and we were introducing the wine tax, why would it be the end of the Labor Party if the member for the Barossa Valley crossed the floor, saying I'm going to vote against the wine tax. In the current circumstances it would be carried with a majority of 14 instead of 16. There wouldn't be any doubt—
this is the important point—
that the local Labor Party members would support what that person did and I don't understand why the Party would rock on its foundations.

That is precisely the message which I believe Labor backbenchers in winegrowing areas must deal with because they have a very clear mandate to maintain the promises they made to their particular electorates. Those promises, as I said, were not to raise taxes and now we have the dilemma that these backbenchers are going to be asked to vote for the rises in taxes, particularly the fuel tax and the wine tax.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the Senate that Senator McMullan's piece of advice, given some years ago, is one that those Labor members of parliament should bear in mind. I put it to the Senate that this wine tax can be overturned if two or three Labor backbenchers in winegrowing areas stand up and say that they are not going to have a bar of this broken promise. One of those people is certainly Mr Cleeland in the Victorian seat of McEwen. Another would certainly be Mrs Silvia Smith in the seat of Bass which, as Senator Sherry will be able to tell us, has extensive winegrowing areas and which was won by 42 votes. Another is the marginal seat of Lyons where there are also extensive winegrowing interests.

Mr President, I put it to you and I put it to Senator McMullan that this will affect jobs. This is a classic broken promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The mandate for those Labor backbenchers of parliament is to stand up for their particular electorates. If they do that, this wine tax can be defeated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the answer given in Question Time today by Senator McMullan to a question from Senator Minchin on the impact of the wine tax.

PARA.TAB: I was very disappointed with Senator McMullan's answer because I asked a question of Senator Gareth Evans in this place last week. He waxed lyrical about the exponential growth—to use his words—that was going to happen in the wine industry. He tried to indicate to us that this tax would have no effect at all. Therefore, I was disappointed that Senator McMullan had not become better briefed in the last week. He obviously has not been out in the electorate listening to the winegrowers. He has not been listening to the people in the towns that support the wine industry. Let me assure him that, like Senator Kemp and Senator Troeth, I have been listening to people in the wine industry in the Hunter Valley.

Last week I had the honour of attending the Hunter Valley wine show, where the premium wines from this year's harvest were exhibited. We tasted the premium wines from last year's harvest. Australia has some of the best wines in the world, and this industry is about to be undercut by the measures of this government. The sort of thing that will happen is not exponential growth, as the minister indicated, but a great cut in growth. Projected exports have been revised downwards by the year 2000 from $1 billion to half a billion dollars. What both ministers seem to fail to understand is that to create a successful export industry we need a very strong and profitable domestic industry, and the domestic industry is now 75 per cent of the wine industry.

I also remind both ministers that three-quarters of the winegrowers in Australia are small businesses. Take any small business and increase its tax by 55 per cent, and what will be the effect? There will be a similar sort of effect on jobs as happened in 1986. I remind both ministers what happened in 1986 when the government last increased the wine tax. At that time we lost 1,000 jobs in the grape growing industry; we lost 1,000 jobs in the wineries. This time the initial projection is that we will lose at least 650 jobs in the wine industry, and that is only an initial projection.

I will tell honourable senators what will also happen in New South Wales. Mr Simmons in the lower house, in the seat of Calare, should take note of this. New areas, such as Orange, will not go ahead. To give evidence of that, I will tell honourable senators what will happen in the wineries that exist in the Hunter valley. At that dinner I was at the table of one of the big winegrowers in this country. Its board has just stepped back from a $5 million investment. It did that the day after the budget was brought down. Its investment of $5 million is not going ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you resigning because of that?

—I will tell Senator Burns what the real tragedy of the day was. I was sitting at a table with young winegrowers. They were all university graduates in winemaking in their mid-20s. Senator Burns's government has cut off their careers. They will not get promoted as they would have hoped, and probably great numbers of them will lose their jobs. I encourage Mr Simmons, whose electorate includes Orange; Mr Fitzgibbon, the honourable member for Hunter; and Mr Horne, the honourable member for Paterson, in the adjoining electorate, to stand up for the Hunter Valley, which is losing from this terrible measure that the government has brought in, and I invite them to cross the floor and vote this tax down.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to also take part in this debate about the wine industry, which has arisen from a question asked by Senator Minchin and the answer given by Senator McMullan. I put on the record that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this move at this time. As a senator for South Australia, I am not prepared to put at risk the futures of not only those employed in small boutique wineries but also the thousands of grape growers in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: We will be asking, firstly, that the government bring together the findings of the various inquiries that are under way at the moment and look particularly at the $250,000 that the South Australian government has put into the industry inquiry. In particular, the Democrats want to see this whole issue referred to the regional development task force as a matter of priority to settle, once and for all, the range of questions that have been put before us.

I am sure that many senators will have received information from the brewing industry. Many claims in that respect have to be looked at and carefully considered. I believe that in the next 12 months all these issues can be raised adequately to make sure that we are not putting at risk a very valuable industry. Indeed, it is one of the industries in South Australia that is really showing promise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have here one of the more tawdry examples of exactly what Senator Gareth Evans referred to in his answer to the first question today: an attempt to turn the Australian legislative process into the United States legislative process, whereby people feel comfortable wandering into the legislature and voting down any measure that anybody might oppose. This means that one winds up with all the proposed tax measures being defeated and all expenditure measures being supported and sometimes enhanced.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that there is a budgetary crisis in the United States, which it has endured for many years? Even with the very successful attempt by President Clinton to negotiate through his budget in the way that has to be done in the United States because of the nature of its political system, the best he can hope to achieve is, by 1996-97, a reduction of the budget to 3 per cent of GDP. That is exactly what will occur if the Senate backs away from every difficult decision and goes for every soft option.

The whole equals the sum of the parts in budgets as it does elsewhere. If those opposite do not wish to face up to the difficult decisions, the only encouragement I would take from that is that it is a very good opposition strategy and it will keep them in opposition for a very long time.

I want to say something about the wine tax and something about that excellent speech of mine to which Senator Kemp referred. The best assessment of the impact of this wine tax is this: a $10 bottle of wine will increase by about 50c and the price of a $7 four-litre cask will accordingly increase by probably 50c. One will increase by just over 50c and one will increase by just under 50c; they will both increase by about 50c.

It is extraordinary to assume that a discretionary purchase such as wine will have such elasticity of demand that the impact of this tax will have the sorts of industry effects that people are claiming. I say to Senator Kemp that, although he took that quote of mine out of context, that speech of mine was an outstanding one. I recommend to him very strongly the principles which it outlines. I am pleased to see that he is at least seeking his edification from more worthwhile sources. I encourage him to continue to peruse them. If he wishes to have copies of other collective speeches, I am very happy to send them to him.
Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop should restrain her enthusiasm. I will be very happy to refer those speeches to Senator Kemp whenever he chooses. The circumstance is simply this—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp quite correctly read it, saw its inherent merit, but unfortunately failed to understand the point that was being made by that contribution. I am yet to persuade my colleagues in the Labor Party of the merits of that proposition. Therefore, the rules about which I was speaking have not been changed even though my view was, and remains, that they should have been. It has been my view for a very long time—
—You would like to be decent if only they would let you; is that what you are saying?

—When Senator Vanstone thinks she is seeing a horrible impression, she really should realise that she is looking in the mirror and not through a window—she should just relax. The situation is that we have a very minor tax measure that will have a very minor impact on consumption. Nobody at the premium end of the market pretends that this level of tax is going to have any impact on consumption whatsoever. Everybody knows that wine exports will not be affected by this change. (Time expired)

—This tax is typical of the budget strategy as a whole—tax and spend. Taxes are raised in order that spending can be kept up without any attempt at reining in expenditure and having that expenditure in reasonable limits. For instance, we will raise out of this tax on wine $100 million. We will spend $170 million to build Gareth's gazebo; a nice new building for him and his apparatchiks to sit in.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that the wine industry has become an export industry. It is providing jobs and it is providing export earnings which we sorely need because of the profligate policies this government has run for 10 years that have racked up an international debt in excess of $200 billion.

The points that Senator McMullan was trying to make from the United States experience would be better couched in terms of the facts. We are indebted to Mr Brian Croser, the President of the Winemakers Federation of Australia—who was mentioned by Senator Kemp—because he points out that in California wine is taxed at the rate of 50c a litre, whereas Australian wine will now be taxed at the rate of $1.47 a litre.

When we talk about having a competitive advantage, having the ability to compete against a foreign competitor, having micro-economic reforms in place and removing the impediments that make it possible for us to export, the result of this tax simply makes it more and more difficult for Australians to gain access to those foreign markets. There is also a lot of empirical evidence which has shown that in Australia when wine merchants are going around attempting to have orders placed for their product, people are simply saying, `No, we will not buy at this stage.'

Now the important input of Senator Minchin's question was: what research had the government done to ascertain what the impact of this tax would be on the loss of jobs. In the first attempted answer Senator McMullan simply ducked and wove—refused to answer; just ignored it. In the supplementary question when Senator Minchin again pushed the point, what did we get, `I'm not going to tell you what research or advice we got.' In other words, how dare Senator Minchin ask the government, as the executive, to account to the parliament for the research that it did to bring out the budget that it did.

In light of the fact that Mr Dawkins said the object of this budget was supposed to be jobs, I can only conclude from Senator McMullan's answer that he cares precious little about ordinary Australians whose jobs are placed in jeopardy. He believes that they are merely a statistic of revenue he has to raise in order to spend in accordance with the policies that it believes are more important than ordinary Australians. One million unemployed Australians to me is not just a statistic; it is one million Australians who are hurting.

The import of this question today was that the government by its callousness, its disregard, or simply by planning, is going to put out of jobs an additional 650 Australians, and kill off the opportunity of other young Australians to get a start in an industry which has growth potential and strength in terms of an export market. Where is the justice and the equity in a tax system that takes no heed of how it impacts on ordinary Australians? I will tell honourable senators the answer: there is none. This government is about collectives but not individuals. Individuals can always be sacrificed to the collective. Six hundred and fifty Australian jobs can be sacrificed so that whatever the number of people can be comfortably ensconced in Gareth's gazebo.

Make the trade-offs. Make the decision. Let the Australian people make the decision. Does this government evidence at any point that it cares about the Australian people? No, it does not. This tax—and the government's failure to show the research it had done on the impact it would have on the Australian people—is just typical of this government and indicative of the fact that it cares not at all. It is downright un-Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Sherry.
—Is sherry being taxed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, as I understand it, the name `sherry' is being abolished at the end of the year. Following an unfortunate agreement between this country and European producers of alcoholic beverages some names of wine—port, champagne and sherry—are disappearing from the shelves.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the issue of wine. In my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and as chair of the horticultural task force, I have been in contact with winegrowers on this issue both before and after the budget. I want to respond to a number of points made in the contributions of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they have supported this, have they?

—No, of course they did not support it. I wish to take up some of the fallacious points that have been made by members of the opposition. Senator Bishop's contribution was interesting in the macro-economic sense in that she alleged that this was a tax and spend budget. I will be dealing with that theme in the urgency debate later on. One point I will be making is that this budget is not a spend budget. Not one cent of the tax increases in this budget will go towards increases in expenditure. The funds from tax increases are being devoted towards reducing the budget deficit over the next four years.

PARA.TAB: We need to note firstly that the wine tax increase is an increase on the wholesale price of wine. It is not an excise increase as in the case of beer and other alcoholic beverages. Therefore the tax situation in the wine industry is still significantly different from that applying to beer and other forms of alcohol. It is not an excise tax. Those opposite refer to a 55 per cent increase in tax; that is not the effect on the retail price. It is not a 55 per cent increase in the retail price as they attempt to make out. It is a 55 per cent increase on the wholesale side. That does not equate to a 55 per cent increase in the retail price.

Senator McMullan has pointed out that the price of a $10 bottle of wine will increase by between $1 and $1.50 at the retail level. The price of a $20 bottle of wine will increase by between $2 and $2.50 at the retail level. I put to those opposite that, when they are dining out in a restaurant and they are paying their $100 or whatever they pay for a couple of people, an extra $1.50 or $2 is not such a significant proportion of the total cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very deceitful comment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Honourable senators on my left will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to those opposite that an extra $1.50 or $2 on the retail price of dining out is frankly not that significant in the context of dining out. In terms of the effect on grape growers, I predict that there will not be a reduction in grape growing in Australia. There may be a change in wine production domestically, but there will not be a decrease in grape production.
—Oh yes there will!
—Both are different.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, I have asked you twice to cease interjecting. You will cease interjecting now.

—If those opposite knew anything about the wine industry, they would know that there is a significant difference between wine production and grape growing. Even if the industry does not meet the $1 billion target—let us assume it meets only the $500 million target that the industry has now said it is down scaling to—that is still an increase in exports. At the moment the industry exports about $380 million worth of wine. If the figure goes up to $500 million, as the industry predicts, there will not be a reduction in grape growing for wine; there cannot be, because even to meet that modest revision that the industry has put on the export of wine, there will need to be an expansion in grape growing.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I accept and follow your instruction that I should not interject, but I ask you to take to the Procedure Committee the notion that, if we can develop some sort of standing order that will require people who come in here to have some understanding of what they are saying—such that we are not motivated to interject ad infinitum—this place might run a bit more efficiently. I have never heard so much drivel in my life.
—That is not a point of order, and Senator Vanstone knows it. If she wants to put something to the Procedure Committee, she should write a letter to the President.

—We often get spurious points of order from those opposite because they do not like the debating points that are made. Not once have I called a spurious point of order to try to interrupt a debate. But if those opposite want to adopt those tactics, so be it—they do not like the truth.

PARA.TAB: I raise another issue about job restructuring in the wine industry. Wine is a manufacturing process as well as an agricultural process. Over the past decade there has been a continuing restructuring in the wine manufacturing process because of the new technologies in the industry. That will continue regardless of whether domestic sales are reduced or exports occur. (Time expired)
