Sales tax for local councils will also have a big impact on country councils. They will be faced with the choice of cutting services or increasing rates. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this budget establishes an economic framework over four years—
Senator Sherry remarked on that—

a framework for continuing low interest rates and continuing low inflation, which, combined with reduced company tax and generous investment incentives, will support increased business investment for future growth in production and employment.

I cannot see it happening either now or further down the track because this budget has knocked the guts out of everyone in the country areas. Yet having said that, the increase in fuel will be inflationary and the fuel increase could raise the CPI by as much as 1.7 per cent. The Treasurer went on to say:
Other commitments include action to enrich the culture of our country, protect its environment, and support those living outside the major cities.

I would say something, if I could in this place, that is attached to the cowyard and is on the ground most of the time. But instead of assistance, there are positive disincentives, fuel being just one. On wine, the Treasurer said:

Wine is currently more lightly taxed than beer and spirits. From tonight, tax on wine will apply at the 31 per cent rate. But the government is committed to retaining the exclusion of wine from excise.

So we did not have an increase in excise, but excise is just another name for tax. We had a massive rise in the wholesale sales tax on an industry that has really started to perform in recent years. We have already heard today about the massive loss of jobs likely to result in the wine industry. We have also heard the cynical response by Senator McMullan, as I am sure every winegrower heard today in question time. It is estimated at least 650 jobs will be lost.

PARA.TAB: Wine exports to the UK now account for some five per cent of wine consumption in that country. It is becoming a vital export for this country but, like all exports, it is being taxed out of existence. The increase will add in direct costs to the Australian wine industry about $100 million; in domestic sales about $445 million in potential vineyard and winery investments; and $126 million in potential export growth. That is not helping that industry much either.

Another promise from the government has been broken. While the government claims that it will protect export industries, it taxes them to damnation and extinction. Indeed, sales tax and customs and excise will bring in the staggering figure of $22,260 million this financial year.

This is not a budget that will get Australia back on its feet. A litany of promises, some implied, have been given to rural Australia with nothing delivered. The budget is a pea and thimble trick from one end to another. The original Artful Dodger would be proud that his modern day namesake is carrying on the family tradition so well.

The federal government has claimed that it has increased spending on the rural adjustment scheme when it has passed the buck to the state governments—$104 million coming from the states and only $53 million from the Commonwealth. Mr Dawkins tells us in his papers that spending on the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service will be reduced by $20 million over the next four years.

We have been told that streamlining and efficiencies have brought about this reduction to the service for which farmers have to pay. Yet when one examines the budget papers, one sees that spending last year was $171 million and by 1996-97 spending will be $166 million. This is $5 million over four years, not the $20 million promised. In order to get the $20 million, the government threw in a few one-offs for this year to inflate the figure—another deception and another fraud on the Australian people. As I said, the Quarantine Inspection Service is a very contentious issue for rural Australia.

We have a budget that has been brought to the parliament which we will be looking at very closely and voting on in the next week or so. It is full of broken promises to the Australian people. As senators in this place, it is up to us to make sure that the community knows about the broken promises and the deceit that has been perpetrated on the Australian community. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion of Senator Short's is fundamentally wrong, and it ought to be rejected on a number of grounds. First, it is factually incorrect. This budget has not caused irreparable damage to all Australians, as stated in the motion. Secondly, this government has not affected the integrity of the democratic parliamentary processes. To the contrary, it is the opposition that has undermined the integrity of the democratic parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, this budget is characterised by the extremely high number of promises actually fulfilled. Fourthly, the motivations that have generated this motion ought to be brought to the attention of this parliament. They are borne of the frustration and the anxiety within the Liberal Party that have arisen as a result of its political defeat. In fact, this was highlighted in the Australian this morning in the article headed `With no policies on board, Liberals have lost the way'.

Senator Short has described this budget as a `budget of betrayal'. Nothing could be further from the truth. The betrayal lies with the conservative parties which went into the last election on a policy of ruthless destruction of working people's living standards. Those parties were rejected for it. We have heard talk of a new Liberal Party which is based on the politics of inclusion, yet we still hear, ringing in our ears, comments from those opposite about renters, social security recipients as bludgers, workers who are destroying this country, unions who have no legitimate place in our economy and conservationists. This is the real Liberal Party. This is the approach towards public policy that the Liberal Party takes in this country.

We have heard yet again from the National Party today, and its old policies aimed at privatisation of profits and socialisation of losses still shine through. That is the guts of the National Party policy today. The conservative parties have betrayed the confidence of the electorate in their failure to respond to the needs and aspirations of Australians. It is a recognition that Malcolm Fraser himself made as recently as last Saturday.

The opposition parties in the Senate have betrayed the democratic processes by their failure to be an effective opposition. Malcolm Fraser himself, as I said, acknowledged just how marginalised the opposition has become within the Australian community. Laura Tingle quoted Malcolm Fraser in this morning's Australian, when she wrote:
The policies followed by those running the party have, he said, "little relationship to the basic Liberal traditions which gave this party—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, his party—
its strength, its independence and its courage".

PARA.TAB: "By the last election we had grown apart from our traditional supporters and the middle ground of Australia.
The Party had become "a right-wing conservative party" where "one particular point of view" has "destroyed the voice of the branches and our membership".

SPEECH.PARA: Laura Tingle also pointed out:

PARA.TAB: It was hard to escape . . . the view that while the political brain of the Liberal Party is now working more sharply than it has in years, the body and soul it is supposed to sustain may well be dead from the neck down.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue is that this motion is factually incorrect. Many Australians have benefited directly from the billions of dollars of government expenditure. The budget with its $16 billion deficit will provide a stimulus to the economy, while at the same time, in the longer term, the government is addressing the question of debt. As Australia works towards being a more effective player on the international markets, the Labor government is moving towards its objective of full employment.

PARA.TAB: By international comparisons Australia's deficit is small. Canada's deficit, for instance, is larger than Australia's, as is Germany's. In fact, the case might be adequately made for an expansion of the Australian deficit, not its further contraction as is argued by the Liberal Party. Therein lies the absolute hypocrisy of the motion before us.

The Liberal Party's policy is to cut government spending, as we have heard from Senator Bishop this afternoon on the question of wine. Its approach is to cut $10 billion out of the budget. As Senator Sherry pointed out, we have not heard exactly how it plans to do that. The budget delivers real gains to many millions of Australians—in education, health, transport, social security, arts, culture and child care. The list is quite extensive. At the same time the government is developing an economic strategy to strengthen our fundamental economic foundations—greater trade with Asia, improved export performances, lower inflation, long term interest rates, which are now at a 20-year low, and productivity growth.

The government is also providing for increased social reform and equity with improved social security benefits for families and children; the seniors card for low income pensioners; improvements in newstart allowances; Commonwealth dental programs for low income earners; and improvement in women's health programs. Over the past 12 months the government has doubled the level of funding for labour market programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 187, a senator shall not read his speech. I have been watching Senator Carr since he started about five minutes ago and he has not lifted his eyes. If he knows the subject as well as he is making out, he might care to stop reading it.
—I have been watching Senator Carr closely. He is certainly using notes and I ask him to continue.

—As have other senators used notes here this afternoon, I might note. There have been improved training opportunities for the long term unemployed—630,000 people will benefit from labour market programs in 1993-94.

PARA.TAB: The motion before us refers to the integrity of our democratic processes. I am very surprised that the opposition has the nerve to raise this point, given its behaviour in this chamber. Over three weeks ago, on 19 August, we saw rammed through this chamber proposals to restrict the level of parliamentary debate by making it mandatory that legislation would only be considered where it met with strict time lines—that is, bills have to be introduced before the cut-off date of 1 October. We have some 84 bills in 50 packages which these restrictive procedures have effectively undermined.

We hear lots about whether people should participate in full parliamentary debate, but the whole proposition that was put before this Senate was to restrict the capacity of the House of Representatives to debate legislation. The whole idea was to frustrate the work of government. As we heard from Dr Hewson just last weekend, the whole strategy of the Liberal Party in this place is to refer as much business as it can to various committees in order to tie up this chamber, to filibuster, to prevent legislation passing. So when we talk about integrity and the work of government, we can see who is at fault in that regard. This is a very good government, but the opposition intends to make it a very bad government and to undermine the whole process of government in this country.

The basic function of the Senate, in the opposition's view, is to turn it from a house of review to an opposition grandstanding chamber. Not content to restrict the house of the people to try to limit its rightful job of managing government business, the opposition has on a daily basis taken up the time of the Senate with a string of inane motions, such as the one we have before us today.

The real point behind this is the fact that the Liberal Party, having faced five election defeats in a row, is under enormous strain. Paralysed by internal conflict and leadership speculation, constantly challenged by the few moderates who still remain within its ranks—that is, those who have not been purged—and devoid of any coherent policy since the election, the opposition has had to face complete rejection by the Australian people. To hide that basic fact the Liberal Party seeks to tie up the business of this chamber with meaningless motions such as that now before us.

The government, on the other hand, has a clear agenda for building a new society looking towards the 1990s and beyond. The Australian Labor Party is leading the community debate on the sort of society we need, the sort of society we are trying to create as we face a new century. All institutions are under review in that process. We are examining critically all sorts of social relationships. No clearer point could be made than in the examination of our national identity. The budget's programs go to that very point.

There is an extensive commitment to preserve Aboriginal culture and heritage, improved access for all Australians to cultural heritage through the expansion of and support for museums and other cultural institutions, and the establishment of the foundation for Australia's cultural development based in Melbourne, which will work with local government, community organisations, museums and other cultural bodies in the lead-up to the centenary. All of these are examples that come out of the budget which highlight the direction we are taking, which contrasts sharply with the inane propositions we have heard from the opposition today.

We are also seeking to ensure that Australians outside the capital cities have access to art and culture, which the National Party does not seem to talk about too much. Art and culture do not really apply to the National Party; it is the sort of concept National Party members find beneath them to discuss. We are establishing national tourism programs. We are attempting to assist young artists. Over $2 million has been allocated to establish a festival of youth arts. All these are important issues. The Senate ought to recognise that there have been substantial benefits for a whole range of people in the areas of children's television, assistance to the government primary schools and the upgrading of the Commonwealth Employment Service.

The sum of $1.1 billion growth funding has been provided in this budget to TAFE over the next four years. Currently 250,000 Victorians enjoy TAFE programs in Victoria. We do not hear anything about the positives of those programs from the opposition. The sum of $1.3 billion has been expended for labour market programs this year, which is an increase of $136 million. There have been further improvements in newstart and jobstart, improved consumer protection for renters, improved child-care facilities, with cash rebates of up to $28 a week for one child and $61 for two children. There is additional assistance for the introduction of child-care initiatives for sick children, the new dental health program, and measures to crack down on overservicing by doctors—medifraud.

The real reason for this motion is that the forces that Senator Short represents in Victoria were defeated on the weekend, and this is a device to try to get over that fact. The opposition is looking for an opportunity to draw attention to, as it sees it, the government's failures and to hide its own. This follows numerous defeats in recent times as the opposition comes to the grips with the fact that it lost the last election and, the way it is going, it is going to lose the next.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order.
—The biggest losers from this weekend—
—Order!

—Obviously the new senator does not understand the courtesies of this chamber or he would sit down when a point of order is called. Once again I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Carr has been reading his speech from beginning to end, despite the fact that your attention was drawn to that matter earlier. It is against the standing orders and I would ask you to call on him to desist and to read his standing orders.
—Senator Carr is obviously using copious notes. I would ask Senator Carr to continue.

—I have referred to a number of items that the opposition really does not like. I have got to the heart of the matter. The real issue for the opposition is not the standing orders—it is the content of what I am saying. Even little Johnny Howard understood—
—Order! `Mr Howard', thank you.
—Little Mr Howard. On the weekend he pointed out that the reason the Liberals lost the last election was that they were essentially outclassed politically.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, on the matter of relevance. I believe that what Mr Howard had to say about why the coalition lost the election is not part of the urgency motion. If Senator Carr does not understand the urgency motion, I will read it again.
—No, you do not have to read it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to rule that he be relevant.
—In a motion like this, it is quite in order for an honourable senator to develop arguments. The arguments in this case are within bounds.

—The real losers at the weekend, as was pointed out in the Australian this morning, were the powerbrokers in the Victorian division of the Liberal Party, who have sponsored this motion here today. They did not get their candidate for the president, they failed to enhance the power of the federal executive, and they failed to strengthen the party's position on the question of the republic. Well may those opposite squeal about why they lost the last election. The fact is—and this is what this motion is really all about—that they did lose the last election. They lost the last election because their policies were wrong and their ideology was wrong. As I said before, and as Mr John Howard pointed out, the real reason that they lost was that they were outclassed politically. As long as they keep putting up motions like this, that will continue to be their fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case honourable senators and those listening to this debate are in any doubt after having heard Senator Carr's masterpiece of irrelevance, the issue we are debating today is the irreparable damage caused to all Australians and to the integrity of our democratic parliamentary process by the Keating Government's deceitful litany of broken promises and its 1993 budget of betrayal. It is nothing to do with the fact that the opposition lost the last election. It has everything to do with the manner in which the government won the election and the manner in which it has continued to govern since the election.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Carr seems to be so involved with the Labor Party, perhaps sometimes he might look outside the Labor Party and see that this nation is hurting—hurting desperately—after 10 years of Labor misrule. At least Senator Sherry earlier in this debate had the good grace to acknowledge that it was important for the government to listen. Senator Carr is obviously from that part of the party that believes arrogantly that it knows all, and that nobody needs to listen to the people of Australia who put them in and who feel grossly deceived, grossly cheated. No matter how Senator Carr may rabbit on, rushing to read his speech from beginning to end, despite the standing orders of this chamber, no matter what Senator Carr might like to portray, the people of Australia feel cheated and hurt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Order!
—Obviously, the minister wants to take some of my time when I am being strictly relevant to the debate.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Is it in order for Senator Newman to accuse Senator Carr of having read his speech while she is reading hers?
—There is no point of order.

—I have not even got copious notes but I know what is happening to the people of Australia. My head and my heart and my ears tell me what is happening to this nation. If we are going to have any more senators like Senator Carr come here, perhaps they should do an education exercise before they arrive here as to how to listen to the Australian people they are meant to represent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry, when he was debating, talked about the integrity behind this budget, which at least is part of the motion. There is no integrity behind this budget. I was appreciative of the fact that Senator Kernot in her speech referred to the lack of integrity, the lack of cohesiveness, the lack of any direction, in the budget. That is something which the opposition has been pointing out ever since the budget was brought down. Senator Sherry did, however, purport to claim that the Liberals are in Disneyland in talking about carving dollars out of the budget. I would suggest that perhaps the boot is on the other foot. If there is anybody in Disneyland, it is the Labor Party, especially when evidenced by a diatribe like we have just received from Senator Carr.

Senator Sherry also said that to say no negotiations, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) did, was not a silly thing to do. I think perhaps Senator Kernot has also dealt with that and I will not waste my time on it. We are not in the habit of putting out ambit claims for budgets in this country. We expect the government of the day, knowing the financial problems and situation of the nation, to put down a budget which is fair to the country, fair to the people of the country and which recognises the financial responsibilities that it has. If members of the government are listening to this community, as Senator Sherry was prepared to say they were, they must now be deafened because the people of Australia are speaking, and speaking non-stop; they are anguished about the budget which has been brought down.

Only today we have seen just what has happened as a result of the government's mismanagement, flowing through as it did into the foreign debt. An interesting thing in today's figures that I thought was particularly notable was the growth in the foreign debt that was caused by the public sector. The public sector net foreign debt has grown to $63.4 billion—an increase of $7.5 billion. That means that the public sector has been responsible for over 60 per cent of the increase in foreign debt in the last quarter. If that does not damn this government for its financial mismanagement, what will? What we are seeing with those figures is the burden that is being laid on our children and grandchildren. Never was such a stark example seen.

The budget is a disaster for all Australians, but my concern is particularly for those on low and middle incomes. They are the ones who really will suffer from the realities of this budget. As we know, the battling families have been hit with a raft of nasties, some of which my colleagues have already spoken about, yet apparently they have been bribed—if the government thinks they are foolish enough to be bribed by it again; I think it is sadly mistaken. The bribe is a magnanimous not quite $2 a week by way of compensation. Get this: that bribe does not get paid until the end of the financial year—after those families have been paying for all these tax increases for the whole of the financial year. Some compensation!

I remind the Senate that in the Fightback package where there were going to be effects on family budgets we bent over backwards to make sure that compensation was not only payable but supergenerous so that those families in particular would have been protected from tax reforms.

I think that we would all have to agree that the most appalling part of the budget is the bit that we do not hear so much about because it is not related to tax. It is the fact that there is no recipe for doing anything meaningful to change the unemployment status in this country. Every thinking person in this nation must weep tears of blood thinking of those people who stay on those unemployment queues for month after month after month. We all have family members now who have gone through the indignity of applying for the dole when they thought that never in their lifetime would they be dependent upon the welfare state, yet they have to accept that assistance because there is no hope of work.

Let us now talk about the taxes. Even after the backdown measures of the government on leaded petrol, it will still increase by 7c a litre by February 1995. With the across-the-board increases in sales tax, families will pay more every time they venture into supermarkets and department stores. Let me mention again that there is no compensation for it—no real compensation at all—like there was in Fightback.

Think of the heavy smokers in low income families. In my experience, people who come to political offices for assistance who are disadvantaged are frequently very heavy smokers. Who would blame them? They need some comfort. But now this government has chosen to particularly target them. They will be slugged by more than $10 a week.

Families will also suffer more in getting pharmaceuticals. They will no longer receive drugs free after hitting the safety net and it will take longer to reach the net. That access to free drugs was particularly important to low income earners. I notice that the government's prediction for inflation is that it will be something like 3.5 per cent. Some people might dismiss that with a wave of the hand and not think too much about it. Once again, it is the low income earners who are particularly disadvantaged by inflation. We have heard some quotes here today. Let me quote. On the day after the budget, Martin Ferguson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I wouldn't want to be a worker who drives a leaded vehicle or smokes or drinks because, frankly, they wouldn't be sitting at home in front of the television thinking about voting for John Dawkins in a double dissolution.

What about Michael Easson? He described the budget as an act of bastardry. Of course, he was referring to the retrospective ripping-off of tax from people's long service leave. What does his wife, the MP, Mrs Easson, have to say about that? We know what Merle Mitchell, the president of ACOSS, has said about the budget. She said:
I am extremely disappointed with (the) tax changes, a lack of action to bring down unemployment and a failure to implement recommendations on national savings.

Let me tell the Senate what some of the Labor politicians in my home state of Tasmania have said about the government's budget. The honourable member for Bass, Mrs Smith, recently supported a call by the Tasmanian pensioners union for the price increase in leaded petrol to be scrapped, saying that the people of northern Tasmania already had high cost petrol. The honourable member for Franklin, Harry Quick, said:

Tasmanians already pay higher petrol prices relative to the rest of Australia, and a tax on leaded petrol would mean Tasmanians would be relatively more disadvantaged by being required to assist in paying for a problem in the larger States.

Even our new ALP senator, Kay Denman, sworn in today, has expressed publicly her concern about the Medicare changes and the paltry $2 a week tax rebate. She has vowed to fight the petrol tax increases. Let them show their disgust. Let them cross the floor when these measures come to this parliament. Then we will take some notice of what they have to say.

PARA.TAB: Do not forget that it is not just the taxes that this government has been deceiving the public about; there are the changes to Austudy and the changes to HECS—once again, particularly a problem to low income earners with several children. But at no stage during the election campaign did this government, trying to cadge for votes, tell those families that it would be making those changes.

We have 16-year-old secondary school students being moved from Austudy to the basic family payment. The rate at which the HECS will be clawed back is to be increased and the threshold is to be lowered to average weekly earnings. Ken Fowlie, the national president of the National Union of Students, summed up this attack by saying that the government had slugged the students to help it overcome its financial problems. There is somebody who has worked out that two and two make four.

This home child-care allowance is another deceitful measure that the government promised during the election campaign and is now messing about with Australian families on. That will not be brought down for another 12 months. That means that the carers in the home, mostly women, will have been waiting more than a year and a half since the promise was first made. Anyway, it is a pea in a thimble trick because it is cashing out the dependent spouse rebate, and the net gain to a family in a week will be $2.80. It hardly indicates a real commitment to mothers in the home.

Do not forget the optometry benefits. The changes there will mean that there will be a $50 for a first consultation fee and $25 for a follow-up consultation for average families. At the moment they pay nothing because 90 per cent of the optometrists bulkbill. This is effectively a tax on spectacle wearers of about $50 a year. It is in clear breach of the government's election platform. The Optometrists Association pointed out in its press release that was made available to members and senators that the government was talking before the election about its platform which included optometrists' services and it said, `all Australians are entitled to exactly the same quality of care'.

The government was talking about Medicare. Yet here we see the first step in dismantling Medicare. During the election campaign the government spent its time trying to portray the opposition as wreckers of Medicare when in fact our concern was that Medicare needed support and improvement. Because this government is not prepared to take the measures necessary to support Medicare by encouraging private health insurance, it is having to further ration health resources. We have rationing of pharmaceuticals. We now have rationing of opticals. We have rationing of physiotherapy. We have rationing of hospital beds. That is because this government is not governing properly for all Australians. The health budget fails to tackle in any substantive way the real problems in the health portfolio.

There are claims that the government is going to reduce medical fraud and overservicing. That is quite unbelievable because its previous activity does not indicate any commitment to reducing any fraud or overservicing that is present. The funding in the budget to reduce hospital queues is inadequate and it is an effort of sleight of hand. At first sight we would think that the government was introducing the first stage of its election promise of $100 million over four years to reduce queues, but if we look at it more closely we see that it is just not true. Last year there was an existing program and the government committed $48 million to the states and territories to reduce waiting times. This financial year that program will get only $12.4 million. But the government is introducing a new program this year to which it has allocated an additional $12.4 million.

What we have after that sleight of hand is a reduction of about $36 million in the old program and an amount of $12.4 million in the new program. That means that the moneys available for getting extra hospital beds out of the private sector appears to be about $23.6 million less than last year. So much for that election promise. It was not a very good promise anyway because it would have reduced the number of people privately insured. We have seen the rationing, we know what the government is up to, and it is simply not up to managing the health care of Australians.

Senator Richardson, in announcing his expansion for palliative care services, has pointed out that there is a need for people to die with dignity, but Australian families want to live in dignity rather than with the continuous struggle they have now to keep their heads above water. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief observations this evening on the matter of urgency that is before the chamber. The circumstances that confront the government though are unusual in that two elements seem to be present in virtually everything coalition speakers say in the course of the debate. I am stunned to see that Fightback is still being argued after 13 March. This is truly remarkable given the resounding defeat inflicted on the Liberal and National parties by the Australian people that day.
—Fightback was honest, which is more than we can say for you.

—Senator Newman continues to argue Fightback. Judgment has been passed on it. It is like the outcome of the Liberal Party federal council at the weekend. The council looked back in anger on Australian history. The Liberal Party seems incapable of looking to the future, of looking to the next century of our constitutional development, to the next century of our political framework.

PARA.TAB: What will happen as a consequence of the determination made at the Liberal Party's federal council at the weekend is just as has occurred on every occasion this century. When the nation takes a step forward, the conservative parties will be found, at best, in the baggage train.

The problem the coalition faces is reflected in the urgency motion. It cannot accept the result of the general election of 13 March. Four defeats in a row were a lot to absorb—there is no question about that; the Labor Party has been there and understands that—but a fifth consecutive defeat was more than anyone in the coalition could comprehend or was prepared to concede. So that is why we have a circumstance in which the coalition in the Senate seeks only to delay, obstruct or frustrate the measures of the elected government, just as occurred previously in our history.

Since the election has been raised in the course of the debate, I recall the night of 13 March vividly—the tally room, the looks on people's faces. Senator Newman raises the state of Tasmania. Of course, it was the state of Tasmania that started the landslide against the coalition, an absolute and utter landslide. Why did that happen? It happened primarily because people could see first-hand, through the actions of the Groom government on industrial relations, what was likely to be superimposed on that system by the prescriptions of Fightback.

It is not only a matter of the GST, and Senator Newman deludes herself if she thinks the electorate merely rejected that tax. True, it has had a savage impact where it has been introduced elsewhere in the world, as the conservative government in Canada will find out in a couple of months. But the coalition deludes itself in thinking the election loss was merely because of the GST. It has to look at the whole value system that was bound up in the Fightback package.

An American friend of mine said to me over dinner late last year—he was on his way back to the United States after having spent a sabbatical in Australia looking at federalism—`Why on earth is the coalition in this country running on a platform that Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan ran on in 1979 and 1980 respectively?'. The best answer I could give was that the coalition really believed that the decade of the 1980s was theirs but that it had been snatched from them by the Labor Party. Labor had gone on in national government to introduce landmark reforms right across the board in terms of internationalising the Australian economy and modernising our economic framework. While Thatcher and Reagan had been in power in the UK and the United States respectively, the coalition felt cheated.

So once again, coming up in the baggage train of history, appears Fightback. Fightback I, as Senator Bolkus remembers only too vividly, was too harsh even for those beating the drum inside the Liberal and National Party joint party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took them a long time to find out.

—Indeed, several months. They amended it in the end to Fightback II, despite the promise of Dr Hewson that he would no longer be the leader of the opposition if Fightback I was amended. Fightback I was amended and Fightback II was rejected by the Australian people. Are we now debating Fightback III? Did Senator Newman introduce Fightback III, which is Fightback II minus the GST?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Would you be so good as to read to Senator Loosley the motion he is meant to be debating? He clearly does not know what he is meant to be debating. He has just raised a question about it. He is not debating the previous election; he is debating the government's budget and dishonesty.
—Order! It is in order for a senator to develop an argument, and I am sure Senator Loosley is doing that.

—The circumstances that confront us are that the coalition refuses to accept the result of 13 March. That is absolute political bedrock, not only here this afternoon where we have yet another nonsensical urgency motion, but generally.
—Why should we?

—Because the Australian people registered their votes in the ballot box—that is why those opposite should accept the result of the general election. It happens to be written into the electoral act. Circumstances being what they are, we will see increasingly in the weeks and months ahead an absolute determination to repeat the events of 1974 and 1975.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted that those opposite raise the argument, `Why on earth should we accept the results of the general election?' The coalition finds it difficult at any time and it finds it particularly difficult this time. If those opposite could have their way, they would repeat the process of 1974 and 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—Thank you. That is precisely what we need to have established on the public record. What does this mean in terms of the manner in which the vandalism is done to our constitutional and democratic parliamentary processes which are at the absolute and utter core of the proposition we are debating this afternoon? What the cabal of senators behind Senator Newman are about doing is repeating the process of 1974 and 1975. The argument leads inexorably and unremittingly to that.

PARA.TAB: The events of 1974 and 1975 were not pleasant experiences for anyone. They were not pleasant experiences for the Australian people, who were forced to an election for a Labor government again in 1974 and forced, about 18 months later, to yet another ballot in December of 1975. They were forced to the polls when the government should simply have been allowed to run its full term, its three-year cycle. I have always believed that if the government had gone its full cycle there probably would have been a change at the end of 1975. If it had gone a full cycle from May 1974 to May 1977, there probably would have been a change.

That is not good enough for those opposite. They would like to use their raw numbers in the Senate to usurp the role of the House of Representatives and to force the government to the polls. That is precisely what Senator McGauran said earlier. He said, `Absolutely' when I asked a rhetorical question. If people are silly enough to respond to rhetorical questions and get themselves on the public record, they can wear it. That is the kind of vandalism of the democratic parliamentary processes that all of us ought to reject.

There was something else said here a week or so ago. Senator Hill rose to speak. From the conservative back benches someone made the remark to the President, who was in the chair at the time, that `The majority leader must be heard'. That is a term alien to Australian politics; it has no place in our system. That is a reference to the United States Senate, which unquestionably has greater constitutional authority than this Senate. It is reflective and indicative of thinking opposite—that this place has greater powers than the House of Representatives in our constitutional framework, as the opposition maintained during 1974 and 1975. That is why we

SPEECH.PARA: see these arbitrary limitations placed upon a government's capacity to legislate; that is why, in matter of days or weeks, a government is expected to have all its budget legislation drafted, debated and in place to come to the Senate chamber. That is an absolute nonsense. Again, that is the vandalism of our democratic parliamentary processes which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Beazley have referred to over past weeks.

PARA.TAB: There are a lot of things that can be said in support of this current budget—the four-year framework, the development of labour market programs and the deficit reduction strategy. A whole range of issues can be canvassed in a light very positive to the Labor government. I am more than pleased to do that. From the perspective of Australian history, it is very important to get those opposite on the record tonight as to what their real agenda is. There is no effective budget reply, no matter whether we read Senator Bishop's speech or Dr Hewson's speech. We can take either of them; there is no effective budget reply.

All those opposite are doing is delaying, obstructing and frustrating. They would love to gut the budget to defeat the deficit reduction strategy. Attempts will be made to do that in this chamber; I do not believe they will be successful. There is a little too much common sense amongst the Democrats and others for that to happen. There is certainly enough intelligence within the framework of the government to make certain that that does not happen. But that is what will occur. There is no question about that.

In terms of what the budget sets out to do, I want to make a couple of points about health and one or two other policy areas because it is important that they be re-enforced. For example, the federal government, through the office of Senator Richardson, the new health minister, is about cracking down on fraud and cheating in health. We are not doing this in an arbitrary way; it is not to be done by the 5 a.m. doorknock. It is being done in cooperation with the Australian Medical Association and the Health Insurance Commission. It is about a crackdown on fraud. This is something which is neglected and ignored opposite—stay with the fantasies of Fightback III, minus the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —I told you that. Get the wax out of your ears.

—I can tell Senator Newman that we would be delighted to fight another general election on Fightback. Does she seriously propose to do that—Fightback III? We would be delighted. I well recall, as we look at the faces opposite, the confident and arrogant nature of people as we approached the general election of 1993 in those final weeks of 1992. There would soon be a change of government and people would be shifting from over there to over here. It did not happen. I invite people in leadership positions in the Senate to come back to the Australian electorate with Fightback mark III. They will not do it; I absolutely guarantee it. We were re-elected on 13 March for a three-year term and we will see the cycle through.
—Let's have an election right now.
—You did not win the last four; you will not win the next election.

—I am afraid I must correct Senator Bolkus; the opposition did not win the last five general elections. That puts those opposite in a circumstance that they have not inhabited before in their history as a coalition. As I recall, Mr Acting Deputy President—you would know this better than I—next year marks the fiftieth anniversary of the formation of the Liberal Party. Menzies gathered all the disparate conservative elements together at a conference in Canberra, excluding the Country Party—probably for good reason at the time; perhaps not for good reason now—and began building the Liberal Party as the modern party of conservative thought, talking about the forgotten people. Of course, when Dr Hewson talks about forgotten people, he is talking about entirely different people to those to whom Bob Menzies referred.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the fiftieth anniversary is coming up in 1994. What will the opposition have to celebrate? Five elections lost? Fightback III, courtesy of Senator Newman and colleagues looming? My God, it will be six losses in a row! What is the opposition doing? Instead of crafting an alternative framework, as people such as Senator Watson are more than capable of doing, and putting it to the House and the Senate, we see delay, frustration and obstruction. That is all that the coalition in the Senate is about. It will get much worse in the weeks and months ahead because the Senate has become a mix of billiards and bastardry. There is no doubt about that.

There is malice evident opposite. As I look opposite I can see malice reflected. There are loose balls rolling in the corners from time to time. There is a circumstance, of course, where the instability that we saw reflected on the money markets a week or so ago can recur. That is a most unfortunate development but it is a reality. That is brought home to us at every level in government. There is no question about that. It ought to be brought home to the coalition as well.

It ought to be brought home to the coalition that it is important in this chamber to legislate in the public interest, not in the sectional interest and not to see what maximum havoc can be wreaked on the basis of raw numbers and the deal of the afternoon. That is all those opposite are about doing at the moment. We would welcome any realistic policy debate on the budget. Delay, frustration and obstruction is the order of the day in the coalition. Senator Newman should waltz up Fightback III and election defeat number six will be hers. We look forward to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Loosley has given an interesting speech. At the beginning of his speech he mentioned that Tasmania led the charge in returning the Labor government at the 13 March election. That is true. He also mentioned that one of the factors involved was the Groom government's industrial relations legislation. That, also, was a factor. I engaged in a very vigorous public campaign on television and radio as well as through speaking engagements against those measures because I thought they were putting the boot unfairly into the workers of my state. At a time when unemployment was so high, it was giving an unfair advantage to employers and encouraging unscrupulous employers to have a competitive advantage over the more responsible employers.

PARA.TAB: It remains to be seen whether this government's Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) will go along that particular track. If that is going to be the case, that will be a double deception of the people of Tasmania because a very important factor which influenced voters in Tasmania was the concern over the GST. Make no error about that; the people of Tasmania know the effect of indirect taxes on them. That was a matter of genuine concern. This budget has ignored the community's justifiable concern. It has not only ignored it, but it has also treated the people with contempt because this budget will impact upon regional Australia and Tasmania more than upon other states or other people in other states.

What is remarkable about this budget is its lack of historical vision for this country. After all, in the words of Edmund Barton, federation was supposed to recognise that this was a continent for a people and a people for a continent. No small part of that vision was the linking together of the Australian colonies into one great common market. What is being done now by the government's measures—for example, in the fuel tax area—is to disadvantage many outlying areas of the Commonwealth, including my state of Tasmania.

This budget is a document not only of deceit but also of contradiction. In his budget speech, Mr Dawkins speaks of Australia becoming more competitive and of the tyranny of distance giving way to the benefit of proximity to Asia-Pacific markets. His own budget actions, which of course speak louder than words, proceed to hobble a large part of our transport infrastructure with additional fuel tax burdens. Not only land transport, which is bad enough, but also shipping will bear the brunt of the additional imposts on petrol and diesel fuel.

Incredibly, the excise on marine fuel is to rise by 92 per cent by August next year. Any gains in productivity on the wharves and in our coastal shipping trade is being snatched from the people of Tasmania by the federal Treasury. In case one did not guess, the federal government has no plans to compensate Tasmanians for the increased costs across Bass Strait through proper adjustment of the freight equalisation scheme.

I am also concerned about the way that the government appears to be taking advice from the Treasury on a number of issues. I pointed one out—credit unions and friendly societies—this afternoon in a question to the minister representing the Treasurer. I pointed out that Fisher based his views of these institutions on some very fundamental principles which are at the heart of the labour movement and which were at the heart of the Labor Party. I pointed out that in 1974 Treasurer Crean overcame a decision of the High Court by giving credit unions tax exempt status. I asked the minister to tell the Senate what principles now motivate the Treasurer. They are not Labor Party principles—they are not traditional Labor principles—because those decisions will affect the worker and workers' organisations.

The real failure of this budget is this: it fails to deal with what I believe is probably the most important economic and social question facing this country, and that is chronic unemployment. My feeling, and the feeling of a lot of people in the community, is that we are not in a recession but a painful transition to a situation of continuous drops in standards of living, with a permanent underclass of unemployed and underemployed. In that situation, one would have expected better from this government. But this government does nothing to tackle the unemployment question. It does nothing to look at the question of the participation rate in the paid work force. If the participation rate now was the same as it was 20 years ago, theoretically, in all events, there would be four per cent unemployment.

Thousands of people in the 50-year-old age group want to retire but cannot do so because of the unacceptable loss in standards of living that would result. On the other hand, thousands and thousands in the same age group who have been put out of work desperately want to get back into the paid work force but cannot. Why not give those who want to retire the opportunity to do so and open up their jobs to others?

What about the thousands and thousands of mothers with young dependent children, some infants, who desire to come out of the paid work force but who are denied that opportunity? They are forced to do so because of the government's discriminatory tax attitude towards one income families. They are being discriminated against. Many families now cannot make ends meet on one income. It is a sad reflection that in Australia the privilege of caring for one's own children in the home will be a privilege for the well-to-do. There are a number of other—(Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! The time for debate on the urgency motion has now elapsed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 18 August 1993, I advise honourable senators that the Acting Manager of Government Business lodged a government document with the Clerk immediately after prayers today. Details of the document are attached to today's Order of Business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that this document is the last report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and, through the minister, to the parliament. The Broadcasting Act 1942 was repealed with effect from 5 October 1992. With that repeal and the introduction of the broadcasting services legislation, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal went out of existence.

PARA.TAB: The tribunal had a very interesting career. Over time, it played an important role in regard to standards for television and radio in Australia. Many members of the tribunal gave dedicated service to the people of Australia. They were hamstrung on a number of occasions by government policies which, in many ways, prevented them from performing the functions for which the tribunal was established.

The tribunal's function was not only to consider appropriate standards for television and radio. A major function was to grant, renew, suspend or revoke licences. As a result of the broadcasting services legislation, we now have the Australian Broadcasting Authority. In the very short time that is available to me, I want to deal with broadcasting and television standards and the proposal that was contained in the—
Debate interrupted.
Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That the following address-in-reply be agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Minchin, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.
—Thank you, Mr President, and in particular I thank the officers and staff of the Senate for all the help and advice I have received in recent weeks.

PARA.TAB: As a committed federalist and supporter of upper houses, I am honoured to have been elected to the Senate. I reject the view of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) that the Senate is composed of unrepresentative swill. I do, however, share our Prime Minister's interest in and affection for pigs, as my father was a pig farmer when I was born. Thus I have no objection to swill, but I do object to the notion that this chamber is unrepresentative.

I am proud to represent the state of South Australia and acknowledge the support of the voters of my home state who so overwhelmingly endorsed the Liberal Party on 13 March this year. As the Liberal Party State Director and the Campaign Director in South Australia for the past eight years, it was gratifying that my final campaign saw my party win eight of the 12 House of Representatives seats in South Australia and three Senate seats.

The task of winning three lower seats and a Senate seat from Labor was never going to be easy, particularly in view of the formidable trade union campaign waged against us. Winning an extra Senate seat in South Australia had the happy consequence of ensuring the continuation of the Senate career of my friend Alan Ferguson, who was no. 3 on the Liberal Senate ticket.

While as a professional campaigner I must congratulate the Labor Party on its victory on 13 March, I note that a clear majority of South Australians voted for a change of government and for the policies of the Liberal Party. I have no doubt they will also vote for a change of government at the impending state election in South Australia.

The state of South Australia is suffering significant economic problems which are bound to sweep away the incumbent government. The $3 billion South Australian State Bank debt is the disastrous proof of the wisdom of my long held view that governments should avoid involvement in the ownership and operation of business enterprises. The government's role in the economic life of the state and nation is to set the rules and act as umpire, and to avoid being one of the players.

The conflict of interest inherent in performing both roles invariably produces disastrous outcomes as we have seen not only in South Australia but also in Western Australia and Victoria. This government, to its credit, has at last accepted the need to privatise federal business entities. However, I urge it to move with the greatest possible speed towards extricating itself from the improper role of commercial player.

Modern politics is in many ways a debate about the proper role of government. It is gratifying that in several areas the Labor Party has, albeit reluctantly and slowly, accepted the Liberal view of the role of government in relation to privatisation, the deregulation of the financial sector and opening up the Australian economy to international competition. It is to be hoped that this government, which clearly is as surprised by its victory as anyone, will accept the need to press on with structural reform of the economy, including reform of the labour market, as has been advocated by my party for many years.

The need for economic reform is no more clearly highlighted than in Australia's horrifying level of unemployment, which is a matter for national shame in a country with our assets. Unemployment is acute in my state of South Australia, which frequently records the highest jobless rate of any mainland state. Federal policy must surely have as its overriding objective a massive reduction in the numbers of people who cannot find a job. A situation in which almost one million Australians are unemployed must be unacceptable to every member of the Commonwealth parliament.

Every practice and policy of government should be critically assessed against the backdrop of mass unemployment. The poverty, depression and human misery occasioned by unemployment are intolerable in a country like ours. The millions of Australians affected by unemployment are no doubt frustrated and angry that while they suffer, the national political debate is dominated by discussions of Mabo and the republic. Jobless Australians must wonder how on earth all the talk about native title and changing the constitution will help them get a job.

As a Liberal senator, I believe my responsibility is to argue for policies which will get Australia back to work. My responsibility is not to be ideologically correct but to seek out practical solutions to our number one problem—mass unemployment. My support for giving managers and workers greater freedom to negotiate their own industrial relations arrangements is based not on ideology but on a desire for good outcomes.

The current level of unemployment sends out one clear message about our industrial relations arrangements—they are simply not working. The federal parliament has a responsibility to do everything possible to ensure that our industrial relations arrangements operate so as to maximise employment. That responsibility applies to every facet of federal activity.

In my view every piece of legislation should be subject to an employment impact test. If the proposed law is likely to restrict employment opportunities, then a heavy onus rests on its proponents to say why it should be passed. Indeed, such a test should certainly be applied to the proposed increase in the wine tax. Real job growth can only occur when businesses are sufficiently healthy to be able to employ more people.

I am an unashamed advocate of pro-business policies for that simple reason. A strong, growing business community will employ more Australians. That growth will be a function of the internationalisation of the Australian economy. I am firmly committed to ensuring that international trade is as free as possible, again for the practical reason that trade among nations is the great engine behind the rise in world living standards and the creation of new jobs.

I pay tribute to the courage of a great South Australian Liberal, Bert Kelly, who has fought so hard to demonstrate the benefits of free trade. Australian businesses must be given every opportunity to penetrate overseas markets, which provide the potential for continuous growth in our living standards. I am pleased to see this government move towards a reduction in our own barriers to international trade, and I urge it to resist the pleas of the protectionists.

Our foreign debt problem, which is such a hurdle to sustainable job growth, can only be overcome by making Australia as efficient and productive as possible in order to maximise our export income and our national savings. It cannot be solved by resurrecting the barriers.

Another great economic principle to which I subscribe is that of competition. Competition in the marketplace is the means by which excellence is achieved, productivity increased, living standards raised and jobs created. The great virtue of opening up Australia to the world economy is the increase in the degree of competition.

One has only to look at a great South Australian industry, car manufacturing, to see the virtues of a more open, competitive market and export orientation. The quality of the cars now being produced by Mitsubishi and General Motors in South Australia is a great tribute to everyone involved in those enterprises, and they deserve the support of Australian motorists.

Taxation is another area where real reform is required if we are to maximise employment opportunities. The tragedy of the recent election campaign is its effect on the great cause of tax reform. Almost every objective Australian with an understanding of our tax system believes we must broaden the tax base by replacing our wholesale sales tax with a value added tax on goods and services and commensurate reductions in income tax. No-one has argued the case better than our current Prime Minister, who was unfortunately ambushed by the unions in 1985.

To his credit, John Hewson put policy virtue ahead of political reality in convincing my party to advocate such a proposal prior to the last election. As a professional campaigner I was not at all surprised that our political opponents made the GST the centrepiece of their campaign, and effectively diverted attention from their record in office. However, as an Australian concerned about our country's economic future, I despair that the 1993 election means more wasted years of struggling under the burden of a hopelessly inefficient tax system which is a barrier to higher employment.

The 1993 election confirmed that an opposition will almost certainly never win by promising a new tax. The only way we will achieve sensible tax reform is by an incumbent government, with bipartisan support, biting the bullet. I hope this government will have the courage to put the national interest first and replace our ramshackle indirect tax system with some form of broad based, value added tax as advocated by the Prime Minister in 1985. It is absolute madness for Australia to tax its exports in the way that occurs under our current tax system.

Any discussion of unemployment must address the impact upon the supply of labour in the 1980s caused by high immigration and the increase in the number of women, particularly women with dependent children, entering the paid work force. Net immigration from 1982 to 1992 was just over one million people—an increase of nearly 50 per cent on the previous decade. In the past decade the female work force participation rate has increased by 40 per cent. Since July 1984 the number of married women in the labour force with dependent children has increased by 27 per cent.

Government policies have played a big part in the significant increase in the supply of labour in the last decade which puts an even greater responsibility upon the federal government to have policies which result in a high demand for labour. Immigration has declined to a net 62,700 in 1992-93 and, in my view, should stay within that figure into the foreseeable future. Women are now reaping the benefits of years of struggle to achieve equal opportunity in the paid work force. However, I have a particular concern for those women with dependent children who have been forced by economic circumstance to seek paid employment when they would prefer to be concentrating on their role as mothers and homemakers.

I raise this subject as someone intimately involved with women who have worked for a living. My mother was the second woman journalist to work in the Canberra press gallery and my wife's journalistic career has included service in that same gallery. My interest lies in seeking to restore a realistic choice to those women with dependent children who want to devote themselves to the jobs of mother and homemaker which, for far too long, have been undervalued. The nurture and care of children should be celebrated and those who undertake this task need all our support.

In a survey conducted in 1990 by Dangar Research for the magazine Family Circle, 86 per cent of mothers agreed that the financial situation has forced a lot of women out to work who do not want to; and seven in 10 women would support the government giving much higher child allowances so more women could stay at home. Our social order is a function of the upbringing our children receive from their parents. Mothers who want to be with their children in those critical preschool years should be given that choice.

I believe the Federal Government should introduce a single universal form of child rearing assistance to replace all existing child care and child rearing allowances and subsidies. This single method of assistance could take the form of a tax credit or benefit paid to all mothers with dependent children. Recipients could, of course, choose to spend the allowance on child care or use it to make it financially viable for them to be full time mothers and homemakers, especially during their children's earliest years.

As a firm believer in policies designed to maximise choice and equity, I find it unjust that families in which the mother sacrifices her earning potential to be a full time mother and homemaker end up subsidising, through their taxes, the costs of child care for mothers who have paid employment. Equity demands that mothers with dependent children be treated equally by way of a benefit replacing all other child related allowances and subsidies.

The economic pressures on Australian families caused by unemployment and declining living standards are a cause of considerable concern to me. Those pressures are a significant factor in family breakdown, divorce, domestic violence, disturbed children, youth suicide and rising crime. Government policy should, in my view, do all it can to minimise the degree of family breakdown. My parents divorced when I was eight years old, so I bring to this parliament first-hand experience of the impact on children of family breakdown—and I trust the impact is not too obvious!

I wish to turn briefly to an area of great interest to me, that of electoral matters. Consistent with my strong support for maximising individual choice, I hold firmly to the view that Australians should be free to choose not to vote in federal elections. I am delighted that the Liberal Party of South Australia is committed to the introduction of voluntary voting following the next state election and I look forward to the federal coalition adopting voluntary voting as policy. I am pleased that our federal council has just reaffirmed its support for voluntary voting.

A truly liberal party cannot, with any philosophical integrity, maintain a commitment to compulsory voting. My 14 years full time work as a senior official of the Liberal Party has convinced me of the need to end compulsion. It is a distasteful anachronism that should be abandoned in the interests of the health of our democracy. I regret that while our political opponents continue to believe that they gain an advantage from compulsion, we are likely to continue being one of the very few countries in the world where a voter can actually end up going to gaol for choosing not to vote.

I would like to take this opportunity to note that I am only the second state director of the Liberal Party to be elected to the Senate. The first was Sir John Carrick, a former Leader of the Government in the Senate and a man for whom I have the highest regard. Sir John's devotion to the development of a culture of cooperation in Australian workplaces to replace our culture of conflict is something I admire and share. I happen to believe that the skills and experience acquired in full time party employment are an appropriate background for a parliamentary career.

Unfortunately, the culture of my party has been a little hostile to its professional staff seeking a position in parliament, as witnessed by my being only the second state director in 50 years to enter the Senate. The Liberal Party is more favourably disposed to granting Senate preselection to its former state presidents, five of whom currently serve as senators in this place—all with great distinction, I might add. I do note that the Labor Party has a very different approach to this issue, as is evidenced by the fact that five former national and state secretaries of the party are currently serving in the Senate.

While my career to date has been political, I have virtually no political antecedents. My great great grandfather, Sir Stewart Donaldson, was the first Premier of New South Wales—the state in which I was born and raised. Sir Stewart remained Premier for only three months; I trust that my tenure in the Senate lasts a little longer than that. I had another great great grandfather who was the first director of the Adelaide Zoo—an occupation not unlike that of director of a political party but one which is no doubt viewed by the public as much more worthy.

I hope in my time in the Senate to do as much as any individual politician can to improve the esteem in which the institution of parliament and its members are held. The low regard for MPs in the community should be of concern to all parliamentarians. Liberal democracy is a fragile thing. Its continuation is dependent upon the public's confidence in and trust in the people elected to parliament. A bipartisan approach to the restoration of faith in the parliamentary process is a worthy goal to which I fully subscribe.

The opposition's role in that process is to provide a constructive contribution to the business of government with a constant eye to the national interest. That contribution must embrace a critical examination of government policies and legislation to safeguard this chamber's true role as a house of review. I look forward to playing my part in our common pursuit of the advancement of the Australian nation and its people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Sandy Macdonald, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and, therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him. I call Senator Sandy Macdonald.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many people outside politics in this very diverse nation who are more or just as able as those of us fortunate enough to be elected to this federal parliament. But those of us who make it through the tortuous course of democratic politics have the chance to make a contribution to our constituents and to our nation which must be grabbed with courage and with both hands. John Buchan, one of my favourite authors, wrote in his autobiography:

SPEECH.PARA: Public life is the crown of a career and to a young man it is the worthiest ambition. Politics is still the greatest and most honourable adventure.

I hope for me it will always be an honourable adventure, because there is much to be done. Success in politics is a rare and humbling honour. Let this message go forward to friend and foe: I will not be bought and I will not be bullied from what I believe is right.

PARA.TAB: The people who have most influenced me have been, in the main, sensible and ordinary country people who work hard and believe in their obligations to their family and their community. I frequently meet these people—be it in the shearing sheds, in the feedlots, working in nursing homes, underground in Broken Hill, in the military or wherever—to whom service has its own rewards. They are the heroes of our time and the inheritors of the Anzac spirit. They are the people who demand respect from us elected here. To them I say that I am here because, in the words of Plato, the definition of citizenship in a democracy is participation in government. As Francis Bacon wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It is left only to God and to the angels to be lookers on.

In politics, as in all things, leadership comes from the top. To have a vision for what one wants is not simply enough. One has to have the discipline to go after one's objectives and the discipline to argue one's case with determination and compassion. One also needs conviction, and one only gets that by either being a good actor or telling the truth.

PARA.TAB: In view of the 13 March result, I make just one point: what we argued in Fightback was right and fair for each and every Australian and right and fair for Australia. We on our side might not have showed we cared, but we did care. I care; I care for my country. I still believe in broadening the tax base with all the compensatory measures we proposed. I believe in the removal of taxes on business, especially those on the export sector that must compete worldwide. I believe in the removal of the intrusive hand of unions from the lives of decent people, if that is their wish. I believe in the protection of those disadvantaged Australians who need the help of government at any stage in their lives. You will not find a policy vacuum in me. I want to make that point very clear, Mr President, while I still have your complete attention.

I won my place as a senator in New South Wales at the expense of former senator Karin Sowada. From all reports she is a very decent person who made a unique contribution to the Australian Democrats and the Senate. I know that Senator Sowada was persuaded by logic to support the opposition from time to time. I hope that her independence of mind on what was sensible policy will always be reflected by other members of her party.

In taking my place in the Senate, it is proper for me to thank the New South Wales Central Council of the National Party for giving me the honour of representing it. I am only too conscious of my responsibilities, as I come here representing the 16,000 National Party members in New South Wales and all the people who voted for me, believing that I am able to represent rural and regional people with energy and integrity. I have said it often, and it is worth repeating: if people were aware of the decent citizens who belong to our party, we would win every electorate in the land. That may never happen, but it places a very high expectation on my shoulders and I will not let them down.

I wish to put on record the solid leadership exhibited by the Hon. Duncan Gay MLC, as Chairman of the New South Wales National Party, and the help given to me by him and all party office holders, particularly Judy Simson, Ruth Strang, Malcolm Lobsey, Marie Maunder and the Hon. Doug Scott. There are many others I would wish to thank. A debt of gratitude is owed by me to those who make our political party function. I salute them; they are our true believers.

I come into this place as a representative of New South Wales. I undertake to give my best to the people of New South Wales, which is Australia's most populous state, and to stand up for the rights of New South Wales, while always recognising the value of our federal system to provide services to a country the size of ours. I have chosen to have my electorate office in Singleton in the Hunter Valley. Lieutenant John Shortland's search for escaped convicts led to the discovery of the Hunter River in 1797. Now, nearly 200 years on, this area with its coalmines, power generation, dairying, beef cattle, wine production, tourism, vegetable growing, thoroughbred industry, military bases and industry of every variety is of immense economic significance to us all and of immense economic significance to Australia.
I come into this Senate as somebody who appreciates the excitement of being elected in a democracy. Churchill described it thus:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all others that have been tried.

There are only 10 countries in the world that have had a tradition of democracy for all of this century. Australia is one of those. Only Britain, the United States, Switzerland and Sweden have known longer periods of democratic rule, uninterrupted by dictatorships of the left or right or by foreign conquest or occupation.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that of the six oldest democratic nations, four—Britain, the United States, Canada and Australia—are of British origin and four—Britain, Canada, Sweden and Australia—are monarchies. As a staunch believer in our country's system of government, I will not be persuaded by any republican who tries to distract me from my commitment and my loyalty to the Australia I know, and my belief in our national identity as a free and sovereign nation under our flag.

I do not feel the identity crisis that certain people, especially the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), seem to have about our place in the world. The fact that we have lost our way over the last decade is not the fault of our constitution, but more a lack of leadership and especially a lack of economic management. It will not be our constitutional make-up that threatens our independence by the year 2000, but it may well be the bailiff from the International Monetary Fund.

Republicans say our independence and our nationhood are devalued because we remain tied to Britain. This is not so. Australia long ago severed all legal and constitutional links with the British parliament. We have long been an independent and sovereign nation with our own Queen. The claim that we need to change our constitutional arrangements to become more independent is wrong. What is more, the republicans who allege this understand it to be wrong. We are seeing yet another campaign based on deception and distraction. All of us who are elected to public office and who have some platform in this debate should be ridiculed for such humbug.

Dare I say that the Prime Minister's case is hardly helped by his selection of the manager for constitutional change. Mr Malcolm Turnbull is not a very attractive salesman. I think the Avon lady could teach him a thing or two. Any changes to our constitution over time will be accepted by me only by evolution and not by intemperate imposition by him.

I come into the Senate as a primary producer and woolgrower, recognising that for prosperity our nation needs a healthy farm sector. I know the hurt felt by farmers is not a statistic; they are flesh and blood, they have been my flesh and blood for four generations and they have recently had a hell of a time. I have never believed Australia is an economic model. My view of economic rationalism is that it should make room for humanity, moderation, non-economic issues and planning.

Some of the stories of the wool crisis and the worst drought since 1940 or earlier break one's heart. I know of a 73-year-old specialist woolgrower who has had to sack four men with 112 years combined service.
