DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY ADMINISTRATION (COST SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the National Residue Survey Administration Act 1992 to share the cost of the survey between the Commonwealth and producers.
Motion (by Senator Bell) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take just 45 seconds to emphasise to the coalition that this is yet another opportunity to vote for its own policy—the policy described by Senator Tambling in his speech during the second reading debate on the bill to establish the National Residue Survey Administration Act 1992, which I now seek to amend. During the second reading debate, Senator Tambling said:

. . . Mr Bruce Lloyd, pointed out in his speech during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives that he was unaware of any other country in the world where producers are required to pay in full, as this Bill—
now the act—
requires, for a public health facility.
Later in his speech Senator Tambling said:

PARA.TAB: As these are Budget Bills, the coalition parties will not be opposing them. However, as Mr Lloyd has already said in his speech during the second reading debate—

SPEECH.PARA: and I emphasise this—
on being elected to government, the coalition will amend this legislation and return to 50 per cent cost recovery.
That is precisely what this bill offers, and I invite the coalition to support it. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my second reading speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: During the previous few weeks the Coalition has made a remarkable discovery.

It has discovered that the senate can deal with, and amend, measures imposing taxes and that it can modify bills amending charges or levies. Last year we were repeatedly told by the Coalition Senators that these sorts of things were really Budget bills and couldn't be tampered with. As a result of that view, thousands and thousands of pensioners became pretty upset with the efforts of Coalition Senators when they allowed the Pensioners Shares Bill to pass through the Senate last December. Senator Patterson, for example, well knows that they are extremely angry with the Coalition on this issue. Pensioners know that if it hadn't been for Senator Patterson and her colleagues, they would not now be selling their shares and ringing up Democrat Senators for advice.
I am surprised that a lot more farmers are not just as angry.

Last year we considered a truckload of bills dealing with levies to pay for the National Residue Survey. The Democrats regard this Survey as quite useful and sensible. We need it because we seem to think that we have to keep on throwing chemicals all over the place and at everything that moves in order to grow a decent carrot or potato. Unfortunately we also know that there can be too much of the stuff, with the consequent severe risk to the health of those of us who finish up eating the produce. For that reason we have set up a testing program, monitoring the residues of chemicals left in our produce.
However there are a number of criticisms of the survey.

Many argue that export produce dominates at the expense of produce for domestic consumption—particularly fruit and vegetables. We are not saying that there is too much testing of export produce; indeed we have some concern about the absence of residue testing of Tasmanian potatoes for example and I will be investigating that further. Rather the concern is about the limited testing of agricultural produce for domestic use. There is also concern about the range of chemicals tested and this is another area I will come back to on another occasion.
The other criticism, and the one being addressed by this bill is the funding arrangements.
Currently a levy is placed on producers. On producers whether or not they use chemicals.
Quite simply the funds for the survey should be met from the source of the need for the testing; that is the chemicals. The funds for the survey should come from the sale of the chemicals.

Indeed just today I lodged a petition about this issue and its incompatibility with principles of ecologically sustainable development. The petition requests that the Australian Government place a levy on the sale of agricultural chemicals, in proportion to the toxicity of the chemicals. It goes on to note that the practice is incompatible with the principles of ecologically sustainable development about which this government trumpets so much when it suits it.
Just as we now recognise that the polluter should pay for the costs of polluting, so should the chemical manufacturers be required to pay for the monitoring of chemical residues in our food.
For now though we would settle for 50%.

This is actually the policy of the Coalition and we would expect that they would vote for their policy. Believing that the Coalition would actually support its own policy, I moved the content of this bill as an amendment to the levy Bills introduced last year.

However I was very surprised to find that they weren't interested in their policy. They simply wanted to support the government. It was a budget Bill we heard. Referring to my amendment at the time, Senator Tambling explained how the Coalition, and I quote,
"believes that it is a reasonable apportionment of the public health situation versus the industry.
The Democrats agree, we said so, and I moved the amendments. The Coalition voted them down. They said they were Budget Bills, and anyway they were going to win the election.
I quote again from Senator Tambling:
"on being elected to Government, the Coalition will amend this legislation (that is, the levy Bills) and return to 50% cost recovery.

But of course the Coalition didn't win the election and just as on the Pensioner Shares issue where thousands of pensioners are left with the choice of selling their shares, the farmers affected by this legislation have no further recourse. Perhaps I am being too cynical but it smacks of pure political cynicism. The Coalition's dirty work was actually done by the Government while the Coalition wallowed in the luxury of having a policy that couldn't get implemented. The Coalition should come clean; it had no intention of repealing the Pensioner Shares Bill, it had no intention of reducing the Residue Survey levy on farmers.
If that is not right, Mr President if they did intend to implement their policy they will support this Bill.

We have come full circle. The coalition has come to realise that the Senate can after all deal with these sorts of measures. So they have the chance, today, to prove that what they say is what they do.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate and trust that it has a speedy passage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1.(1)That, within 14 sitting days after the adoption of this resolution by the Senate and 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation of allegiance as a Senator, each Senator shall provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of:
(b)the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware:

2.That statements of the registrable interests of a Senators's spouse or of any dependent children submitted in accordance with paragraph (1) shall be maintained in a separate part of the Register and shall remain confidential to the Committee of Senators' Interests except where the Committee considers that a conflict of interest arises, at which time the Committee may table the declaration.

3.That the statement of a Senator's registrable interests to be provided by a Senator shall include the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware, of the Senator's spouse and of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and shall cover the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (a)shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;

TAB.TAB: (i)in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly rise with pleasure to speak on this debate this evening. It is a measure that has been around for a mighty long time. I can remember that in all the years Senator Button was here he tried get it through. I point out to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the whole chamber and anyone who cares to be listening tonight that I have no problem with this legislation involving the declaration of senators' interests.

PARA.TAB: When I was in local government in Western Australia, councillors' interests had to be disclosed if they were voting on a matter that they may have had interest in. There was no such formality to declare councillors' interests, as the government is asking for now. There was simply a book to sign if one was thinking of voting on a matter in which one may have had an interest.

When I was shire president, I used to wait for people to declare their interests before the discussions started. I used to throw the book at them to sign. Once they had declared their interests, they were not allowed to take part in the debate or to vote. Furthermore, when that debate was over and the motion was passed or lost, it had to be noted in the minutes that councillor such and such was not entitled to vote and did not vote. So I am used to that sort of thing, and I am not frightened of it.

I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and anyone else here in this chamber: what is the use of the form that Senator Gareth Evans's motion has proposed for the declaration of senators' interests? Last May he went through the fiasco—if I may call it that—of getting the Labor senators to declare their interests. I will come to them in a moment. As I said, I am not worried about any such sort of declaration, except in relation to points that I will come to later. But I must ask: what does it achieve?

To find out what it achieves, I looked at the Register of Members' Interests of the 36th parliament. I flicked open a few pages and took the first example that I saw, which was none other than Laurence John Brereton who is in the other chamber. I went through the details, not because he was Mr Brereton but just to see what these declarations exposed to the Senate and to the people of Australia. The first heading states:

SPEECH.PARA: Shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of company or companies.

For himself, he put down, `Nil', which I presume is the situation. For his spouse, he put down, `Not known to me'. The next heading is `Family and business trusts and nominee companies'. I suppose if all these things are there, they are supposed to be filled in to the best of one's knowledge. Once again, for himself he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. For his dependent children he said, `Nil'. The next one, which refers to the nature of operation, states:

. . . in which the Member, the Member's spouse, or a child who is wholly of mainly dependent on the Member for support, is a trustee (but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Member . . .

Once again, Mr Brereton said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. On the question of real estate, he put down his property, his home and a weekender and then for his spouse he said, `See above'.

PARA.TAB: We move on to registered directorships, For himself, once again he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. The next heading states:

SPEECH.PARA: Partnerships indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership.

For himself he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. Then No. 6 refers to the nature of overdrafts, liabilities et cetera, and he explains his own situation. This time he knew what was going on with his spouse because he said, `See above'. For the next one relating to bonds, debentures, et cetera, once again, for himself he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. So what one can know about one's spouse can be a bit selective. The next heading states:
Savings or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned.
For himself he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. Then he goes on to say what his children are doing.

PARA.TAB: I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, how can Mr Brereton—who seems to have children and obviously a wife, though he does not seem to know what she is doing at all—not run a bank account? I would like to know where Mr Brereton's pay goes, whether it goes into a bank account or whether this parliament sends out cash in an envelope. I would just like to know how one can operate a family situation and not have a bank account? I thought for a while that one did not have to declare cheque accounts, but then I looked at other members and senators who have disclosed their cheque accounts. But in this case nothing was disclosed at all.

The form goes on to refer to the nature of other assets. Mr Brereton states that he has part share of two boats, et cetera. The next one refers to other substantial sources of income. For himself he said, `Nil' and for his spouse he said, `Not known to me'. The form continues and he is asked about membership of organisations he belongs to. The final one is No. 14, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any other interest where a conflict of interest with a member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
For himself he said `Nil', and for his wife `Not known to me'.

PARA.TAB: The stupidity of this legislation is the fact that the form is there for those concerned to disclose these details. I object myself to disclosing the spouse's situation, but in this case here one can get around that by saying, `Not known to me'. I believe that if one shares a home and a family life with one's spouse, one has some idea of what is going on in one's spouse's life.

Also when one looks at a fellow like Mr Brereton, who is a minister in this government, one may say that he is a man of very moderate means. It hardly seems right that a minister does not have a bank account. But Mr Brereton is a very presentable fellow; he is well dressed; he mixes with the best of company; he took leave when in Europe to attend a high society wedding in London. I expect then that he has a bank account, or at least has some knowledge of what his spouse does or does not do. Surely there should either be a section relating to the spouse which we should complete, or no section at all. We should not accept the stupid excuse of the person concerned being unaware of what the spouse is doing.

Then I picked up another declaration. It happened to belong to Senator Gareth Evans, who caused this situation in the first place, and who lashed the opposition because we were not in a hurry. Section 9 of the statement of registrable interests asks for details of `the nature of any other assets (excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5,000. Maybe Senator Evans was in a hurry with this section. It is a bit hard to understand his writing, anyhow. But I have looked at this section to find where a motor car fits—there is no other place it could fit—and, as I have seen other declarations showing motor cars under section 9, I presume from this that Senator Evans does not own a car, or at any rate a car worth over $5,000. Going on the average age of Australian cars, any car that is worthy of a minister to drive should be worth $5,000. But there is nothing mentioned. So what do these forms mean? What do they tell us? They tell us nothing whatsoever.

The government, including Senator Evans, made big play of the fact that Labor Party members had filled in these forms so I went through the forms of the ordinary people on the other side, the ones who are not ministers. I saw Senator Cooney's form but I turned his over, and I came to Senator Childs. Senator Childs went through his form and completed it but it is unsigned. It has been tabled unsigned. So what are these documents worth? They are not worth the paper they are written on.

What else do these forms show? They show that you may have a bank account; it does not tell anyone how much you have in the bank account. You are asked about liabilities. I do not think you are asked for details of the extent of the liabilities. So the whole lot is a sham, especially considering one form has been tabled unsigned. I take it that more than half the senators opposite do not own a car. I take it that a few ministers of the government do not know what their spouses are doing. I maintain that if you share a life with a spouse you must have an idea of what their situation is. If you do not, you should not be pretending that it is a family unit. If we are going to have sections asking for spouses' details, let us fill them in properly or let us not fill them in at all.

I ask what all this achieves. There is a wide range of declarations that worries me. It worries me that we have to disclose what a spouse is doing. We also have to disclose details regarding children `wholly or mainly maintained'. In this day of equal opportunity, I find it rather insulting that I have to disclose my spouse's situation. There is more than one reason for that. I might be like Mr Brereton, and not know what my wife is doing. But I do claim that I know. It may embarrass my wife in regard to what she has. It might embarrass her more in regard to what she does not have.

Furthermore, I come to the children. When do children become independent? Sometimes they return to your dependency. Even my party room laughed when I said that, but it does happen. Senator McMullan is smiling at that one, but has he not had the experience I have had and that dozens of others have had? Children may finish a degree, work for a few years and then go back and do a higher degree. The government is not very benevolent towards them; someone has to keep them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or they lose their job.

—That is right. Someone has to keep them while they are doing that second degree or higher study. So what do you? You bring them back home. Then you have to ask your grown-up children exactly what they own. I believe that this is a futile exercise as it stands now.

PARA.TAB: Let us go through some of the finer points of the situation. The resolution says that within 28 days of making or subscribing an oath each senator shall provide a statement of that senator's registrable interests of which the senator is aware. But I might be like Mr Brereton and not be aware of what exactly I own and what I do not own. You have to register the details of yourself, your spouse and your children. If a senator or member is a share-trader—and I presume we are expected to share in the equity of Australia and Australian businesses and invest in businesses that may produce for Australia; I presume there is nothing to be ashamed of in being a share-trader or a share investor—then what do we have to do? We have to put in an updated version every 28 days.Section 1(2) of the resolution states:

SPEECH.PARA: That any Senator who:
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar . . . by the due date;
(b) knowingly fails to notify any alteration . . .
that is, every time you buy and sell a share you have to notify that alteration—
within 28 days of the change occurring;
you might have sold those shares off again—
shall be guilty. . .

But it says `knowingly'. There are not many places where you can use not knowing as a defence. The tax department does not take as a defence that you were not aware of something. So once again as far as I am concerned you can drive a bus through the measures of this registration of senators' interests. This government is trying to create the impression around Australia that members of the coalition might not be the most honest of people. That is all government members are trying to do. They went through the stupid exercise of declaring their interests and having to table them and yet one of them was not signed. I could speak all night on this issue, but unfortunately I am running out of time. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Falkinder, Mr Charles William Jackson, DSO, DFC

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to pay tribute to, and express my condolences on the death of, a great Tasmanian and a great Australian who is a former member of the other place, the House of Representatives, Charles William Jackson Falkinder.

PARA.TAB: Charles Falkinder was born on 29 August 1921 in Tasmania. He had not long left school when he enlisted in the RAAF on 27 May 1940 at the age of 19. He served with tremendous distinction in British bomber squadrons in the European theatres of war. In fact, he released the first bomb over Europe on 6 June 1944, D-day, the invasion of Normandy, which signalled the beginning of a rapid end for Germany.

Bill Falkinder rose rapidly through the ranks of commissioned officers in the RAAF and ended the war as the most decorated bomber-navigator in the RAAF. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross in 1943 with bar the year after. In 1945 he was accorded the very great honour of the Distinguished Service Order. A bomber crew's life was short and tenuous, yet Bill Falkinder flew a remarkable 107 sorties during the war in both heavy bombers and mosquito bombers, the famous plywood planes which required the bravest and the most daring pilots and navigators in order to be flown.

After the war his brilliant career continued. On 28 September 1946 he was elected to the Commonwealth parliament representing the southern Tasmanian seat of Denison. At the time of his election he was just 25 years of age, the youngest person ever elected at that time to the federal parliament. Indeed, the Liberal Party had then been in existence but two years. Bill Falkinder was one of the very first group of candidates elected as members of the Liberal Party only; that is, candidates who had never been elected under the name of another party. Bill Falkinder and his parliamentary peers in the Liberal Party in 1946 presaged the great and seminal election victory in 1949. In 1946, they were harbingers of this victory three years later and of the golden age that Australia was to enjoy for the next two decades.

Bill Falkinder retired from politics, perhaps prematurely, at the age of 46 on 31 October 1966. He had enjoyed re-election to his seat seven consecutive times after 1946. As a politician, Bill Falkinder was forthright and articulate. His primary concern, however, was always with the men and women of his electorate who had actually put him into parliament. We would all do well to consider the way in which this man of such considerable achievements and stature never forgot those who put him into parliament and why he was there.

He understood better than most that his role was to serve his constituents. In fact, his maiden speech dealt with a scheme in existence at the time which was of assistance to the apple and pear orchardists of his state. Some may have thought that a prosaic topic with which to commence a parliamentary career, but Bill Falkinder knew that to his constituents there was not a topic of more interest and importance at that time.

In his last speech on the budget in 1966 Bill Falkinder warned against the dangers of elective dictatorship, to borrow Lord Hailsham's phrase, by the executive. These were not the words of a mere back bench dissentient, but the assertions of a man of principle who believed strongly in the virtues of representative democracy.

Criticising what he termed the deluded view of the divine right of cabinets, he argued that backbenchers had given away their rights as individuals to have an expression in what becomes law through parliament. Such remarks are perhaps even more apposite three decades later and those opposite may do well to note his comments. Following his resignation from parliament, he worked in Sydney as a public relations consultant, finally retiring in 1980 whereupon he returned to his home town of Hobart to live.

Bill Falkinder represents or symbolises a number of things. For Liberals he represents what must have been a fascinating and exciting period—the birth of the Liberal Party and its first dramatic successes. As a parliamentarian, he represented the Australia of the 1950s and 1960s, a time now falsely excoriated as cloistered and dull by historical revisionists for their own shabby political purposes. It was in truth a time of unparalleled growth, prosperity and contentment. In the 1990s, the placidity of that time does not seem such an unenviable quality. Above all, Australia was then a land at peace with itself, a state we can now only aspire to.

Lastly, Bill Falkinder represents the brave and courageous young men who fought for Australia's liberty so selflessly in World War II. We should never allow ourselves to forget that it was the sacrifices of these young men and of their fathers a generation before in the Great War that enable us to live in the free and rich society that Australia is today. A man of many parts, I, as a Tasmanian, take special pride in Bill Falkinder being a son of my state.

I believe that Justin O'Byrne would like to join me in these expressions of condolence. Justin is a former young Australian fighter pilot in the air battles over Europe. Like Bill Falkinder, Justin served in the parliament for many years.
I express my condolences to Patricia, his children, Suzanne and Christopher, and his five grandchildren, Amanda, Mark, Fiona, Nicholas and Aruna. Vale Bill Falkinder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A recent declaration by the World Health Organisation that toxic chemicals and the illnesses they cause are the plague of the present decade is a chilling thought. But in view of the stories that I have been presenting to the Senate over the past 12 months, and will continue to present to the Senate, that should not come as any surprise. Indeed, a colleague of mine has recently put it very succinctly. Sufferers of chemically induced illnesses will soon be making claims in courts that will make the asbestos fiasco look like pocket money for the pictures.

PARA.TAB: We have to find a way now to redress this scourge that we have created. The most effective way to do that is to open up the channels of information. A number of members of this government used to be very vocal about the need for open government. Of course, that was before they came into government. The first time around they were perhaps a little more vocal, but now we do not hear very much about that cliche of open government. It is a long time back. There were prophets who would talk in the style of Ralph Nader and they would quote his famous piece of wisdom that information is the currency of democracy. There is now a genuine developing pressure to significantly open up the information files on chemicals to the general public. The sooner the better.

Take the example of Mancozeb. Mancozeb is a fungicide used in potato production. It is marketed under the names of Mazeb, Dithane 945 or Dithane M45. Information which is supplied with the product says that inhalation, skin absorption, eye contact and ingestion may be harmful and that the effects of overexposure, acute overexposure and chronic overexposure are not known. The safety data sheet supplied by one company says that Mancozeb is considered to be practically non-harmful by all exposure routes, while prolonged skin exposure may lead to mild irritation or dermatic effects. In other words, what we are being told is that it is not exactly a cordial, but then it is not particularly dangerous.
The chemical name is Maneb. I have here a copy of a hazardous substance fact sheet provided by the Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Maneb can affect you when breathed in.
Maneb should be handled as a Carcinogen—with extreme caution.
Overexposure can irritate the nose, throat and eyes. Repeated skin contact can cause a rash.
High or repeated exposures may interfere with thyroid function, cause damage to the nervous system, affect liver function, or cause kidney damage.

The Canadian facts sheet includes much more: it suggests workplace exposure limits, ways of reducing exposure, health hazard information, medical testing, workplace controls, protective equipment and emergency advice. All this is important information. It is produced by the New Jersey Department of Health and is not generally available in Australia. What we are told is something slightly different. One of the strongest criticisms that I have been hearing over recent months is just that—that information is not readily available. There is concerted reluctance, and in many cases even a refusal, to provide it.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, I can quote the example of a constituent of mine who came into my office for help the other day. In the course of his work, labouring on a Tasmanian government project, he was required to apply chemicals from a can marked `Mineral turpentine'. No advice about safety or protective equipment was supplied to him. After suffering some horrific skin ulcerations and loss of sleep for weeks at a time, headaches, kidney and abdominal pains, he found that he had been exposed to Agent Orange. It had taken several years of persistently battering the bureaucracy to get information, which should have been supplied when he was asked to administer whatever it was in that can marked `Mineral turpentine'. The information came too late for him to be able to use it through the courts.

People should not have to resort to freedom of information provisions on these issues, nor should they have to go through a bureaucratic minefield of stonewalling evasion or even hostility, as was the case with Lorinna residents in Tasmania recently, to whom I will refer in a moment. People should not have to go through that sort of messing about to obtain the information from overseas. It should be available here. United States experience suggests that public access to information about chemicals through a legislative framework is an important means of promoting a safer environment, reducing the usage of toxic chemicals and preventing pollution and initiating clean methods of production. These are all issues that are now too important to be trusted simply to the secrecy of government and industry, which are trying to make a profit from it.

The Australian chemical industry, sensing that the tide of public opinion is gaining support in its demands for greater access to information about the chemicals it produces, has undertaken the development of a responsible care program. Part of this program is the inclusion of a version of community consultation. The extent to which that is translated into action remains to be seen because so far industry has baulked at disclosing information about its products, making the usual claim of commercial considerations. That is the record so far. This is all we have to judge these companies by.

Public consultation is still an illusive concept and it does mean different things to different people. Because the need has now become so urgent and important, because the issues have literally become a matter of life and death for so many people and because our agricultural resource base is under threat, nothing less than full disclosure of the relevant information upon request can be acceptable. Nothing less than a national information resource providing information on formulation, toxicology, exposure data, labelling and legal, health and medical data on all toxic chemicals is required. It must occur and I will be pursuing this during these sittings.

Last year I told the Senate about the D'Alton special school in Hobart. This was a special school for children with a wide range of disabilities. That school closed down after reactions to the children following a routine spraying for argentine ants. Although it was authoritatively claimed at the time that everybody was suffering from a winter virus, many attribute the `emotive reaction' to the toxic chemicals which were used on that site. Not only has there been no obligation on authorities to provide the full information after investigations, there was a clear refusal to even consider that insecticide poisoning had been responsible for what occurred; yet the authorities saw fit to close down the site.

We increasingly have situations where people are expected to quietly accept the advice and the word of government or industry. That is no longer good enough. In Tasmania, for example, we had the recent case of the drinking water contamination by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and the use near Lorinna of the herbicide Atrazine. The people of Lorinna were told that the chemical Atrazine was quite safe, yet it is listed by the International Agency for Research on Cancer of the World Health Organisation as a category 2B carcinogen. Is that quite safe? We do not know. In other words, Atrazine is described as a substance for which there is sufficient evidence in animal tests, or degrees of evidence considered appropriate, to classify it by that body as a possible human carcinogen. In response to a question on notice, the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Atrazine is a residual herbicide with relative persistence . . . Atrazine is no longer approved for use in Sweden due to concerns over possible water contamination.

The central point is that it is not for government alone to be making assessments about the safety of a chemical and holding the information in secret files. People who will be affected ought to be able to gather information about, in this case, the toxicity of the stuff which ends up in drinking water. That right ought to exist and there is absolutely no excuse to withhold that right any longer.

PARA.TAB: I have pointed to tangible benefits that would result from full disclosure of information about chemical use in our society. Specifically, the United States experience is that its Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act 1986, which gives citizens access to information about corporate uses and emissions of toxic chemicals, has enabled chemical use to be reduced by up to 20 per cent compared with 1987.

Another piece of legislation is California's proposition 65. I am sure honourable senators will be aware of how California's legislation in the form of propositions comes to force. These are propositions which originate from the community. California's proposition 65 requires businesses to warn citizens beforehand if they may be exposed to a significant amount of a chemical known to cause cancer or reproductive harm. In addition, the burden of proof was reversed so that industry needed to be able to demonstrate that exposure to listed chemicals posed no significant risk. A very important aspect of that is well endorsed by the experience which has subsequently ensued.

As a result of those legislative initiatives, emissions have decreased to the point where six listed chemicals are no longer emitted at all. A number of companies have made public commitments to reduce emissions. For example, the Monsanto Corporation has pledged to reduce by 90 per cent its worldwide toxic emissions. AT&T of the United States has set a goal of eliminating toxic air emissions by the year 2000. I would suggest that a very important catalyst in bringing about these pledges by these companies has been the legislation that I have described so far.

Industry is part of society and must be accountable to it. Full disclosure enables the public to better understand the effects of chemicals on health and the environment. Public exposure and involvement will enable better emergency planning and a greater ability to plan for potential disasters.

The Coode Island disaster of 1991, for example, highlights the need for much better access to information on toxic chemicals. Indeed, the final report of the review panel recommended that legislation was needed to assist the public understanding of hazardous materials and production processes. Currently, the responsibility for planning for emergencies is entirely with government agencies. In the United States, the communities are involved in local emergency planning committees. Information on the location and nature of the storage of toxic chemicals is required by those communities.

The Canadian city of Vancouver, for example, has legislation which requires that when pesticides are applied to areas under its jurisdiction—including parks, schools, community centres and theatres, et cetera—signs which feature the well recognised skull and crossbones, the symbol of danger, have to be erected for a certain time. In Australia, nothing less should be acceptable. Residents surely have the right to be informed and, more importantly, warned about activities such as blackberry spraying and other weed control measures that are occurring in their neighbourhood if those activities are dangerous. How many councils in Australia actually do regard it as their obligation to signpost their spraying operations? I suggest that to do so would inevitably draw attention to another sort of pesticide poisoning, aerial spraying.

Another area of great concern is the composition of pesticides and, particularly, whether labelling is adequate. I am sure that many honourable senators will have been confronted by the sorts of labels that can be seen on pesticide cans. While the concentration of the active component is shown on those labels, little information is supplied about the other inert components in the mixtures. For example, some products contain toxic spectator compounds that function as solvents to be able to carry the active agents. They might carry wetting agents or dispersants to make the active ingredient work.

Toxicology testing is conducted on the active ingredient rather than on the mixture as it is used in its application. In other words, when it is all mixed together, we really do not have a clue about the effect that it might have. Unfortunately, despite that, there is no evidence that industry is about to regulate itself towards recommending that toxicological testing be conducted on the actual mixture.

It is also relevant to refer to the mixtures of different chemicals that are frequently used in agriculture and elsewhere. Often, two or more chemicals are either mixed for the purpose of application or applied in tandem, perhaps to save passing continuously by one form of equipment or to meet a seasonal requirement that it be done within a certain time.

I am continuously being asked by people to insist that government and industry start toxicity testing on the basis of real life situations—not laboratory testing but actually as things are applied. I have just mentioned that chemicals are used in tandem or in a mixture. These techniques are still being used without reference to tests that have been made regarding that sort of practice.

It is no longer good enough for us to be treating chemicals as single agents. They are not. More often, they are being used in conjunction with others, the combined result of which is simply not known. The cocktail effect often brings about the unknown symptoms which I have been at pains to provide this chamber with for so many months now.

The time has gone when our population can continue to be fobbed off on these issues. There is a real and increasing demand for information about the chemical wonders of our time. An increasing number of people are allergic to chemicals. There are people who are subjected to chemicals when they go about their business in our schools, parks and general homes. They are exposed to chemicals which are attached to food which has been produced or chemicals in places of entertainment.

I suggest that the next time honourable senators board an aircraft they make sure it is not the one which has been sitting on the tarmac overnight, because one of the first things that is done before they sit down is the application of chemicals to the seats. If it contacts their skin and it is still in a strong concentration, they may suffer a reaction. Cleaning chemicals are normally supposed to dry off before people take their seats.

People going about their normal daily business are exposed in a number of ways. It may be that before honourable senators take their seats they have applied another chemical to their skin. That cocktail is unknown in its effect. We need to know much more about the chemicals to which we are exposed in going about our daily business. We all have the right to know the composition and the known and unknown effects of these new agents of our modern living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to speak briefly on a matter in the history of Australia which has been subject to very long, and perhaps endless, debate. I refer to the events of 1975 that occurred in this place concerning the blocking of supply, as it was called, and the subsequent events which led to an election and a landslide victory for the coalition.

PARA.TAB: Today, during the debate on the urgency motion, Senator Loosley and I exchanged interjections. He raised the point that, following the 1993 election, the coalition had not accepted the people's voice and the defeat of that election. My interjection was that the Labor Party has never accepted the 1975 defeat and the people's voice then. It was good to see—it made my day—Senator Loosley's reaction to that comment because it really did symbolise the Labor Party's continual bitterness and its uncontrolled agitation about the events of 1975. It showed that Labor Party inability to hold back a swelling of anger. It was good to see that I hit the spot.

Senator Loosley then accused the coalition of running the 1975 tactics in the Senate in this session of parliament. He said that we would disrupt the parliament in the same manner as the coalition opposition did in 1975. My reply to that was, `Absolutely'. Senator Loosley should not have been as surprised as he looked, because my views should not surprise him.

I was a very keen student of politics in those days and attended many of the rallies that were held in the lead-up to the 1974 election and straight after the dismissal. Moreover, my views about the events of 1975 were put down in my maiden speech in this parliament on 21 September 1987. I will read a section of my maiden speech once again:

SPEECH.PARA: I stand by the powers of the Senate to review, pass or reject Supply or any such similar appropriation Bill as outlined in the context of section 53 of the Constitution. It is an authority given to the Senate in the Constitution under the democratic principle that a second House is needed to check, balance and review the conduct of the executive arm of government. This is common and fundamental to the past and continuing ideal of our Australian democratic system of government. I oppose such tired yet persistent attempts to reduce the important and traditional role of the Senate so clearly set down by our forefathers.

How similar are the events of today to those of 1975. Following the 1974 Labor election victory by the then Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, the government immediately went into a spiral of chaos. The Whitlam government went into terminal decay immediately following the 1974 election.

PARA.TAB: Today, as then, the government is morally bankrupt in the eyes of the community. Now, as then, we have a Prime Minister who has been rolled by his cabinet and caucus as recently as today on important issues, such as budget matters, and national issues, such as Mabo. Senator Loosley and the other members of the government know that all too well. They can smell the events of 1975 encroaching upon them again—that spiralling decaying government.

Like the then Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, the now honourable Prime Minister, Mr Keating, leaves parliament early. Gough Whitlam had no interest in economics. When the issues he was interested in were finished for the day, and the parliament probably got on to more important matters such as the economy, he would leave parliament. The present Prime Minister is not much different; he leaves early too. When matters that are of particular interest to him, such as the republic, are not being debated he can be found back at home away from the running of the country.

There is a difference between the then Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, and the now honourable Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Gough Whitlam based his political motivation on himself; Mr Gough Whitlam's role model was Mr Gough Whitlam. Unlike Mr Gough Whitlam, the now honourable Prime Minister, Mr Keating, as we all know, bases himself and his political background on Mr Jack Lang. This must be a case of history repeating itself. If one looks at the history of Jack Lang, one sees that he was one of the more ratty and madder politicians this country has seen. In the dying days of his political life he became a most bitter man and a nonsensical man. I think there are great parallels to be drawn there.

While the Senate is not of the same makeup as it was in 1975—and nor is the Governor-General of the same ilk—there is no doubt that this government has the terminal decay smell of Mr Gough Whitlam's government. It is a regime that is now in a spiral to defeat.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Falkinder, Mr Charles William Jackson, DSO, DFC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks made tonight by my colleague Senator Watson about the untimely death of a very distinguished Tasmanian, a courageous Australian and fine member of the other place, Mr Charles William Jackson Falkinder CBE, DSO, DFC and Bar. As has been said earlier tonight by my colleague, Bill Falkinder was one of Australia's most decorated, if not the most decorated, bomber-navigator in the European theatre of World War II.

PARA.TAB: Bill would have been 72 years old yesterday. He was born in Hobart and, like many famous Tasmanians, he was educated at Hobart High School. In 1939, like a lot of young Australians, he joined the RAAF and was one of the first empire air scheme trainees to arrive in England. He went on to serve in the elite Pathfinder force of Bomber Command. He completed 107 sorties in heavy bombers and Mosquito aircraft. It is said that he was a navigator of great technical skill and efficiency, and that he had a great devotion to duty. He went on to become a wing commander. As Senator Watson said in his speech, because of his ability he was chosen to release the first bomb over Europe on D-day.

Our former colleague Bill Falkinder came to the other place in 1946 at the age of 25, and was at that time the youngest member of parliament. He was re-elected in 1949, 1951, 1954, 1955, 1958, 1961 and 1963. He retired in 1966 in frustration. A report of an interview he gave at the time stated:
``Frustration had something to do with it,'' he says. ``There is a regrettable tendency for Parliament to be run by the executive''.

SPEECH.PARA: What has changed from that day to this? A more recent member for Franklin, Bruce Goodluck, also retired in frustration, I believe.

PARA.TAB: As the member for Franklin, Bill Falkinder represented my electorate. My family and I have lived there all our lives, and my family before me. As Senator Murphy knows, Tasmania is a small place when it comes to sorting out families and relationships. I must say that the late Bill Falkinder had more than a passing interest in my birthplace of South Arm. It seems that Bill's sister, Helen, was a land army girl who worked on a property next door belonging to my uncle. Also, before the war, Bill Falkinder spent many happy times at the residence of his sister, Mrs Drake, in a seaside cottage at South Arm less than half a mile from where I lived.

After World War II South Arm was a favourite recreation area for more than one federal politician. I remember very well the late Sir Reginald Wright spending many a happy time at South Arm where he owned a seaside cottage. I can remember having a drink with him at the local RSL club. Likewise, the late Hon. Athol Townley, a former Minister for Defence, spent a fair amount of time at South Arm. Mr President, you may remember that this former Minister for Defence first ordered our F1-11 fighter bombers which are still looked upon as being one of our foremost defence aircraft.

Like Senator Watson, I looked with particular interest at Bill Falkinder's maiden speech. I say this with no disrespect to my colleagues Senator Troeth and Senator Sandy Macdonald, but maiden speeches are often looked back on later in life and what one says in that first speech may come back to haunt one. Bill Falkinder made his first speech following debate on the budget of 1946-47. In those days, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Menzies, had moved by way of amendment that the first item be reduced by #1 as an instruction to the government. In other words, what was happening in the chamber in those days was very similar to what is happening here in the Senate today.

As Senator Watson said, Bill Falkinder spoke about his electorate and about how the Labor government of the day was supporting an apple and pear acquisition scheme of some nine million bushels. I must say that the apple industry has reduced somewhat since then, but I am pleased to see that it is making a comeback. In those days #2 1/2 million was a direct capital investment into a scheme that acquired fruit and destroyed it to keep the industry going—things have changed somewhat since then—and it was a Labor government that was doing that.

I looked back to see what happened before Mr Falkinder made his speech. Mr President, you will be pleased to know that there was a certain Mr Harrison in the other place who would not withdraw a remark. As you would know, that Mr Harrison was the father of former Senator Shirley Walters. That is interesting—it must run in the family, as she would not withdraw. I quote from the Hansard:
Mr. HARRISON.—I will not withdraw and apologize.
Mr. SPEAKER.—I name the honourable member for Wentworth.

SPEECH.PARA: Then some young, new member for Richmond, I believe it was, a Country Party member in those days, Mr Anthony, interjected and said:
Name the Minister, too!
The Speaker turned around and said:
I warn the honourable member for Richmond (Mr. Anthony) that I shall name him if he disregards the authority of the Chair.
I thought things were much more quiet in those days. Mr Anthony said:
Have a go!
So he did. He named the honourable member for Richmond who retorted with:
A very impartial Speaker, a back-stabber!

Obviously, in those days as well, they were having trouble with the Speaker in the other place. Both of those opposition members were named and they departed from the chamber. I just wonder what was going through Bill Falkinder's mind when he had to follow on and make his first speech in that place. Obviously, Bill Falkinder did a very fine job for his electorate. He held a seat for 20 years. I doubt whether anybody else will ever do that—including Harry Quick—in the electorate of Franklin, because it is a changing area. He was very well respected by those people who I remember talking about him. He was obviously a very fine Australian, very courageous and successful, and one of the few bomber pilots who returned to Australia. I pass on my condolences to his family—his wife, Patricia, his daughter, Suzanne, his son, Christopher, and his grandchildren. I support the remarks made earlier by my colleague Senator Watson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise a matter relating to a doctor from Nowra whom I know very well. He was the anaesthetist involved when I had a hernia very effectively fixed up in the Shoalhaven hospital. In the House of Representatives adjournment debate on 18 August Mr Knott, the temporary member for Gilmore, quite improperly and disgracefully blackguarded this reputable and decent doctor from Nowra. Mr Knott said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is with some trepidation that I do what I am about to do. . .
Obviously he did it with no conscience, no decency and no concern for the facts, as well as with some trepidation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, I have just been thinking about what you said. That was a direct imputation against a member of another place.
—That is probably true, Mr President.
—I think you should withdraw it.
—I withdraw it. Was that the bit about the conscience and so on?
—You said that he acted improperly.
—I withdraw that element. I believe that he acted disgracefully. Can I say that?
—No. Senator Baume, you cannot make an imputation like that against a member of another place.

—I withdraw the imputations because the facts will speak for themselves. Without any reference whatsoever to this doctor, without seeking to inquire of the facts of this doctor, Mr Knott—with the protection of parliamentary privilege—attacked him in a way which I believe to be unacceptable. I thought that the normal decencies are that, if one is are going to make accusations about a doctor, particularly accusations such as, `I do not think he is a person who should be practising medicine', it would be worth at least establishing the facts. Mr Knott thought so strongly of this point that he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Is this doctor the sort of person who should even be practising medicine?

Let us deal with the facts. The facts are that Mr Knott has a personal friend who received an account from the doctor. Mr Knott did not admit that this was the 10th account for the same service from this doctor—the 10th account over a period of 2 3/4 years. All this patient had to do was take the bill to the Medicare office, get a Medicare cheque and take it to the doctor in payment of the account. This patient was too indolent to do that. Did Mr Knott check on that? Not on your nelly.

PARA.TAB: The simple facts are these: according to Mr Knott, this patient received a letter saying that there was an amount outstanding on his account. In that letter—this is what prompted Mr Knott to make these accusations—it was said:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that all four Anaesthetists rendering services in the Shoalhaven area have a computer linked system. All non payments are obvious and noted by all doctors concerned. Therefore, in order not to jeopardise receiving future treatment PLEASE PAY YOUR ACCOUNT PROMPTLY!!
Mr Knott says that there is an imputation there that no anaesthesia services would be provided to this recalcitrant patient if he did not pay his bill. Mr Knott goes on:
. . . I will progressively name the other three doctors, whether they are threatening this friend of mine with not receiving medical attention in an emergency?

There is no suggestion that in an emergency no service would be provided. But tell Mr Knott that, because he obviously does not understand. Not all medical services are emergency services; there is such a thing as discretionary surgery. I am overjoyed to see that we have a doctor sitting on the front bench opposite who will know how ludicrous this accusation is.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that these four anaesthetists operate out of one office. They are in a cooperative venture, sharing the same secretary, the same telephone and—shock, horror!—the same computer for their accounts.

Why does Mr Knott seek to penalise the victim—the doctor who is not getting paid—when in fact it is the Commonwealth that would, should the bill be paid in full, be providing the total amount and, if the Medicare cheque were to be taken in full settlement, the whole of the bill?

At no stage does Mr Knott seek to justify the failure of this man to pay the account after 2 3/4 years—if this is the patient that Mr Knott himself appears to have identified to the doctor. The doctor tells me that he has never taken action against any patient; that he can only identify this one person from the evidence presented. He has not given me his name and I do not seek it. But Mr Knott has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The doctor has never asked why this man has never paid.

I ask Mr Knott why, over 2 3/4years, did this man not take one of the 10 bills he received along to the Medicare office, get a cheque and give it to the doctor? What was his moral objection to paying what he was obliged to pay, or to getting off his backside and getting the government's cheque that was obliged to be paid for the provision of a service that presumably was to his advantage?

PARA.TAB: Why do people think that they can with impunity avoid their own obligations? Is it because they have members of parliament, such as Mr Knott, who will get up and traduce a doctor—damn him publicly—as someone not fit to carry on his profession if the doctor dares to say, `Come on, pay your bill'? Mr Knott goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the federal police to look at whether or not these people are guilty of threatening my friend's life.

Great stuff for the local paper—because that is what it is all about. It is a desperate attempt by Mr Knott to show that he is in there fighting for the battlers who were foolish enough to elect him temporarily as the member for Gilmore.

PARA.TAB: If Mr Knott is going around threatening this doctor, I threaten his friend's ability to avoid meeting his responsibilities with impunity. I am a threat to his ability to do that, because he will not do so with impunity. I hope the local media will respond to what I am saying about what I believe is the unacceptable way that Mr Knott has misrepresented the reality. How dare Mr Knott ask: should this sort of person not be facing some sort of criminal charge for his actions? This is the doctor. It is great headline stuff, is it not?

Here we are, penalising the victim. The victim is not the patient who got ten, `Get off your backside and give me the cheque', notes. The victims are the doctor and his employee, and the system which is being mucked around by people like this who are too indolent to even provide the Medicare cheque.

It may be that the patient thought, `Oh dear, I won't go and get the Medicare cheque because he'll want the rest'. But at no stage did the patient communicate that he had any difficulty whatsoever in paying the bill. He certainly indicated that he had no difficulty in getting off his backside and going to the Medicare office to get the cheque. In fact, there was no contact whatsoever until just before Mr Knott raised this matter in parliament. The debt was magically paid one week before Mr Knott raised it in the parliament, but only to the extent of the Medicare cheque and not the balance. In other words, the doctor had to wait 2 3/4 years before something that ultimately cost the patient nothing, except a little energy, was done.

All I ask of Mr Knott is that he do better and learn the responsibilities of being a member of parliament. If Dr Cole, for whom I have a high regard, is regarded by Mr Knott as not being a fit and proper person to be practising medicine, I could say that that is in itself a great commendation to Dr Cole. He must be good if Mr Knott denigrates him. I assure Dr Cole and any other medical practitioners who are subject to this kind of standover tactic that I will do all I can to ensure that the full story is told, and that no member of parliament—I use the phrase in a generic sense—should improperly blackguard decent, honourable members of the medical profession with impunity.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions tonight. One of the things that sticks in my mind is the thought of a young man, Bill Falkinder, arriving in this place in 1946, aged 25, having done, as both Senators Watson and Calvert said tonight, all those things for so many years and survived them. It is quite extraordinary. One would have thought he might have arrived here at age 40. To be 25 and having survived he must have brought an extraordinary history into this place. While I did not know Bill Falkinder, I certainly join with the sentiments of my colleagues opposite who have brought that to my attention and to the attention of Senate.

PARA.TAB: I thank Senator Bell for his alerting the Senate to the importance of accessibility of the community to information about toxic chemicals. It is a very important point and one that is consistent with Senator Bell's contributions in this place on that and other matters.

Senator McGauran's contribution was nothing if not amusing. In football parlance there is the description of a spoiler. They may sometimes be effective, but they are never elegant. I ask Senator McGauran to meditate on that.

Senator Baume's contribution causes me some anxiety. I am the doctor sitting opposite he referred to earlier. From what he has said and from what has been given to the Senate tonight, we can be sure we do not know the full story. I think it is important that we leap to those kinds of judgments from whichever side with caution. It is important that we are slow to judgment in these matters. If what he said is true about doctors collectively indicating that they would withhold service, I can certainly understand a concern on behalf of citizens but, as I say, I can only go on what he has said tonight. I think it is important that we say no more because we do not have the full facts. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article by Robert Richards in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 March 1993 regarding the liability to fringe benefits tax of outplacement services provided by employers.

(1) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) confirmed that, apart from the provision of counselling services, which are specifically exempted by s.58M of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 ("the Act"), the provision of other outplacement services will be subject to a fringe benefits tax liability.

(2) Will the provision of such services be specifically exempted from fringe benefits liability, especially in the present economic climate where large scale retrenchments are occurring with their industries; if not, why not.
(3) Is the ATO aware that the precedents for special tax treatment are as follows; ss.58K, 58L, 58LA, and 58M of the Act.

(4) Will the Act be amended to exclude from its operation the provision of outplacement services, which may include, as well as counselling, retraining to enable the employee to undertake alternative work and the provision of office services to enable retrenched staff to organise interviews and have resumes typed; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In answer to Items 1 to 4 above, the ATO has recently reviewed the application of section 58M of the Act as it relates to the provision of outplacement services and counselling.
The ATO has advised that the scope of section 58M of the Act is generally wide enough to encompass benefits provided to employees in the form of outplacement services and counselling.

The view is taken that the provision of normal outplacement services improve or maintain the quality of the performance of the employer's remaining employees. As such, these services fall with the definition of "work-related counselling" in subsection 136(1) of the Act and, thus, within the exemption in section 58M of the Act.

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there concern in the Mandurah region, south of Perth, about pollution emanating from a piggery at Wandalup, which is operated by George Weston Foods.

(2) Is this pollution fed into the Serpentine River and ultimately into the Peel-Harvey Wetland System which is protected under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands and the Japan-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement and the China-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement.
(3) Has the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service been alerted to ensure that Australia's obligations under these international treaties are honoured; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There have been concerns expressed about the high levels of phosphorus entering the Peel-Harvey Wetland System from piggeries in the Peel-Harvey Catchment, including the Wandalup Farms piggery. Wandalup Farms piggery and the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority (WA EPA) have agreed on a strategy to reduce phosphorus discharge by at least 75% through the installation of a wastewater treatment plant by July 1994. The reduction in pollution was in line with the objective for all land uses in the Peel-Harvey catchment.

(2) The Serpentine River flows into the Peel-Harvey Wetland System. Nutrients emanating from the piggery reach the Serpentine via a constructed drain, even though the piggery is almost l500m from the river itself. The WA EPA River Pollution Strategy released in December 1992 gives priority to the Swan, Peel-Harvey and Albany waterways.

(3) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency (formerly the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service) has been advised of the strategies to reduce pollution in the Peel-Harvey catchment and is satisfied that these will improve water quality in the future and ensure Australia's obligations under the international convention and bilateral agreements are being met.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Does the Australian Bureau of Statistics use the umbrella title "Yugoslav" or "Yugoslavia" in official records and publications to also refer to the people of Bosnia and Croatia; if so, does the Government propose to change official use of the word "Yugoslavia" in its records and publications to reflect the new countries in south-eastern Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The ABS does not yet separately identify people from the new countries of the former Yugoslavia in statistical publications due to concerns about data reliability.

People born in territory which is now part of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia or Slovenia frequently give the name of the country as it then was ("Yugoslavia") in response to a question about their country of birth.

The variation in the information provided to the ABS places serious limitations on the usefulness of the data for distinguishing country of birth in terms of current boundaries. Current ABS practice is to aggregate the data relating to such people and show it in statistical tables with the label "Former Yugoslav Republics". The label "Yugoslavia" is used for data collected during the period before Australia recognised the independence of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, including data from the 1991 Census.

Where individuals responding to the 1991 Census described their country of birth as one of the constituent republics of the former Yugoslavia, this information was coded. Consequently, 1991 Census counts of birthplace can be compiled on request for all six constituent republics of the former Yugoslavia. Similar information is available in respect of overseas arrivals and departures. However, in both cases the data would be subject to serious quality limitations for the reasons outlined above.

Information about the country of origin of persons is classified by the ABS according to the Australian Standard Classification of Countries for Social Statistics (ASCCSS). The ABS uses this classification to compile statistics on the birthplace of members of the Australian population or the birthplace of their parents. It is also used in statistics on overseas arrivals and departures. The ASCCSS was revised to separately identify Croatia and Slovenia after Australia recognised their independence on 16 January 1992. However, the ASCCSS has not yet been revised to include Bosnia-Herzegovina.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Does the department use the umbrella title `Yugoslav' or `Yugoslavia' in official records and publications to also refer to the people of Bosnia and Croatia; if so, does the Government propose to change official use of the word `Yugoslav' in its records and publications to reflect the new countries in south-eastern Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Departmental records and publications are expected to refer to people of foreign countries in accordance with the Australian Government's recognition of foreign states. The Australian Government recognised as independent countries the following republics that were part of the former Yugoslavia:
Slovenia—16 January 1992
Croatia—16 January 1992
Bosnia-Herzegovina—1 May 1992
It is Government policy that individuals from these countries be referred to by their country name, eg Croatians, and not as `Yugoslavs'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are there no industry representatives on the newly created Australian Consumers' Council (ACC).

(2) Was any peak industry body, such as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI), or the Business Council of Australia, or the Confederation of Australian Industry approached for input into the ACC; if not why not.
(3) Do peak bodies, such as the ACCI, speak for Australian industry, or does the Society of Consumer Affairs Professionals in Business, or any other society, represent industry interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Industry and business are represented on the Australian Consumers' Council (ACC). The ACC was created to provide the Government with consumers' views on strategies for effective consumer protection. Its objective is to provide a source of expertise to enable the Minister both to anticipate consumer protection developments and to make the quickest and most effective response to consumer protection developments as they arise. The Society of Consumer Affairs Professionals in Business (SOCAP) was asked to nominate a member on the ACC in order to help bring the widest community perspective to the ACC's task.
(2) None of the peak bodies cited was approached for input into the Australian Consumers' Council. SOCAP was approached to nominate a member of the ACC, for the reason cited in (1).

(3) The responsibility and purpose of SOCAP are specifically to foster and maintain the integrity of business in dealing with consumers and to encourage and promote effective communication and understanding between business, consumers and government. There can be no more effective voice on the Australian Consumers' Council than SOCAP for business and industry which are committed to the best interests of their customers.
