TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to personnel serving as Ready Reservists, and the fact that some will enrol as students but finish their Army engagement after their education has been completed, perhaps in professional employment:
(1) In the event of injury in the final period of their engagement, at what level will compensation be paid.
(2) At what level will compensation be payable should the injury be re—aggravated in the future when the ex—Reservist is working in private enterprise or is self—employed.
(3) At what level will compensation be paid should the injury be re—aggravated in the future should the ex—Reservist be working in the Public Service.
(4) If there is any difference between the two levels of compensation, was any consideration given to this when the Reserve concept was being planned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Members of the Ready Reserve are entitled to the benefits provided by the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRC Act 1988) if they suffer an injury arising out of, or in the course of, their Ready Reserve employment and that injury results in death, incapacity for work or impairment:

For each of the first 45 weeks of incapacity following a compensable injury, a Ready Reservist would receive 100 percent of the pre—injury normal weekly earnings. Should resulting incapacity exceed 45 weeks, compensation payments would reduce to 75 per cent of normal weekly earnings for the duration of the incapacity until age 65 years.

All reasonable medical, hospital and treatment costs incurred as a consequence of the compensable condition would be covered under the SRC Act 1988 and a rehabilitation program, specifically designed to assist the injured member return to work, will be developed in consultation with the injured party and the treating health providers.

Should a compensable injury result in permanent impairment, assessment of the extent of the functional impairment and related non economic loss would be undertaken and a lump sum award paid. Acceptance of the lump sum award would not disentitle the recipient from any of the other benefits available under the Act.

(2) If an aggravation of the injury occurs as a consequence of an incident in private employment, this would normally be considered a new injury. Compensation for the incapacity associated with that incident would be payable by the workers' compensation insurer of the private employer at the level provided for by the prevailing State or Territory workers' compensation legislation.

(3) If the ex—Reservist joins the Australian Public Service, workers' compensation insurance would be provided by the SRC Act 1988 and an aggravation of a pre—existing injury by Commonwealth employment would be treated as a new and separate injury with compensation payable as detailed above.

(4) The difference between the levels of compensation payable in respect of an aggravation in private employment, or an aggravation in public service employment, is related to the level of benefit available under the workers' compensation legislation applicable to that employment. Should an ex—Reservist suffer an aggravation working for either a private employer, or the public service in an Australian State or Territory, the level of benefit payable is that provided for by the relevant State or Territory workers' compensation scheme. If the aggravation occurs during Commonwealth employment the applicable scheme would be the SRC Act 1988. This was acknowledged during the planning of the Ready Reserve concept.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 20 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the third report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which outlined a number of findings regarding the level of unfunded public sector superannuation liabilities:
(1) What is the current level of these liabilities for Commonwealth employee superannuation.
(2) Would a figure of $40 billion be close to the mark.
(3) What progress has been made on the calculation of the figure on the current level of superannuation debt and the development of forward estimates for the next 20 to 30 years.

(4) With reference to the difficult exercise of reporting public sector superannuation debt under a non-accrual accounting structure, what are the details of any plans to report the debt on a regular and meaningful basis.

(5) With reference to a recommendation in the third report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for the convening of a super summit, at which State and Federal Finance ministers would develop a plan of action to address mounting public sector super debt, when will the department respond to this recommendation and when will the summit be convened.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The most recent report on superannuation liabilities in respect of the Commonwealth's civilian employees is entitled "Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme: A report on the long-term costs by the Australian Government Actuary—using data to 30 June 1988". This report was tabled in the House of Representatives on 14 May 1990 and in the Senate on 16 May 1990. It quantified the existing liability in respect of past service benefits in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) as an estimated $33 billion. The liability net of taxation and social security "clawback" was estimated at $18 billion. Since that time the Government has introduced the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS) which was expected to be a lower employer cost scheme. The Australian Government Actuary will next review the superannuation liabilities under the PSS and CSS in 1993-94, based on data as at 30 June 1993.

(2) Some commentators have estimated that the Commonwealth's superannuation liabilities, including those for the military schemes, are currently around $40 billion. Based on the estimated past service liabilities for the CSS in the Australian Government Actuary's 1990 report and actuarial estimates of liabilities in respect of then current contributors to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits scheme calculated in 1990, a $40 billion figure may be close to the mark. However, as noted in answer to Question 1 above, a reliable figure in respect of superannuation liabilities will not be available until the Australian Government Actuary completes the reviews of Commonwealth schemes that will be conducted in 1993-94.

(3) In the report tabled in May 1990, the Australian Government Actuary projected estimated CSS costs as a percentage of salaries for superannuation purposes to the year 2050, the period over which the benefits were expected to be paid in respect of then existing contributors to the scheme. It is expected that the Australian Government Actuary's next report, covering both the PSS and the CSS, will project the estimated superannuation costs over a similar period in line with projected benefit payments.
(4) The Australian Government Actuary performed reviews of the long term costs of the CSS as at 30 June 1982, 1985 and 1988. The report of

ANSWER.PARA: each review was tabled in the Parliament. With the concurrence of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the triennial review of the CSS which, if the PSS had not been introduced from 1 July 1990, would have been conducted as at 30 June 1991, was deferred to 1993-94 to allow adjustment of records in respect of transfers from the CSS to the PSS during 1990-91. In keeping with the past review cycle and, now, the Occupational Superannuation Standards, actuarial assessment of liabilities and costs will return to three-yearly intervals thereafter. The Government's decision to introduce accrual based reporting for departments, announced by the Minister for Finance in November 1992, will provide for further comprehensive information to be reported to Parliament on superannuation liabilities.

PARA.TAB: (5) The Government is currently considering its response to the third report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1991-92 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission annual report, which details expenditure of $204.5 million for the year on 20,139 participants in Community Development Employment Projects, an average cost per week of $195.28 per participant, what are the maximum and minimum weekly rates paid to individual participants in the scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In the 1991/92 financial year the total Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) budget was $204.5 million. A breakdown of the budget is Wages $150.590 million, Oncosts (now

ANSWER.PARA: CDEP Recurrent ) $30.877 million and Support (now Capital) $23.055 million.

PARA.TAB: The Wages grant is paid by communities to participants for work done; the Oncosts or CDEP Recurrent grant is used to meet the recurrent costs of administering CDEPs and servicing CDEP Work Plans, and the Support or Capital grant is used for large capital items needed to achieve the goals of the CDEP Work Plan.

The CDEP Wages grant is allocated to a community based on the number of persons on the participant schedule multiplied by an Average Per Participant (APP) rate determined by the Department of Finance for remote and non-remote areas. As at 1 January 1992 the Remote Rate was $158.00 and Non-remote Rate was $142.90. The APP rates are adjusted in line with the Consumer Price Index, and is currently $162.01 for remote areas and $145.81 for non-remote areas.

Although the wages grant to the community is on the basis of an APP rate this does not mean that every participant receives the APP rate. Under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's Special Conditions for CDEP Grants, the grantee organisation must offer work to all persons listed in the approved CDEP Participant Schedule and every person must be given the opportunity to receive income at a level which is at least equivalent to his/her Job Search or Newstart entitlement. For some participants this will mean an income in excess of the APP rate and for others an income below the APP rate.

Participants are able to be paid above their otherwise Job Search or Newstart Allowance, provided the community have so arranged their wage structure. If the community has structured its wages in such a way that it generates savings it may be able to pay some participants additional weekly income from the Wages grant for work done as follows:
Single participants may earn up to twice the remote participant rate; and
Married couples may earn a combined income of up to four times the remote participant rate.

CDEP participants may also earn additional income from Outside the CDEP Wages grant funds, including "top-up" from CDEP Recurrent grant funds or other sources or from non-CDEP employment. There are however limits as to how much additional income from "other sources" the participant may earn and still remain eligible for CDEP.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: What are the reasons for the difference in the expenditure by the Regional Councils of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in the 1991-92 financial year in Western Australia, where the figure was $484.80 per head or $20,261,006 spent on a 1991 census population of 41,792, compared with New South Wales where the figure was almost four times lower at $131.04 per head, or $9,033,939 spent on a 1991 census population of 68,941.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following response:

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) does not determine its budgetary allocations to Regional Councils on the basis of an equal per capita share.
Assessments of relative need as well as historical recurrent funding commitments are taken into account in determining allocations of program funds to Regional Council areas.

The reasons for the difference in the per capita funding for Western Australia and New South Wales arise from the difference in the level of socio-economic disadvantage of the respective Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations, and from the varying commitments of Local and State Governments in addressing needs. This is reflected in the historical distribution of expenditure by the Commission's predecessors (the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission) and continues to be reflected in the Commission's budgetary allocations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the claim made by Dr Don Edgar from the Australian Institute of Family Studies in Senate Estimates C on 10 May 1993 that he and the then Minister for Social Justice and Family Issues (Mr Howe) came to an understanding that the Living Standards Study was a high priority study that would be fully funded by the Government, is this claim correct?

(2) Why did the Government allow the Australian Institute of Family Studies to continue working on the design of the Living Standards Study for 6 months before informing it that only $1 million of the $1.89 million funding that was being sought would be provided?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)The claim that the Living Standards Study was agreed by Minister Howe to be a high priority study is correct.It is not correct that there was an understanding or agreement that the study would be fully funded.
(2) The Government did not "allow the AIFS to continue working on the design of the Living Standards Study for 6 months" before its funding level was determined.

The Director of AIFS has apologised and corrected his statement made in Senate Estimates C on 10 May 1993. The sequence of funding negotiations for the Australian Living Standards Study (ALSS) is set out below.

During discussions on 11 October 1989, the then Minister for Social Security, the Hon Brian Howe, expressed interest in a study that would address such issues as the relative access of families in different locations to jobs, child care and support services of various kinds in relation to family functioning. AIFS had considered such a study in previous years, with different emphases, but had inadequate finances to mount it.

The study was costed at $3,234,500 over three years to work on eleven (11) areas. The Board of AIFS agreed to contribute approximately $445,000 in staff salaries each year to work on the Living Standards Study, a total AIFS contribution of $1,335,000.
No detailed design work had been done on the study to this point.
On 12 February 1990, a grant of $1,000,000 was approved by Government.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy wanted the study to include a greater focus on rural areas, and agreed to give AIFS an extra $80,000 for one extra area (Roma) and as supplementation for the additional costs for Tennant Creek.

The shortfall of $899,355 was considered by the Institute's Board of Management on 16 February 1990, and it was decided to go ahead with the study in 11 areas, trying to cut down the costs of fieldwork and fit the study into the Institute's budget.

Work on detailed survey and questionnaire design began from the point of receiving approval of the $1 million grant. Advertisements in February 1990 led to the commencement of a Project Manager for ALSS on 19 March 1990. By that time other AIFS staff had already been assigned to the project.
After some discussion, it was determined that the study would be done under contract to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The final contract was signed on 18 December 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the Reserve Bank Governor, or any other officer, contacted by Mr Alwyn Johnson concerning the financial health of the Tasmania Bank; if so, what were the details of the matters raised by Mr Johnson.
(2) Did Mr Johnson specifically ask the Governor of the Reserve Bank not to divulge the matters raised in his letter until they had met and discussed it.

(3) Did the Reserve Bank Governor disregard this request and contact Mr Johnson's superior (Mr Paul Kemp) the day after receiving the letter; if so, why did the Reserve Bank Governor breach the specific request for confidentiality and what did the Reserve Bank Governor tell Mr Kemp.
(4) Was Mr Johnson dismissed from his employment the day after the Reserve Bank Governor spoke to Mr Kemp.
(5) Does the Reserve Bank Governor accept responsibility for Mr Johnson's dismissal and will the Government or the Reserve Bank compensate Mr Johnson for his loss of employment.

(6) Given that the Reserve Bank has been severely criticised by various Royal Commissions inquiring into the collapse of both the State Bank of Victoria and the State Bank of South Australia, for not paying enough attention to the prudential supervision of State banks, why did the Reserve Bank not treat Mr Johnson's concerns seriously.

(7) If an employee of a bank under the supervision of the Reserve Bank has concerns about any of the practices of his or her employers, or the prudential health of his or her employer, how can they bring this type of information to the attention of the Reserve Bank without risking loss of employment.
(8) Will the Government grant some type of legal protection or immunity to whistleblowers to allow them to protect the public interest by exposing corruption; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Governor of the Reserve Bank received a letter from Mr Alwyn Johnson dated 1 July 1991 and marked `Strictly Private & Confidential'.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Governor discussed the letter with Mr Johnson by phone. In view of the matters raised by Mr Johnson, the Governor subsequently judged it appropriate to make inquiries of Mr Kemp (General Manager, Trust Bank).
(4) Yes.
(5) No (to both questions). The Reserve Bank is very clearly of the view that Mr Johnson's departure from Trust Bank was in no way related to the discussion between the Governor and Mr Kemp.

(6) All matters which come to the Reserve Bank's attention relating to prudential supervision of banks are treated very seriously. The Bank's response to matters raised by Mr Johnson was no exception.

(7) The Reserve Bank is mindful of the need to protect its sources of information. It also has statutory responsibilities for prudential supervision of banks and for protection of their depositors. It is possible that, in following up particular allegations about a bank's condition or its management, non-disclosure of the source of such allegations is not a credible option. The Bank would be very concerned, and would object strongly, if it believed that a bank employee had suffered in any way as a result of providing information, in good faith, to it.

(8) The Government is currently examining proposals for legislation to protect whistleblowers as part of its consideration of recommendations made by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law (conducted by the Gibbs Committee) on the disclosure of official information. The desirability of whistleblower legislation as a means of combating fraud is also being examined by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration as part of its inquiry into fraud on the Commonwealth.

(5) Under the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, the following people have been appointed to the Endangered Species Advisory Committee:

Mr David Papps, Deputy Director, Policy and Wildlife, National Parks and Wildlife Service, New South Wales. Representative from the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council;
Dr Gordon Drake, Manager External Relations, Health, Safety and Environmental Affairs, BHP, nominated by the Business Council of Australia. Representative of the business community;
Mr Donald Kratzing, Environmental Scientist for Ampolex Limited, nominated by the Business Council of Australia. Representative of the business community;

Mr Don Pfitzner, Farmer and Grazier, Eudunda, South Australia, Past President, United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia Inc, nominated by the National Farmers Federation. Representative of the rural community;
Prof James Kirkpatrick, Head of Department of Geography and Environmental Studies, University of Tasmania, nominated by the State Conservation Council. Representative of state conservation groups;
Michael Krockenberger, Biodiversity Program Coordinator, Australian Conservation Foundation. A representative of conservation groups;
Dr Ray Nias, Conservation Manager, World Wide Fund For Nature Australia. A representative of conservation groups;
Dr Peter Bridgewater, Chief Executive Officer, Australian Nature Conservation Agency. Representative of the Commonwealth;

Dr Judy West, Program Leader, Australian Flora Resources and Management, Australian National Herbarium, CSIRO Division of Plant Industry. Representative of the scientific community (botanical specialist);
Dr Tim New, Reader in Zoology, La Trobe University, Victoria. Representative of the scientific community (invertebrate specialist);
Dr Meryl Williams, Director, Australian Institute of Marine Science. Representative of the scientific community (marine specialist);
Dr Margaret Brock, Department of Botany, University of New England. Representative of the scientific community (ecological communities and freshwater specialist).

PARA.TAB: (6) The members of the Endangered Species Advisory Committee which represent the scientific community form the Scientific Subcommittee under the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.

(7) The Prime Minister, in his Environment Statement of December 1992, committed the government to the development of a national comprehensive system of parks and reserves, to be achieved in cooperation with the states and territories. I have discussed the matter with my state and territory ministerial colleagues on ANZECC and it is my intention to present a joint paper with the Queensland and Victorian Environment Ministers for consideration at the ANZECC Ministerial Council meeting scheduled for later this year. Consultation with community groups, including the Aboriginal community and non-government organisations will be a matter addressed in the paper.

(8) I am not planning to attend the meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee on the Convention on Biological Diversity to be held in Geneva in September 1993. It is intended that the meeting undertake preparatory work for the first meeting of the Conference of Parties and accordingly will not be at ministerial level.

(9) The government's Coordination Committee on Science and Technology (CCST) has established a working party on access to Australian biological resources and their products. The Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; Foreign Affairs and Trade; Attorney-General's; Primary Industries and Energy; Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services; Employment, Education and Training; and Environment, Sport and Territories; and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation are members of the Working Party. Membership of the Working Party is confined to Commonwealth Government Agencies and does not include non-government organisations such as representatives of the Aboriginal community.
The terms of reference of the working party are:
To examine what action, if any, is required to ensure that:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's scientific, commercial and nature conservation interests are appropriately protected;
Australia's national and international obligations are honoured; and
a fair and equitable share in benefits is obtained by Australia,

in relation to access to, research in and development of Australia's biological resources (all living organisms, including products derived directly or indirectly from them) and in access by collectors and researchers from foreign companies and countries to these resources.

PARA.TAB: Within these Terms of Reference, the Working Party will take into account:

ANSWER.PARA: the adequacy and effectiveness of existing legislation and related processes;
all relevant international treaties, conventions, declarations etc and their status with respect to access to and responsibility for national biological resources;
the need to develop controls and procedures which:

PARA.TAB: provide effective protection of Australia's biological diversity and commercial interests, while
encouraging and promoting appropriate scientific research and the communication of the results of that research;

ANSWER.PARA: methods and/or processes which may encourage and facilitate commercial development in Australia, based on Australia's biological resources;
measures put in place by other countries to regulate access to biological resources.

PARA.TAB: The Working Party will take cognisance of reviews of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 and of any relevant work undertaken by the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council.
The CCST Working Party is expected to report within the next few months to the CCST with the intention of making the report publicly available.

(10) In its report on the ratification and implementation of the Convention, the ANZECC Task Force on Biological Diversity identifies the control of access to Australia's genetic resources as an issue of national importance requiring urgent attention. The Task Force recommends that First Ministers arrange for the establishment of a Commonwealth, State and Territory Working Group to investigate and report on the strengthening of existing controls governing access to genetic resources, including legislation. It is my intention to raise this matter with the states and territories.
(11) I have previously indicated my intention to have a National Strategy for the Conservation of Australia's Biological Diversity adopted by the end of 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the book entitled The Prime Minister was a Spy a fabrication; if so, was the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO) involved.
(2) Was the short story published by Pascoe Publishers Victoria and written by the former Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), entitled Shiny Brass Coffin Handles, related to matters raised in the book in (1).

(3) Were there United States Executive orders linking the Central Intelligence Agency, ASIO and the Australian Government with respect to the late Hon. Harold Holt; if so, will the Government introduce legislation with respect to interference by foreign government intelligence agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Attorney-General has not seen this book and so cannot comment on whether it is a fabrication.
(2) The Attorney-General has seen this short story but can see no connection with any of the matters the Honourable Senator has raised.

(3) Section 19(1)(c) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 (the ASIO Act) provides that the Attorney-General may authorise the Director-General of Security to liaise with specified authorities of other countries. Consistent with the practice of successive Commonwealth Governments in the interests of security, the Attorney-General does not propose to comment on any matter concerning ASIO's operations, such as whether it has any relationship with foreign authorities.

In respect of legislation to deal with interference by foreign government intelligence agencies, the Attorney-General advises that subsection 17(1)(a) of the ASIO Act already provides that one of ASIO's functions is to obtain, correlate and analyse intelligence relevant to security, one aspect of which involves the protection of, and the people of, the Commonwealth and the several States and Territories from acts of foreign interference.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What redress does a constituent, living in Derby, Western Australia, have, and against whom, when he believes he has been overcharged by Telecom for calls which, although made to engaged numbers, have recorded a charge for which he has subsequently been billed.

(2) Does the Federal Consumer Affairs Bureau have past experience of complaints from Telecom customers who believe they have been incorrectly charged for dialling and reaching an already engaged number.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Transport and Communications advises that there are a number of possible avenues of redress available to people who believe they have been overcharged by Telecom, including:
Telecom's internal disputes resolution mechanism;
the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL);
the Commonwealth Ombudsman (until the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman commences operation);
the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (from the date of commencement of operation); and
normal mechanisms of legal redress (e.g. Small Claims Court).

(2) I am advised that the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs, which is not primarily a complaint handling body, is aware of some allegations by Telecom customers of incorrect bills, including being charged for calls made to engaged numbers. Further, I am advised that the volume of such allegations over recent years about Telecom accounts is extremely low.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What advice has the Australian Government received concerning the applicability of the disciplinary provisions of Part III of the Public Service Act 1922 to unattached public service officers appointed by the Executive Council as heads of Australian diplomatic missions.

(2) Has an unattached officer of the Commonwealth Public Service ever been charged with misconduct under Part III of the Public Service Act 1922 for actions while serving as the Head of an Australian diplomatic mission under appointment by the Executive Council: if so, was specific advice sought in relation to the power to make charges under Part III provisions, bearing in mind the provisions of Part IV.

(3) Did the Privacy Commissioner write to the then Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Dr Wilenski) on 26 October 1992, advising him that he was conducting an investigation under section 40 of the Privacy Act 1988 into complaints made by the former Australian Ambassador to Chile (Mr Malcolm Dan): if so, has the department made a complete response to all points raised by the Privacy Commissioner; if not, how long will it take the department to make a complete response.

(4) (a) What was the total cost of the investigation of allegations of misconduct made against Mr Dan; (b) how many times did the team or members of the team visit posts where Mr Dan had served; (c) what were the dates of those visits; and (d) have any other such investigations been carried out by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; if so, what was the total cost of each.

(5) Has Mr Dan made any complaints of irregularities in the investigation of allegations of misconduct made against him in relation to his posting as Ambassador to Chile and Ambassador to Argentina; and (b) has he made any complaints about the subsequent process of inquiry under section 61(2) of the Public Service Act 1922; if so, what are those complaints and what investigations did the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade initiate to determine the truth of those allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by my Department that the answer to the honourable senator's question is follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department has received advice concerning the applicability of the disciplinary provisions of Part III of the Public Service Act 1922 (the Act) to officers of the Department who are appointed as Heads of Mission on the following occasions:

(i) 30 March 1989—This advice was provided by the Attorney-General's Department and concludes that unattached officers of the Australian Public Service are subject to disciplinary action under the Act;

(ii) 4 July 1990—This advice was provided by the Department's Administrative Law Section. It concludes that officers of the Department who are appointed Heads of Mission are unattached officers for the duration of their appointment and can therefore be charged with misconduct under Section 63L of the Act;

(iii) 10 December 1990—This advice was provided by the Department's Administrative Law Section. It considers the possible disciplining of Heads of Mission under Section 63J(2) of the Act, and concludes that, as unattached officers, Heads of Mission may be disciplined for improper conduct under this Section;

(iv) 20 December 1990—This advice was provided by the Department's Administrative Law Section. It concludes that HOMs are unattached officers and fall under the discipline regime set out in Sections 63J and 63L of the Act. It also concludes that these provisions provide a separate disciplinary regime for unattached officers;

(v) 21 December 1990—This advice was provided by the Attorney-General's Department. It states that when an officer of the Australian Public Service is appointed as a Head of Mission that officer becomes unattached and is deemed to be on leave of absence without pay. Such officers may be charged with misconduct under Section 63L of the Act;

(vi) 28 April 1992—This advice was provided by the Australian Government Solicitor. It concludes that if charges are laid under Section 63J against an unattached officer and that officer is subsequently reattached there are doubts as to whether those charges could proceed further;
(vii) 23 November 1992—This advice was provided by Queens Counsel. It concludes that charges against an unattached officer under Section 63J must be disposed of before that officer is reattached.

(2) Only one unattached officer has been charged with misconduct under Part III of the Public Service Act for actions while serving as the head of an Australian diplomatic mission under appointment by the Executive Council. The charges were drafted by the Australian Government Solicitor, taking into account the provisions of Parts III and IV of the Public Service Act.

In addition, one former head of an Australian diplomatic mission has been charged with misconduct under Part III of the Act. Those charges were brought against the officer after he had been reattached but related to alleged misconduct while he had been head of mission and therefore unattached. The charges were dismissed by the Inquiry Officer largely on the facts of the case. Subsequent legal advice concerning an unrelated matter indicated, as noted in answer (1)(vii) above, that if charges are laid under Part III of the Act against an attached officer for misconduct while that officer was unattached there is a doubt whether those charges would stand.

(3) Yes, the Privacy Commissioner wrote to Dr Wilenski in October 1992 advising that he was conducting an investigation under section 40 of the Privacy Act following a complaint by Mr Dan under section 36 of the Act. The Department has provided a full response to the letter.

(4) (a) The cost to the Department of the investigation of allegations of misconduct against Mr Dan so far is $15,139. That cost includes travel to Santiago and Buenos Aires by two Departmental investigators and their accommodation and allowances; (b) two Departmental officers travelled to Santiago and Buenos Aires to carry out the investigation into allegations against Mr Dan. They travelled together and on one occasion only. They were accompanied to Santiago by an officer from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; (c) the visit to Santiago was made from 18 April to 3 May 1991 and to Buenos Aires from 3 to 7 May 1991; (d) since the establishment in March 1989 of a discrete area within the Department dealing with fraud and discipline matters, there have been 180 separate investigations into allegations of misconduct, mal-administration or fraud, including the investigation into Mr Dan. Of that number, 77 of the investigations were in relation to allegations by the so-called "Officers Revolutionary Council". Nine overseas posts have been visited in the course of those investigations, in addition to the two posts visited during the Dan investigation, at a total cost of $81,352.

Departmental investigations into fraud and misconduct are carried out by the Fraud Prevention and Discipline Section. That Section has a notional complement of five officers headed by a Director at the Senior Officer Grade B level. As well as its investigative function, the Section is responsible for providing policy advice on fraud and discipline matters and carrying out pro-active functions including fraud awareness seminars and fraud risk assessments. As it is not possible to determine accurately the number of staff hours dedicated to any particular investigation, no attempt has been made to provide these costs.

(5) (a) Yes, Mr Dan has made a number of allegations to the Privacy Commissioner of irregularities in the investigation of allegations of misconduct made against him in relation to his posting as Ambassador to Chile and Ambassador to Argentina. As noted above, the Department has provided a full response to the Privacy Commissioner addressing all of these allegations. Following is a summary of the allegations:

that the Department collected personal information by unlawful or unfair means contrary to Information Privacy Principle 1 (IPP 1) and that the collection of that information was unreasonably intrusive contrary to IPP 3;
that the Department used information without first taking reasonable steps to ensure that the personal information was accurate, up to date and complete contrary to IPP 8;

that the Department disclosed personal information relating to Mr Dan contrary to IPP 11 and possibly failed to protect adequately from unauthorised disclosure records containing personal information relating to Mr Dan contrary to IPP 4.

(b) Yes, Mr Dan made complaints about various aspects of the Inquiry into three charges of misconduct which were finalised in September 1991. The three charges were proven. Mr Dan's complaints included:
an allegation that an officer involved in the investigations sat in on the Inquiry in 1991 despite assurances to the contrary. (This was not the case);

an allegation that he was unable to properly present his case because witnesses did not give oral evidence and no cross examination was possible. (The Inquiry was conducted according to procedural requirements. It is an administrative process and the rules of evidence do not apply);
a challenge to the evidence on which the Inquiry Officer's findings were based;
a challenge to the jurisdiction of the Inquiry Officer under the Act;

an allegation that he was denied the opportunity to gather evidence due to his absence from Santiago. (This was not the case. There was no restriction placed on his movements and it was open to Mr Dan to return to Santiago if he so wished).

Mr Dan was granted leave by the Merit Protection Review Authority for an extension of time to appeal the three findings of misconduct by the Inquiry Officer. A Disciplinary Appeal Committee (DAC) hearing was scheduled for February 1993. Mr Dan withdrew his appeal to the DAC shortly prior to the proposed hearing. In doing this, he brought the matter of the three charges to a close.

An Inquiry into seven charges of misconduct is still in progress. Mr Dan made an application to the Federal Court seeking review of the following alleged decisions by the Inquiry Officer regarding these seven charges:
not to investigate the alleged alteration of a document;
to proceed with the Inquiry prior to the completion of FOI requests made by Mr Dan;
to conduct the Inquiry without hearing oral evidence and without allowing the cross examination of witnesses;
to proceed with the Inquiry without requiring the Department to make available all documents in its possession to Mr Dan;
to proceed with the Inquiry before Mr Dan's request for documents from other Departments had been satisfied;
to assert jurisdiction under Part III of the Act;
Mr Dan has withdrawn this application to the Federal Court.

Mr Dan also issued court proceedings challenging the appointment of the original Inquiry Officer. In accordance with its legal advice, the Department revoked the appointment and appointed a new Inquiry Officer.
In addition, Mr Dan has made complaints about various aspects of the Inquiry into the seven charges including:

the Department's alleged failure to provide him with copies of various documents. (The Inquiry Officer has provided Mr Dan with copies of all the documents from the Department and other Commonwealth sources which are to be taken into account by the Inquiry Officer);

the Department's alleged failure to permit Mr Dan to present his account of events prior to the laying of the seven charges and the appointment of the Inquiry Officer. (The Department complied with all the procedural requirements in laying the charges and appointing the Inquiry Officer. Mr Dan has now made written submissions to the Inquiry Officer);
the cost of the Inquiry to the Commonwealth and to himself;

the alleged differences in the treatment of Mr Dan and the treatment of Mr Burke, the former Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See. (Unlike Mr Dan, Mr Burke was not an unattached officer of the Australian Public Service during his time as Ambassador to Ireland and thus was not subject to Part III of the Act);

the laying of the seven charges contrary to an alleged assurance by the Inquiry Officer into the first three charges that no further charges would be laid. (That Inquiry Officer has by affidavit sworn that no such assurance was given);

the reliance placed on the reports and statements of the investigators by the Department and the Australian Government Solicitor. (It is open to Mr Dan to challenge any of the evidence before the Inquiry Officer during the course of the Inquiry);

alleged tampering with a document. (On the advice of Counsel, the Inquiry Officer referred these allegations to the Department's Fraud Prevention and Discipline Section (FDS) for investigation. FDS found that there was no evidence of tampering with Departmental documents but concluded that the matter should be referred to the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) for investigation as there was evidence that one of DAS's documents may have been altered. Mr Dan has also referred this matter to the Australian Federal Police);

challenging the Inquiry Officer's jurisdiction under the Public Service Act. (The Inquiry Officer has written to Mr Dan to inform him that although he is inclined to accept the Department's legal advice that he does have jurisdiction he will hear Mr Dan's submissions on this point in the course of the Inquiry. At the Inquiry Officer's invitation, Mr Dan has provided his written submissions);

challenging the appropriateness of the Department's investigation into the alleged tampering with a document and alleging flaws in the Department's report. (The Inquiry Officer has informed Mr Dan that he may require further investigations into this aspect depending on the material presented to him by Mr Dan during the Inquiry);

alleging that there is a campaign against him which has included the fabrication of evidence, embellishment and falsification of official reports on investigations, offering bribes to potential witnesses, failure to caution him before taking evidence, concoction of the bases of the charges, posing of an officer as a policeman to intimidate staff, threats to locally engaged staff, illegal taping of witnesses, submission of false and untested material to the Australian Government Solicitor, Australian Federal Police, & Director of Public Prosecutions. (It is the role of the Inquiry Officer to examine the evidence before him during the course of the Inquiry. It is also open to Mr Dan to challenge any of this evidence by way of written or oral submission).
It would be inappropriate for the Department to comment further on these matters whilst the Inquiry is still in progress.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 4 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have any koalas exported from Australia to approved United States (US) zoos been loaned to any other zoos; if so, please list these zoos.
(2) Have any progeny of koalas exported from Australia to approved US zoos been loaned to any other zoos; if so, please list these zoos.
(3) Have any of these US zoos ever had their facilities checked by Australian authorities; if so, please list these zoos.
(4) Have any of these US zoos ever been given specific approval by these authorities to receive koalas; if so, please list these zoos.
(5) Which US zoos have given an undertaking that they will not trade commercially in koalas and will details of any such undertakings be provided.
(6) What are the mortality statistics for koalas in Japanese zoos.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Current controls governing the export of native fauna were introduced with the proclamation of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 on 1 May 1984. Regulation 7 to the Act provides the basis for limiting overseas zoos from trading in native fauna. Based on the information received from the USA approved zoos, no koala exported since 1 May 1984 has been loaned to any other zoo.
Koalas exported to San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles Zoos prior to 1 May 1984 have been loaned to the following zoos: Cincinnati; Columbus; Minnesota; Toronto; Chicago; Hogle and Audubon.
(2) Progeny that were born to koalas exported from Australia since 1 May 1984 have been loaned to the Atlanta and Chicago zoos.

In addition to these loans, progeny that were born to koalas that were exported from Australia prior to 1 May 1984 have been loaned to the following zoos: Toronto and Granby in Canada; Lisbon in Portugal; Dublin in Ireland; London in England; Busch Gardens; Denver; San Antonio; Philadelphia; Topeka; Louisville; Memphis; Milwaukee; St Louis; Indianapolis; Buffalo; Oklahoma; Seattle; Sacramento; Washington; Toledo; Minnesota; New York and Columbus in the USA.

(3) Some of these zoos have been visited by Australian authorities due to proposals to receive other native fauna from Australia, but none has been visited specifically to inspect its koala facilities.
(4) None of these zoos has been given specific approval by Australian authorities to receive koalas.

(5) The Directors of each of the three USA zoos approved under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 to receive koalas from Australia, namely San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles, have each signed declarations stating that each will ensure that their zoo does not engage in commercial trade in specimens of native Australian fauna.
(6) Specific mortality rates for koalas in Japanese zoos are currently being sought. This information will be provided to the honourable senator as soon as it is available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is Australia required to produce a national statement on population by September 1993 for the Preparatory Committee of the United Nations' Conference on Population and Development.
(2) Has the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been given responsibility for Australia's participation in this conference; if so, why.
(3) What measures are being taken to prepare a statement.
(4) Will there be any form of community consultation in preparing a statement.
(5) What role did Australia play in the recent Preparatory Committee in New York in May 1993.

(6) At the Preparatory Committee in May 1993, why did Mr Richard Butler, head of Australia's delegation to the United Nations, give his country's statement after the chairman had specifically asked that he wanted only `conceptual feedback on the draft statement'.
(7) What role will Australia play at the next Preparatory Committee meeting in April 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Secretary-General of the International Conference on Population and Development invited each participating country to prepare a national report on population issues for the 1994 Conference. National Reports are to be submitted to the Secretariat of the Conference by 30 September 1993.

(2) Preparations for Australia's involvement in the Conference involve a number of Commonwealth Government Departments and Agencies including Foreign Affairs and Trade; AIDAB; Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; the Office of the Status of Women; Environment, Sport and Territories; and Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services. The range of Departments involved reflects the number of complex issues to be addressed by the Conference. As the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio has responsibility for population coordination issues and was responsible for preparations and participation in the last International Conference on Population in 1984, that Department has taken on a coordinating role for national activities. Foreign Affairs and Trade will remain responsible ultimately for the international aspects of the Conference.

(3) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is responsible for coordinating Australia's preparations for, and participation in the Conference including the preparation of Australia's national report. I understand that the national report will be submitted to the Secretariat by 30 September 1993.

(4) The Government accepts and supports the general principle that there needs to be consultation with the community on the range of issues to be addressed in the national report. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has established an inter-departmental committee which is in the process of examining options which will allow for effective participation and input from a cross-section of the community.

(5) Australia participated actively in the 2nd Preparatory Committee meeting for the Conference held in New York in May 1993. Australia was represented at the Preparatory Committee meeting by a delegation led by Ambassador Butler which also comprised technical experts from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and AIDAB.

(6) The Chairman's request that delegates address the draft conceptual framework was not intended to preclude any relevant comments. Ambassador Butler made Australia's statement during the first session of debate on the conceptual framework and did address it. In addition, the delegation submitted a number of Australian position papers to the Secretariat to enable it to take into account more detailed Australian views which could not be addressed fully in an oral statement of limited duration.
(7) Australia will continue to play an active role in the preparations for the conference, including at the Preparatory Committee in April 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 4 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Australian media report the explosion at Tomsk, immediately after it occurred, as a `3' on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), on which Chernobyl was said to be a `7' and what is the significance of a `3' on the INES.
(2) Did subsequent evaluations of the accident indicate that the explosion at Tomsk was a least a `5' or possibly a `6' on the INES.
(3) What are the details of the stage in the process at which the accident actually occurred.

(4) Did an emergency committee which was set up in the wake of the accident state that Russian airforce monitoring planes reported a radioactive cloud at an altitude of 3000 metres travelling at 36 kph and that 20 tonnes of radioactive material had been released by the explosion.

(5)(a) Did the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) ever conduct a safety inspection of the Tomsk site; (b) did they have any knowledge of safety systems at Tomsk; (c) does the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) have knowledge of the Tomsk site; and (d) will there now be an IAEA inspection of the Tomsk site; if so, will ANSTO personnel be involved in any way.

(6) Is the process used in plutonium separation at Tomsk broadly similar to processes used in plants at Sellafield in the United Kingdom (UK), La Hague and Marcoule in France, and in weapons-related plants in the United States (US) and did a similar explosion take place in the UK in 1973.
(7) Does ANSTO still intend to send some of its spent fuel to be reprocessed in a similar manner in the US, and has the accident at Tomsk in any way affected plans so far.

(8) Has the Tomsk site been chosen as the site for the disposal of plutonium from warheads dismantled under the START treaty, and has the Tomsk regional Parliament vetoed or tried to veto this development.
(9) Did the Australian media misrepresent the real significance of the Tomsk accident and grossly down-play it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Tomsk-7 is a military nuclear reprocessing facility in Siberia, about 3000 km from Moscow and 230 km from the city of Novosibirsk. The accident occurred in facility N15 of the Tomsk chemical complex, some 115 km from the main Tomsk-7 installation and 28 km from the town of Tomsk. The immediately surrounding area is not densely populated. The accident occurred in an above ground section of the N15 facility, most of which is located underground. N15 is surrounded by a perimeter fence some 8 km from the plant. The accident referred to in your question occurred on 6 April 1993.
The specific answers to the questions are:

(1) Yes. The INES was developed jointly by the IAEA and the Nuclear Energy Agency of the OECD to communicate promptly and consistently to the public the safety significance of reported events at nuclear installations. It classifies each event at one of seven levels—from a level 1 `anomaly', to a level 7 `major accident' with serious and widespread health and environmental effects. The INES is logarithmic, similar to the Richter scale for earthquakes. An increase in the INES from one level to the next represents an increase of approximately ten times in severity. Thus the Chernobyl accident, at level 7, was at least 10,000 times greater in severity than a Tomsk-like level 3 event. Level 3 is the lowest level event involving an off-site release of radioactivity above authorised limits. It corresponds to the most exposed person off-site receiving a dose of radiation of the order of tenths of a millisievert. Such a dose is about one tenth of the annual dose typically received from natural background radiation.

(2) No. It is possible that more detailed analysis of an event may result in its initially assessed INES level being raised or lowered. This has not occurred with the Tomsk explosion. The event was investigated by two special commissions, one from the State Committee for Emergency Situations and the other from the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy. Their findings were later corroborated by an international observer team invited to the site. The international team reported that, although the facility was extensively damaged by the explosion, the radiological effects appear to have been minimal. The total release of radioactivity at Tomsk is estimated to have been about 40 Curies, which is about one millionth of the Chernobyl release. A subsequent independent analysis by Russia's Kurchatov Institute confirmed that the explosion had limited radiological impact.

(3) The available information suggests that Tomsk-7 is a military reprocessing plant using the `Purex' process to extract plutonium from irradiated uranium. Irradiated uranium fuel is first cut into pieces and the uranium dissolved in nitric acid. The early stages in the process separate most of the radioactive fission products from the uranium using an organic solvent. The explosion is believed to have occurred at a later stage, when nitric acid is added to a uranium nitrate-organic complex, in solution. It is understood that a release of gases in this stage, believed to be due to insufficient stirring of the solution, ruptured the tank holding the material and caused an electrical short circuit which lead to a fire and the explosion. The accident has been attributed to human error.

(4) Not according to the reports made available to me. Early media reports quoted the emergency committee as saying the wind had blown the radiation away from the plant to the north east. Media reports of a `radioactive cloud' attributed the details to Russian television or `local officials'. The international observer team noted that the wind was light and that it was snowing at the time of the accident, which may have helped limit the spread of the material released. Available information suggests that much less than 10 tonnes of material were released, mostly within the plant boundary.

(5)(a) No. The IAEA conducts safety inspections of civil nuclear facilities at the invitation of member states. As military-related applications were conducted at the Tomsk site, the IAEA was never invited to conduct a safety inspection there.
(b) I am advised that the IAEA had no prior knowledge of safety systems at Tomsk.
(c) ANSTO has no direct knowledge of the Tomsk-7 military site.
(d) No invitation to inspect the site has been issued to the IAEA.

(6) Variations of the Purex solvent-extraction process are used in all the plants. The explosion which occurred on 26 September 1973 at the B204 head end plant at the Windscale reprocessing plant in the UK took place at the initial stage in reprocessing and involved the fission products and the solvent. The radioactivity released was confined within the building.

(7) The Australian Government's 1985 approval in principle for the return of 450 spent fuel elements from ANSTO's HIFAR research reactor to the US remains in force. Subject to further environmental assessments, the US Department of Energy expects to reactivate its policy of receiving foreign research reactor fuel for storage and eventual disposal in the US.

(8) I understand that Tomsk was one of the sites listed for the disposal of plutonium from warheads dismantled under the START treaties and protocols and I am not aware of any decision to remove the site from the list. The only actions of the Tomsk regional Parliament of which I am aware are its appeal to the Russian Supreme Soviet on 17 April 1993 for 210 billion roubles (about $250 million) to deal with the consequences of the incident, and its appeal to the Presidium of the Russian Supreme Soviet that the site be placed under local rather than federal control.
(9) Australian media reports of the Tomsk accident appear to have been generally responsible. Their early reporting of the accident as a level 3 event on the INES has not needed to be modified.

PARA.TAB: A downwards deflator adjustment was made to both the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) in the 1992-93 Additional Estimates Bills. The adjustments are a consequence of the triennial funding arrangements which are in place for both organisations.
Under these arrangements the Government has agreed to maintain funding to the SBS and the ABC in real terms, based on actual movements in the Non-farm Gross Domestic Product (GDP non-farm) deflator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 10 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is smoking still allowed on Qantas aircraft given that Qantas ground operations are smoke free.

(2) Given that the workplace of a Qantas aircraft is covered by Australian law and Qantas is owned and operated by the Australian people, why does the Federal Government not ban smoking on Qantas aircraft in line with the rest of the company and Federal Occupational Health and Safety legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under Air Navigation Regulation 246 smoking is banned on all regular public transport aircraft, including Qantas flights, engaged in operations between aerodromes within Australia.

With regard to international flights, the government has approached Australian carriers encouraging them to voluntarily ban smoking on flights to and from Australia. To date Qantas has imposed voluntary smoking bans on all its trans-Tasman flights and three of its weekly non-stop Sydney-Los Angeles flights. From 1 August this year all Qantas flights of four hours or less will be smoke-free.

With Qantas support, the government has pursued the issue of in-flight smoking on international flights in the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). Australia successfully co-sponsored a resolution which was adopted by the 29th General Assembly of ICAO last year, that calls upon all member states to take necessary measures as soon as possible to restrict smoking progressively on all international passenger flights, with the objective of implementing complete bans by 1 July 1996.
(2) The government is committed to implement the ICAO Resolution referred to in my response to Question (1). Legislation to give effect to the Resolution by banning smoking on international

ANSWER.PARA: passenger services to and from Australia is currently under consideration.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force: Training of Overseas Personnel

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have any Australian Defence Force personnel been involved in training any military, para-military, police or maritime surveillance personnel from other countries from 1987 to date.

(2) Was any training provided to the personnel from: (a) Papua New Guinea; (b) Malaysia; (c) Indonesia; (d) Singapore; (e) Philippines; (f) Thailand; (g) Fiji; (h) Tonga; (i) the Solomon Islands; (j) Kiribati; (k) Vanuatu; (l) Western Samoa; (m) the Federated States of Micronesia; (n) the Marshall Islands; (o) Cook Islands; or (p) Brunei; if so, what training was provided to personnel from each of these countries and did it include training on human rights, the handling of prisoners or detainees, interrogation techniques or the handling of civil unrest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(a) to (p) Each year, an extensive program of Australian Defence Force (ADF) training is provided under Defence Cooperation and cost recovery basis to these countries. Training is provided through courses conducted by Navy, Army and Air Force, courses at the Joint Service training establishments, ADF personnel posted in-country, and combined military exercises.

Within ADF training, the subject of human rights is not covered as a separate curriculum. As part of broader courses training is provided on Australia's obligations under international humanitarian law, which includes the application of the Laws of Armed Conflict (LOAC), and in particular, the 1949 Geneva Convention and its two Additional Protocols.

International humanitarian law issues are covered in initial employment training for officer cadets, promotion or career development courses, single Service Staff College, the Joint Services Staff College and other routine training courses. Foreign students attending these courses receive the same periods of instruction regarding international humanitarian law as their ADF counterparts.

Navy has trained personnel from all the countries listed. Numerous courses are offered to foreign students of all ranks, providing training in the command and staff, technical and maintenance aspects of Naval operations.

Training in the operation of Pacific Patrol Boats for maritime surveillance is also provided by Navy personnel to the Solomon Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Tonga, Western Samoa, the Cook Islands, Fiji and Kiribati. This includes tuition in boarding party procedures and questioning techniques used during the unopposed boarding of a vessel in a fisheries surveillance context.

Army has trained personnel from all the countries listed, with courses relating to officer development, Corps specific training and logistics and support subjects. Courses that cover the LOAC include Royal Military College Duntroon, Junior Staff Course, Command and Staff College, Intermediate and Advanced Operations Courses and Sub Unit Training.
The Army also conducts training specifically developed for other countries and instances where this training has dealt with humanitarian considerations include:

In November 1992 at the Land Warfare Centre (LWC), Canungra, fifteen foreign officers received brief instruction on prisoner of war handling including the provisions of the Geneva Convention and Australian Army procedures. The officers came from the Philippines, Thailand, Tonga, Indonesia and Malaysia;
The LWC has conducted in-country military skills training for members of the Royal Solomon Islands Police, and the Vanuatu Police Force, which has included aspects of the LOAC;

Training conducted by the LWC for the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) has included instruction in the LOAC, Rules of Engagement, Orders for Opening Fire and the proper treatment of civilians, suspects and prisoners in aid-to-the-civil-power roles; and,

An ADF adviser attached to the PNG-Australia Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) Development Project from July 1990 to December 1992, provided training for the RPNGC Special Services Division (Mobile Squads) in discretionary use of force, legal responsibilities and prisoner handling.

Air Force has trained personnel from PNG, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines, Thailand and Brunei. Courses are offered to all ranks, and include training in aircraft operation and maintenance and support roles. Due to the technical nature of most of these courses LOAC issues received only limited attention.

In addition, Defence Cooperation funding together with funding from AIDAB, was used to assist the Human Rights Commission to conduct a series of seven seminars in the Philippines early in 1993 to a target audience of between 700 and 1000 military and police officers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent reports from the United States (US) concerning health problems being faced by US defense personnel who served in the Gulf War:
(1) Has the Minister been briefed by the US Department of Defense concerning this issue.
(2) Are Australian Defence personnel suffering any health problems arising from their service in the Gulf War.
(3) Do the Australian Defence forces use either ammunition or equipment that contains `depleted uranium'.
(4) Are some of the health problems of US defense personnel due to exposure to radiation from `depleted uranium'.

(5) What action is the Australian Department of Defence taking to protect the health and safety of Australian defence personnel and civilians in the light of these concerns about the radiation exposures from `depleted uranium'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The US Department of Defense has not provided a formal briefing on this issue nor is there any reason to require such a briefing. The Office of the Surgeon General Australian Defence Force is monitoring developments with the United States and British Defence Forces and will take any necessary action where advice received may have a bearing on Australian personnel.
(2) One case of illness believed to be attributable to service in the Gulf War has been reported within the Royal Australian Navy. The cause is not believed to be due to exposure to depleted uranium.

(3) The three Services have advised that, to the best of their knowledge, no ammunition is used that contains depleted uranium. However, depleted uranium is used as a balance in the `roll' mechanism of the PAVETAC laser guidance system on board F111 aircraft. In addition it is used in F18, B707 and C130 aircraft as a mass balance in control surfaces (ailerons). In all of the mentioned uses, it is considered safe and indeed is believed to be in similar use in civil aircraft eg B747.
(4) There is no medical evidence at present to link health problems in Gulf War veterans to exposure to depleted uranium.

(5) The Office of the Surgeon General Australian Defence Force is continuing to monitor development on Gulf War health related issues, particularly as they may affect Australian serving and ex—service personnel. When necessary, specific information is sought through Defence medical channels from United States and British sources. A Health Policy Directive has already been issued regarding exposure to oil field fires and procedures for critical incident stress debriefing are in place. Further steps will be taken, when necessary, to protect the health and safety of Australian Defence Force personnel who served in the Gulf conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has Australia's International Development Assistance Bureau provided funds for training in the use of weapons in Papua New Guinea; if so: (a) what did the training involve; (b) when did it take place; and (c) what controls exist for such programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. As part of the Royal PNG Constabulary Development Project weapons training is provided to officers of the RPNGC.

Australia's assistance to the Royal PNG Constabulary is to support the Papua New Guinea Government's efforts in developing a community-based policing strategy. Phase 1 of the RPNGC Development Project concluded on 31 December 1992 and Phase 2 has been underway since 1 January 1993.

The Royal PNG Constabulary Project Phase 1 operated for five years from December 1987 to December 1992. It has laid the foundations for a significant improvement in the capability of the RPNGC to carry out preventive and reactive policing tasks. The fundamental approach of the project was to provide assistance to the RPNGC through the provision of training and advice incorporated in six project components, namely: operations support; training support; scientific services;financial and administration management; personnel management; and information technology.

As a result of agreements made at the Papua New Guinea-Australia Ministerial Forum in January 1990, Phase 1 of the project was extended to include training for the Papua New Guinea Special Services Division (Mobile Squads) of the RPNGC. The objective of the extended assistance was to organise and train the Mobile Squads to develop an operational capability to effectively carry out police tasks associated with civil unrest and internal security, such as prevention of tribal fighting, crowd control or search and rescue.

Phase 1 provided for formal training in the use of firearms to the Papua New Guinea Squads as part of the training program. The training was provided to encourage the safe and responsible use of firearms in accordance with the laws of Papua New Guinea and with Constabulary's emphasis on the use of minimum force. The training was similar to that which would be provided within an Australian Police Service. The contents page of the training manual is at Attachment A.

(a) Training focused on field tactics appropriate for the range of situations faced by the police in PNG and to enable the squads to meet their primary role in combating civil disturbances and maintaining public safety.

The formal firearms training strictly complies with the "Weapons Training" topics specified in the Mobile Squads Training Syllabus. The topics were approved by senior executives within the RPNGC. The training methods were in keeping with project policy.

(b) The firearms training was provided during the period between August 1990, after the implementation document for the PNG Special Services Division (Mobile Squads) was produced, and November 1992 when Phase 1 was concluded. The training took place in Port Moresby and Mt Hagen where the project advisers to the Mobile Squads were based.

(c) The Mobile Squads advisers like all project personnel operated strictly in accordance with the project administration manual in which their roles and responsibilities were set out clearly. Under Phase 1 of the project support and training for the Mobile Squads was provided by four police advisers and one ADF officer. All the advisers were responsible to the Australian Project Manager. The ADF officer was under the command of the Head of the Australian Defence Services (HADS) in the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby but was directed and supervised in his training and advisory role by the Australian Project Manager. The duty statements of the advisers are at Attachment B.

AIDAB and the Papua New Guinea Government continuously monitor adherence to the projects design and implementation requirements. The Managing Contractor provides an Annual Plan each year which specifies the activities for that year. Project progress is measured against the approved Annual Plan through monthly reports and regular project visits by the AIDAB Office at the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby. Six monthly reports are provided to a Project Coordinating Group comprising representatives of the PNG and Australian Governments which assess project progress and gives policy direction. Two major reviews were also undertaken of the project in 1990 and 1992.

In June 1992 a Joint Review Team recommended a second five year phase of the project and Phase 2 was approved by the Papua New Guinea and Australian Governments. This phase seeks to further improve the capability of the RPNGC to preserve peace and good order and to maintain and, as necessary, to enforce the law in an impartial and objective manner. The main focus is to introduce community-based crime prevention and control methods.

ANSWER.PARA: 2.0Prepare, in conjunction with the Project Manager, the inception report, monthly and other reports as required.
3.0Liaise with persons involved with the Project both internally and externally to the RPNGC.

6.0Ensure that the Project strategy in relation to Mobile Squads remains in accordance with the requirements of both Governments and AIDAB specifications.
7.0Carry out training and advisory services as determined by the inception study.

8.0Provide management and supervisory training for Counterparts and other Constabulary personnel, to direct the efficient, effective and ethical delivery of operational functions of the Mobile Squads.
