TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government still support the defence exports guidelines as set out in the Department of Defence publication of March 1992 entitled Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods: Guidelines for Exporters, if not, what is the current policy.
(2) Are exports from Defence Co-operation and Defence (Australian Government Munitions Factory goods) subject to the same controls as described in the guidelines.
(3) Which defence exports are not subject to controls in the guidelines and what controls apply to those exports.
(4) Do the guidelines prohibit the export of defence goods to states `where foreign policy interests outweigh export benefits'.
(5) Do the guidelines say that military goods may not be exported to unstable regions, or to a country that is involved in internal conflict.
(6) Does the ongoing supply of weapons to Papua New Guinea (PNG) under both the Defence Co-operation Sub-program and Defence Export Program, contravene the guidelines; if not, why not.
(7) Is the Government reviewing its supply of weapons and ammunition to PNG because of current tensions; if not, why not.
(8) If a review is taking place, when will it be completed and will it be published; if not, why not.

(9) With reference to military exercises planned for the remainder of 1993 and 1994, for each exercise what are the details of: (a) the name, locations and individual costs; (b) the participating armed forces, including the nationality if not Australian; and (c) the social and environmental impacts relevant to each exercise, including the Government's approach to dealing with these impacts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government still supports the defence exports guidelines as set out in the Department of Defence publication of March 1992 entitled "Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods: Guidelines for Exporters".
(2) Yes.
(3) All defence exports listed in the guidelines are subject to controls.

(4) Yes. Applications to export military and related goods are considered on a case by case basis and in accordance with the terms of Australia's stated policy. The export of defence goods is not permitted where foreign policy interests outweigh export benefits.

(5) Defence exports are not normally permitted to unstable regions or to a country involved in internal conflict. However in some cases such exports are permitted to friends and allies of Australia involved in conflict or where there may be an insurrection against the legitimate government of such a friendly country.
(6) No. The export of defence and related goods to Papua New Guinea (PNG) is consistent with Australia's interests in the security of PNG and our close and longstanding defence relationship.

(7&8) No. The Government considers that the supply of defence equipment to PNG is consistent with Australia's national interests, meets PNG's legitimate defence needs and accords with the guidelines on the export of defence and related goods.
(9)(a&b) Details of future exercises are classified and therefore are not available to be released.
(c) In assessing and dealing with the environmental, including social, impacts of exercises, Defence is bound by the provisions of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is `Circle of Poison' legislation likely to be introduced into the United States (US) legislature in 1994.
(2) If such legislation is to be adopted, is it likely to prohibit the export of heptachlor and chlordane from the US.

(3) If the answer to (1) and (2) is yes, what action is the Australian Government taking to facilitate the implementation of alternative methods of termite control before the cessation of exports of heptachlor and chlordane from the US.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The so called `Circle of Poison' legislation is related to the export of pesticides not registered in the United States and which could return to the US by way of residues of these chemicals in imported foods. It is not known if this will ultimately be promulgated in US legislation or when. However, some of the principles of this legislation are currently encapsulated in a US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) policy, approved in February 1993, and which requires companies to provide multilingual labels on exported US products and notify foreign importers before they export unregistered US products.
(2) Chlordane and heptachlor are conditionally registered in the US under a negotiated agreement with the manufacturer, Velsicol and as such are excluded from the EPA policy on pesticide exports.

(3) There is on-going research into a number of alternatives to heptachlor and chlordane. In addition there is an alternative chemical termiticide already registered for use in Australia and has been in use both here and overseas for a number of years.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 June 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article by Dr Eric Hoskins in Third World Network Features 1029/93, concerning the use of Depleted Uranium Penetrator ammunition.
(1) What discussions have taken place between the Australian and United States governments or defence officials about the use of such ammunition.
(2) Has such ammunition been used by Australian troops in exercises, training or in the field.
(3) Have any approaches been made to the Australian Government or defence officials by officials of other countries proposing to use such ammunition in exercises in Australia.
(4) What is the attitude of the Australian Government to the manufacture and use of ammunition containing radioactive waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No specific discussions have taken place between the Australian and United States governments about the use of depleted uranium ammunition.

(2) The RAN has in the past used ammunition containing depleted uranium. The depleted uranium rounds comprised an initial quantity procured for firing by the 20mm Phalanx Close in Weapons System. In the mid 1980s an Australian variant of the Phalanx round was introduced into service as a replacement for the depleted uranium rounds. In the Australian variant, sintered tungsten is used in lieu of depleted uranium. All Phalanx rounds containing depleted uranium have been expended and the RAN uses only the Australian produced rounds containing sintered tungsten.
(3) No approaches have been made to the Australian Government or defence officials by foreign governments proposing to use depleted uranium ammunition in exercises in Australia.
(4) The government has no plans to either permit local manufacture or to purchase further stocks of depleted uranium ammunition.

(c) Assuming market conditions are suitable and preparations for the sale are complete it is anticipated that the float will take place some time in the second half of the 1993/94 financial year.
(d) & (e) No decisions have yet been taken regarding an employee share scheme or other similar arrangements.
